analemma: An orthographic projection of the sphere on the plane of themeridian, the eye being supposed at an infinite distance, and in theeast or west point of the horizon.
archidiaconal: Of or pertaining to an archdeacon.This offense is liable to be censured in an archidiaconal visitation.Johnson.
abiogenetic: Of or pertaining to abiogenesis. Ab`i*o*ge*net"ic*al*ly, adv.
actinism: The property of radiant energy (found chiefly in solar orelectric light) by which chemical changes are produced, as inphotography.
armor-bearer: One who carries the armor or arms of another; an armiger. Judg.ix. 54.
aerography: A description of the air or atmosphere; aërology.
a priori: Characterizing that kind of reasoning which deducesconsequences from definitions formed, or principles assumed, or whichinfers effects from causes previously known; deductive ordeductively. The reverse of a posteriori.
abstractive: Having the power of abstracting; of an abstracting nature. "Theabstractive faculty." I. Taylor.
antiloimic: A remedy against the plague. Brande & C.
analyzation: The act of analyzing, or separating into constituent parts;analysis.
arteriac: Of or pertaining to the windpipe.
albuminoidal: Of the nature of an albuminoid.
actinomere: One of the radial segments composing the body of one of theCoelenterata.
analgesia: Absence of sensibility to pain. Quain.
angioscope: An instrument for examining the capillary vessels of animalsand plants. Morin.
almshouse: A house appropriated for the use of the poor; a poorhouse.
abature: Grass and sprigs beaten or trampled down by a stag passingthrough them. Crabb.
arson: The malicious burning of a dwelling house or outhouse ofanother man, which by the common law is felony; the malicious andvoluntary firing of a building or ship. Wharton.
angola pea: A tropical plant (Cajanus indicus) and its edible seed, a kindof pulse; -- so called from Angola in Western Africa. Called alsopigeon pea and Congo pea.
aid: To support, either by furnishing strength or means incoöperation to effect a purpose, or to prevent or to remove evil; tohelp; to assist.You speedy helpers . . . Appear and aid me in this enterprise. Shak.
alphabetism: The expression of spoken sounds by an alphabet. Encyc. Brit.
argas: A genus of venomous ticks which attack men and animals. Thefamous Persian Argas, also called Miana bug, is A. Persicus; that ofCentral America, called talaje by the natives, is A. Talaje.
axle guard: The part of the framing of a railway car or truck, by which anaxle box is held laterally, and in which it may move vertically; --also called a jaw in the United States, and a housing in England.
arteritis: Inflammation of an artery or arteries. Dunglison.
atonable: Admitting an atonement; capable of being atoned for; expiable.
acceleration: The act of accelerating, or the state of being accelerated;increase of motion or action; as, a falling body moves toward theearth with an acceleration of velocity; -- opposed to retardation.A period of social improvement, or of intellectual advancement,contains within itself a principle of acceleration. I. Taylor.(Astr. & Physics.) Acceleration of the moon, the increase of themoon's mean motion in its orbit, in consequence of which its periodof revolution is now shorter than in ancient times.-- Acceleration and retardation of the tides. See Priming of thetides, under Priming.-- Diurnal acceleration of the fixed stars, the amount by whichtheir apparent diurnal motion exceeds that of the sun, in consequenceof which they daily come to the meridian of any place about threeminutes fifty-six seconds of solar time earlier than on the daypreceding.-- Acceleration of the planets, the increasing velocity of theirmotion, in proceeding from the apogee to the perigee of their orbits.
asiarch: One of the chiefs or pontiffs of the Roman province of Asia,who had the superintendence of the public games and religious rites.Milner.
anti-imperialism: Opposition to imperialism; -- applied specif., in the UnitedStates, after the Spanish-American war (1898), to the attitude orprinciples of those opposing territorial expansion; in England, ofthose, often called Little Englanders, opposing the extension of theempire and the closer relation of its parts, esp. in matters ofcommerce and imperial defense. -- An`ti-im*pe"ri*al*ist, n. -- An`ti-im*pe`ri*al*is"tic (#), a.
armchair: A chair with arms to support the elbows or forearms. Tennyson.
astromantic: Of or pertaining to divination by means of the stars;astrologic. [R.] Dr. H. More.
auxometer: An instrument for measuring the magnifying power of a lens orsystem of lenses.
apo: A prefix from a Greek preposition. It usually signifies from,away from, off, or asunder, separate; as, in apocope (a cutting off),apostate, apostle (one sent away), apocarpous.
avoid: To defeat or evade; to invalidate. Thus, in a replication, theplaintiff may deny the defendant's plea, or confess it, and avoid itby stating new matter. Blackstone.
averter: One who, or that which, averts.
antisepsis: Prevention of sepsis by excluding or destroying microorganisms.
after-glow: A glow of refulgence in the western sky after sunset.
aerugo: The rust of any metal, esp. of brass or copper; verdigris.
aspiring: That aspires; as, an Aspiring mind.-- As*pir"ing*ly, adv.-- As*pir"ing*ness, n.
antialbumid: A body formed from albumin by pancreatic and gastric digestion.It is convertible into antipeptone.
amphicome: A kind of figured stone, rugged and beset with eminences,anciently used in divination. [Obs.] Encyc. Brit.
artifact: A product of human workmanship; -- applied esp. to the simplerproducts of aboriginal art as distinguished from natural objects.
apomecometer: An instrument for measuring the height of objects. Knight.
adaptiveness: The quality of being adaptive; capacity to adapt.
alkaline: Of or pertaining to an alkali or to alkalies; having theproperties of an alkali. Alkaline earths, certain substances, aslime, baryta, strontia, and magnesia, possessing some of thequalities of alkalies.-- Alkaline metals, potassium, sodium, cæsium, lithium, rubidium.-- Alkaline reaction, a reaction indicating alkalinity, as by theaction on limits, turmeric, etc.
abradant: A material used for grinding, as emery, sand, powdered glass,etc.
aviette: A heavier-than-air flying machine in which the motive power isfurnished solely by the aviator.
accord: An agreement between parties in controversy, by whichsatisfaction for an injury is stipulated, and which, when executed,bars a suit. Blackstone. With one accord, with unanimity.They rushed with one accord into the theater. Acts xix. 29.
antistrophic: Of or pertaining to an antistrophe.
amvis: An explosive consisting of ammonium nitrate, a derivative ofnitrobenzene, chlorated napthalene, and wood meal.
adorableness: The quality of being adorable, or worthy of adoration. Johnson.
arefy: To dry, or make dry. Bacon.
alabastrine: Of, pertaining to, or like, alabaster; as alabastrine limbs.
acoumeter: An instrument for measuring the acuteness of the sense ofhearing. Itard.
archelogy: The science of, or a treatise on, first principles. Fleming.
aslake: To mitigate; to moderate; to appease; to abate; to diminish.[Archaic] Chaucer.
anxiousness: The quality of being anxious; great solicitude; anxiety.
antipyrotic: Good against burns or pyrosis.-- n.
amole: Any detergent plant, or the part of it used as a detergent, asthe roots of Agave Americana, Chlorogalum pomeridianum, etc. [Sp.Amer. & Mex.]
adulation: Servile flattery; praise in excess, or beyond what is merited.Think'st thou the fiery fever will go out With titles blown fromadulation Shak.
admonitor: Admonisher; monitor.Conscience is at most times a very faithful and prudent admonitor.Shenstone.
atabal: A kettledrum; a kind of tabor, used by the Moors. Croly.
anachronism: A misplacing or error in the order of time; an error inchronology by which events are misplaced in regard to each other,esp. one by which an event is placed too early; falsification ofchronological relation.
absorbability: The state or quality of being absorbable. Graham (Chemistry).
acclimatize: To inure or habituate to a climate different from that which isnatural; to adapt to the peculiarities of a foreign or strangeclimate; said of man, the inferior animals, or plants.
ambit: Circuit or compass.His great parts did not live within a small ambit. Milward.
antichronical: Deviating from the proper order of time.-- An`ti*chron"ic*al*ly, adv.
anastate: One of a series of substances formed, in secreting cells, byconstructive or anabolic processes, in the production of protoplasm;-- opposed to katastate. Foster.
anglicization: The act of anglicizing, or making English in character.
assailment: The act or power of assailing; attack; assault. [R.]His most frequent assailment was the headache. Johnson.
ardently: In an ardent manner; eagerly; with warmth; affectionately;passionately.
achatina: A genus of land snails, often large, common in the warm partsof America and Africa.
anchovy pear: A West Indian fruit like the mango in taste, sometimes pickled;also, the tree (Grias cauliflora) bearing this fruit.
ash-fire: A low fire used in chemical operations.
adjection: The act or mode of adding; also, the thing added. [R.] B.Jonson.
adjectival: Of or relating to the relating to the adjective; of the natureof an adjective; adjective. W. Taylor (1797)
azoleic: Pertaining to an acid produced by treating oleic with nitricacid. [R.]
ankerite: A mineral closely related to dolomite, but containing iron.
avicula: A genus of marine bivalves, having a pearly interior, allied tothe pearl oyster; -- so called from a supposed resemblance of thetypical species to a bird.
adopted: Taken by adoption; taken up as one's own; as, an adopted son,citizen, country, word.-- A*dopt"ed*ly, adv.
axstone: A variety of jade. It is used by some savages, particularly thenatives of the South Sea Islands, for making axes or hatchets.
aptotic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, aptotes; uninflected; as,aptotic languages.
amazonian: A variety of feldspar, having a verdigris-green color.
afflux: A flowing towards; that which flows to; as, an afflux of bloodto the head.
adnation: The adhesion or cohesion of different floral verticils or setsof organs.
ascendency: Governing or controlling influence; domination; power.An undisputed ascendency. Macaulay.Custom has an ascendency over the understanding. Watts.
accruer: The act of accruing; accretion; as, title by accruer.
antisepalous: Standing before a sepal, or calyx leaf.
astral: Pertaining to, coming from, or resembling, the stars; starry;starlike.Shines only with an astral luster. I. Taylor.Some astral forms I must invoke by prayer. Dryden.Astral lamp, an Argand lamp so constructed that no shadow is castupon the table by the flattened ring-shaped reservoir in which theoil is contained.-- Astral spirits, spirits formerly supposed to live in the heavenlybodies or the aërial regions, and represented in the Middle Ages asfallen angels, spirits of the dead, or spirits originating in fire.
andiron: A utensil for supporting wood when burning in a fireplace, onebeing placed on each side; a firedog; as, a pair of andirons.
angienchyma: Vascular tissue of plants, consisting of spiral vessels,dotted, barred, and pitted ducts, and laticiferous vessels.
atticize: To conform or make conformable to the language, customs, etc.,of Attica.
axiom: A self-evident and necessary truth, or a proposition whosetruth is so evident as first sight that no reasoning or demonstrationcan make it plainer; a proposition which it is necessary to take forgranted; as, "The whole is greater than a part;" "A thing can not, atthe same time, be and not be."
ah: An exclamation, expressive of surprise, pity, complaint,entreaty, contempt, threatening, delight, triumph, etc., according tothe manner of utterance.
anthrax vaccine: A fluid vaccine obtained by growing a bacterium (Bacteriumanthracis) in beef broth. It is used to immunize animals, esp.cattle.
attendant: Depending on, or owing duty or service to; as, the widowattendant to the heir. Cowell. Attendant keys (Mus.), the keys orscales most nearly related to, or having most in common with, theprincipal key; those, namely, of its fifth above, or dominant, itsfifth below (fourth above), or subdominant, and its relative minor ormajor.
antimask: A secondary mask, or grotesque interlude, between the parts ofa serious mask. [Written also anue.] Bacon.
androsphinx: A man sphinx; a sphinx having the head of a man and the body ofa lion.
assumer: One who assumes, arrogates, pretends, or supposes. W. D.Whitney.
afterbirth: The placenta and membranes with which the fetus is connected,and which come away after delivery.
abacinate: To blind by a red-hot metal plate held before the eyes. [R.]
attitudinarian: One who attitudinizes; a posture maker.
atlas: The first vertebra of the neck, articulating immediately withthe skull, thus sustaining the globe of the head, whence the name.
adhortatory: Containing counsel or warning; hortatory; advisory. [Obs.]Potter.
antipole: The opposite pole; anything diametrically opposed. Geo. Eliot.
abrade: To rub or wear off; to waste or wear away by friction; as, toabrade rocks. Lyell.
atrocha: A kind of chætopod larva in which no circles of cilia aredeveloped.
aftercast: A throw of dice after the game in ended; hence, anything donetoo late. Gower.
atrophied: Affected with atrophy, as a tissue or organ; arrested indevelopment at a very early stage; rudimentary.
aggrege: To make heavy; to aggravate. [Obs.] Chaucer.
asthma paper: Paper impregnated with saltpeter. The fumes from the burningpaper are often inhaled as an alleviative by asthmatics.
antisocialist: One opposed to the doctrines and practices of socialists orsocialism.
affiliate: To connect or associate one's self; -- followed by with; as,they affiliate with no party.
abstruseness: The quality of being abstruse; difficulty of apprehension.Boyle.
alternat: A usage, among diplomats, of rotation in precedence amongrepresentatives of equal rank, sometimes determined by lot and atother times in regular order. The practice obtains in the signing oftreaties and conventions between nations.
american plan: In hotels, aplan upon which guests pay for both room and boardby the day, week, or other convenient period; -- contrasted withEuropean plan.
atrophy: A wasting away from want of nourishment; diminution in bulk orslow emaciation of the body or of any part. Milton.
anemogram: A record made by an anemograph.
assume: To undertake, as by a promise. Burrill.
affray: The fighting of two or more persons, in a public place, to theterror of others. Blackstone.
alkalescent: Tending to the properties of an alkali; slightly alkaline.
apteria: Naked spaces between the feathered areas of birds. SeePteryliæ.
attitude: The posture, action, or disposition of a figure or a statue.
abditory: A place for hiding or preserving articles of value. Cowell.
addressee: One to whom anything is addressed.
alexiteric: A preservative against contagious and infectious diseases, andthe effects of poison in general. Brande & C.
atomism: The doctrine of atoms. See Atomic philosophy, under Atomic.
applicant: One who apples for something; one who makes request; apetitioner.The applicant for a cup of water. Plumtre.The court require the applicant to appear in person. Z. Swift.
acrostic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, acrostics.
auf: A changeling or elf child, -- that is, one left by fairies; adeformed or foolish child; a simpleton; an oaf. [Obs.] Drayton.
amphigoric: Nonsensical; absurd; pertaining to an amphigory.
astrophysical: Pertaining to the physics of astronomical science.
address: To consign or intrust to the care of another, as agent orfactor; as, the ship was addressed to a merchant in Baltimore. Toaddress one's self to. (a) To prepare one's self for; to apply one'sself to. (b) To direct one's speech or discourse to.
avulse: To pluck or pull off. Shenstone.
appease: To make quiet; to calm; to reduce to a state of peace; tostill; to pacify; to dispel (anger or hatred); as, to appease thetumult of the ocean, or of the passions; to appease hunger or thirst.
anabranch: A branch of a river that reënters, or anastomoses with, themain stream; also, less properly, a branch which loses itself insandy soil. [Australia]
ampliative: Enlarging a conception by adding to that which is already knownor received."All bodies possess power of attraction" is an ampliative judgment;because we can think of bodies without thinking of attraction as oneof their immediate primary attribute. Abp. W. Thomson.
aorta: The great artery which carries the blood from the heart to allparts of the body except the lungs; the main trunk of the arterialsystem.
americanize: To render American; to assimilate to the Americans in customs,ideas, etc.; to stamp with American characteristics.
amylolysis: The conversion of starch into soluble products, as dextrins andsugar, esp. by the action of enzymes. -- Am`y*lo*lyt"ic (#), a.
acerate: A combination of aceric acid with a salifiable base.
avicular: Of or pertaining to a bird or to birds.
affrightment: Affright; the state of being frightened; sudden fear or alarm.[Archaic]Passionate words or blows . . . fill the child's mind with terror andaffrightment. Locke.
anthropomorphosis: Transformation into the form of a human being.
albescent: Becoming white or whitish; moderately white.
administrable: Capable of being administered; as, an administrable law.
abolitionize: To imbue with the principles of abolitionism. [R.] Bartlett.
adlegation: A right formerly claimed by the states of the German Empire ofjoining their own ministers with those of the emperor in publictreaties and negotiations to the common interest of the empire.Encyc. Brit.
accusable: Liable to be accused or censured; chargeable with a crime orfault; blamable; -- with of.
asystole: A weakening or cessation of the contractile power of the heart.
aesir: In the old Norse mythology, the gods Odin, Thor, Loki, Balder,Frigg, and the others. Their home was called Asgard.
apophyge: The small hollow curvature given to the top or bottom of theshaft of a column where it expands to meet the edge of the fillet; --called also the scape. Parker.
ax: To ask; to inquire or inquire of.
anastomosis: The inosculation of vessels, or intercommunication between twoor more vessels or nerves, as the cross communication betweenarteries or veins.
acetarious: Used in salads; as, acetarious plants.
arduousness: The quality of being arduous; difficulty of execution.
annunciative: Pertaining to annunciation; announcing. [R.] Dr. H. More.
asynchronous: Not simultaneous; not concurrent in time; --opposed tosynchronous.
anatifa: An animal of the barnacle tribe, of the genus Lepas, having afleshy stem or peduncle; a goose barnacle. See Cirripedia.
air hole: A fault in a casting, produced by a bubble of air; a blowhole.
austerely: Severely; rigidly; sternly.A doctrine austerely logical. Macaulay.
alicant: A kind of wine, formerly much esteemed; -- said to have beenmade near Alicant, in Spain. J. Fletcher.
alum stone: A subsulphate of alumina and potash; alunite.
agonothetic: Pertaining to the office of an agonothete.
amateur: A person attached to a particular pursuit, study, or science asto music or painting; esp. one who cultivates any study or art, fromtaste or attachment, without pursuing it professionally.
affectingly: In an affecting manner; is a manner to excite emotions.
aliturgical: Applied to those days when the holy sacrifice is not offered.Shipley.
androus: A terminal combining form: Having a stamen or stamens;staminate; as, monandrous, with one stamen; polyandrous, with manystamens.
anglicity: The state or quality of being English.
arrestation: Arrest. [R.]The arrestation of the English resident in France was decreed by theNational Convention. H. M. Williams.
adynamic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, debility of the vitalpowers; weak.
apparent: An heir apparent. [Obs.]I'll draw it [the sword] as apparent to the crown. Shak.
ankylostomiasis: A disease due to the presence of the parasites Agchylostomaduodenale, Uncinaria (subgenus Necator) americana, or alliednematodes, in the small intestine. When present in large numbers theyproduce a severe anæmia by sucking the blood from the intestinalwalls.  Called also miner's anæmia, tunnel disease, brickmaker'sanæmia, Egyptian chlorosis.
aplomb: Assurance of manner or of action; self-possession.
antrum: A cavern or cavity, esp. an anatomical cavity or sinus. Huxley.
agazed: Gazing with astonishment; amazed. [Obs.]The whole army stood agazed on him. Shak.
adscititious: Supplemental; additional; adventitious; ascititious."Adscititious evidence." Bowring.-- Ad`sci*ti"tious*ly, adv.
alienor: One who alienates or transfers property to another. Blackstone.
astert: To start up; to befall; to escape; to shun. [Obs.] Spenser.
atlas powder: A blasting powder or dynamite composed of nitroglycerin, woodfiber, sodium nitrate, and magnesium carbonate.
alkali flat: A sterile plain, containing an excess of alkali, at the bottomof an undrained basin in an arid region; a playa.
amidships: In the middle of a ship, with regard to her length, andsometimes also her breadth. Totten.
aquarellist: A painter in thin transparent water colors.
adulteress: A woman who violates her religious engagements. James iv. 4.
asphyxial: Of or relating to asphyxia; as, asphyxial phenomena.
anisomeric: Not isomeric; not made of the same components in the sameproportions.
ape: A quadrumanous mammal, esp. of the family Simiadæ, having teethof the same number and form as in man, having teeth of the samenumber and form as in man, and possessing neither a tail nor cheekpouches. The name is applied esp. to species of the genus Hylobates,and is sometimes used as a general term for all Quadrumana. Thehigher forms, the gorilla, chimpanzee, and ourang, are often calledanthropoid apes or man apes.
anniversary: Returning with the year, at a stated time; annual; yearly; as,an anniversary feast. Anniversary day (R. C. Ch.). See Anniversary,n., 2.-- Anniversary week, that week in the year in which the annualmeetings of religious and benevolent societies are held in Boston andNew York. [Eastern U. S.]
aramaic: Pertaining to Aram, or to the territory, inhabitants, language,or literature of Syria and Mesopotamia; Aramæan; -- specificallyapplied to the northern branch of the Semitic family of languages,including Syriac and Chaldee.-- n.
adagial: Pertaining to an adage; proverbial. "Adagial verse." Barrow.
aloofness: State of being aloof. Rogers (1642).The . . . aloofness of his dim forest life. Thoreau.
apyrexial: Relating to apyrexy. "Apyrexial period." Brande & C.
atop: On or at the top. Milton.
anatine: Of or pertaining to the ducks; ducklike.
antisplenetic: Good as a remedy against disease of the spleen.-- n.
antediluvian: Of or relating to the period before the Deluge in Noah's time;hence, antiquated; as, an antediluvian vehicle.-- n.
angulosity: A state of being angulous or angular. [Obs.]
alfet: A caldron of boiling water into which an accused person plungedhis forearm as a test of innocence or guilt.
allumette: A match for lighting candles, lamps, etc.
animalism: The state, activity, or enjoyment of animals; mere animal lifewithout intellectual or moral qualities; sensuality.
andropogon: A very large and important genus of grasses, found in nearlyall parts of the world. It includes the lemon grass of Ceylon and thebeard grass, or broom sedge, of the United States. The principalsubgenus is Sorghum, including  A. sorghum and A. halepensis, fromwhich have been derived the Chinese sugar cane, the Johnson grass,the Aleppo grass, the broom corn, and the durra, or Indian millet.Several East Indian species, as A. nardus and A. schonanthus, yieldfragrant oils, used in perfumery.
apple pie: A pie made of apples (usually sliced or stewed) with spice andsugar. Apple-pie bed, a bed in which, as a joke, the sheets are sodoubled (like the cover of an apple turnover) as to prevent any onefrom getting at his length between them. Halliwell, Conybeare.-- Apple-pie order, perfect order or arrangement. [Colloq.]Halliwell.
although: Grant all this; be it that; supposing that; notwithstanding;though.Although all shall be offended, yet will no I. Mark xiv. 29.
aseptic: Not liable to putrefaction; nonputrescent.-- n.
alb sunday: The first Sunday after Easter Sunday, properly Albless Sunday,because in the early church those who had been baptized on Easter evelaid aside on the following Saturday their white albs which had beenput on after baptism.
al-: All; wholly; completely; as, almighty,almost. (b) Etym: [L.ad.]
affirmative: Expressing the agreement of the two terms of a proposition.
alanine: A white crystalline base, C3H7NO2, derived from aldehydeammonia.
accommodator: He who, or that which, accommodates. Warburton.
augmentative: Having the quality or power of augmenting; expressingaugmentation.-- Aug*ment"a*tive*ly, adv.
amenorrhoea: Retention or suppression of the menstrual discharge.
assuetude: Accustomedness; habit; habitual use.Assuetude of things hurtful doth make them lose their force to hurt.Bacon.
agalmatolite: A soft, compact stone, of a grayish, greenish, or yellowishcolor, carved into images by the Chinese, and hence called figurestone, and pagodite. It is probably a variety of pinite.
asteridian: Of or pertaining to the Asterioidea.-- n.
abluvion: That which is washed off. [R.] Dwight.
adeption: An obtaining; attainment. [Obs.]In the wit and policy of the capitain consisteth the chief adeptionof the victory. Grafton.
astigmatic: Affected with, or pertaining to, astigmatism; as, astigmaticeyes; also, remedying astigmatism; as, astigmatic lenses.
alfione: An edible marine fish of California (Rhacochilus toxotes).
affectionately: With affection; lovingly; fondly; tenderly; kindly.
aurigraphy: The art of writing with or in gold.
adiaphorous: Incapable of doing either harm or good, as some medicines.Dunglison.
apostleship: The office or dignity of an apostle.
ammonia: A gaseous compound of hydrogen and nitrogen, NH3, with apungent smell and taste: -- often called volatile alkali, and spiritsof hartshorn.
applicancy: The quality or state of being applicable. [R.]
anaplasty: The art of operation of restoring lost parts or the normalshape by the use of healthy tissue.
abnodation: The act of cutting away the knots of trees. [R.] Crabb.
aurichalcite: A hydrous carbonate of copper and zinc, found in pale green orblue crystalline aggregations. It yields a kind of brass onreduction.
agnoiology: The doctrine concerning those things of which we arenecessarily ignorant.
anomalous: Deviating from a general rule, method, or analogy; abnormal;irregular; as, an anomalous proceeding.
alternity: Succession by turns; alternation. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
apprehensively: In an apprehensive manner; with apprehension of danger.
afferent: Bearing or conducting inwards to a part or organ; -- opposed toefferent; as, afferent vessels; afferent nerves, which conveysensations from the external organs to the brain.
agrestic: Pertaining to fields or the country, in opposition to the city;rural; rustic; unpolished; uncouth. "Agrestic behavior." Gregory.
antipathous: Having a natural contrariety; adverse; antipathetic. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.
arduously: In an arduous manner; with difficulty or laboriousness.
amphibiology: A treatise on amphibious animals; the department of naturalhistory which treats of the Amphibia.
armistice: A cessation of arms for a short time, by convention; atemporary suspension of hostilities by agreement; a truce.
amenability: The quality of being amenable; amenableness. Coleridge.
antitrochanter: An articular surface on the ilium of birds against which thegreat trochanter of the femur plays.
auriform: Having the form of the human ear; ear-shaped.
atlanta: A genus of small glassy heteropod mollusks found swimming atthe surface in mid ocean. See Heteropod.
accusatory: Pertaining to, or containing, an accusation; as, an accusatorylibel. Grote.
attaminate: To corrupt; to defile; to contaminate. [Obs.] Blount.
astragal: A convex molding of rounded surface, generally from half tothree quarters of a circle.
anopla: One of the two orders of Nemerteans. See Nemertina.
affection: Disease; morbid symptom; malady; as, a pulmonary affection.Dunglison.
agamogenesis: Reproduction without the union of parents of distinct sexes:asexual reproduction.
astonishedly: In an astonished manner. [R.] Bp. Hall.
androtomous: Having the filaments of the stamens divided into two parts.
algaroba: A term used for the Powder of Algaroth, a white powder which isa compound of trichloride and trioxide of antimony. It was formerlyused in medicine as an emetic, purgative, and diaphoretic.
acetifier: An apparatus for hastening acetification. Knight.
alternatively: In the manner of alternatives, or that admits the choice of oneout of two things.
allopathist: One who practices allopathy; one who professes allopathy.
accommodating: Affording, or disposed to afford, accommodation; obliging; asan accommodating man, spirit, arrangement.
aliene: To alien or alienate; to transfer, as title or property; as, toaliene an estate.
associable: Liable to be affected by sympathy with other parts; -- said oforgans, nerves, muscles, etc.The stomach, the most associable of all the organs of the animalbody. Med. Rep.
amovability: Liability to be removed or dismissed from office. [R.] T.Jefferson.
alt: The higher part of the scale. See Alto. To be in alt, to be inan exalted state of mind.
argentous: Of, pertaining to, or containing, silver; -- said of certainsilver compounds in which silver has a higher proportion than inargentic compounds; as, argentous chloride.
albino: A person, whether negro, Indian, or white, in whom by somedefect of organization the substance which gives color to the skin,hair, and eyes is deficient or in a morbid state. An albino has askin of a milky hue, with hair of the same color, and eyes with deepred pupil and pink or blue iris. The term is also used of the loweranimals, as white mice, elephants, etc.; and of plants in a whitishcondition from the absence of chlorophyll. Amer. Cyc.
abeyant: Being in a state of abeyance.
almoner: One who distributes alms, esp. the doles and alms of religioushouses, almshouses, etc.; also, one who dispenses alms for another,as the almoner of a prince, bishop, etc.
africanize: To place under the domination of Africans or negroes. [Amer.]Bartlett.
affectuous: Full of passion or emotion; earnest. [Obs.] --Af*fec"tu*ous*ly, adv. [Obs.] Fabyan.
aeration: A change produced in the blood by exposure to the air inrespiration; oxygenation of the blood in respiration;arterialization.
about-sledge: The largest hammer used by smiths. Weale.
alopecist: A practitioner who tries to prevent or cure baldness.
autotypography: A process resembling "nature printing," by which drawingsexecuted on gelatin are impressed into a soft metal plate, from whichthe printing is done as from copperplate.
antibromic: An agent that destroys offensive smells; a deodorizer.
africander: One born in Africa, the offspring of a white father and a"colored" mother. Also, and now commonly in Southern Africa, a nativeborn of European settlers.
auroral: Belonging to, or resembling, the aurora (the dawn or thenorthern lights); rosy.Her cheeks suffused with an auroral blush. Longfellow.
animadverter: One who animadverts; a censurer; also [Obs.], a chastiser.
adelocodonic: Applied to sexual zooids of hydroids, that have a saclike formand do not become free; -- opposed to phanerocodonic.
aurist: One skilled in treating and curing disorders of the ear.
adorer: One who adores; a worshiper; one who admires or loves greatly;an ardent admirer. "An adorer of truth." Clarendon.I profess myself her adorer, not her friend. Shak.
ambidextral: Pertaining equally to the right-hand side and the left-handside. Earle.
adumbration: The shadow or outlines of a figure.
appetible: Desirable; capable or worthy of being the object of desire.Bramhall.
alethoscope: An instrument for viewing pictures by means of a lens, so as topresent them in their natural proportions and relations.
aflow: Flowing.Their founts aflow with tears. R. Browning.
apricot: A fruit allied to the plum, of an orange color, oval shape, anddelicious taste; also, the tree (Prunus Armeniaca of Linnæus) whichbears this fruit. By cultivation it has been introduced throughoutthe temperate zone.
adrogation: A kind of adoption in ancient Rome. See Arrogation.
actinaria: A large division of Anthozoa, including those which have simpletentacles and do not form stony corals. Sometimes, in a wider sense,applied to all the Anthozoa, expert the Alcyonaria, whether formingcorals or not.
agrarian: Wild; -- said of plants growing in the fields.
attack: To make an onset or attack.
anglemeter: An instrument to measure angles, esp. one used by geologists tomeasure the dip of strata.
anorthoscope: An optical toy for producing amusing figures or pictures bymeans of two revolving disks, on one of which distorted figures arepainted.
antenumber: A number that precedes another. [R.] Bacon.
arytenoid: Ladle-shaped; -- applied to two small cartilages of the larynx,and also to the glands, muscles, etc., connected with them. Thecartilages are attached to the cricoid cartilage and connected withthe vocal cords.
amomum: A genus of aromatic plants. It includes species which bearcardamoms, and grains of paradise.
apiology: The scientific or systematic study of honey bees.
appellatively: After the manner of nouns appellative; in a manner to expresswhole classes or species; as, Hercules is sometimes usedappellatively, that is, as a common name, to signify a strong man.
aweigh: Just drawn out of the ground, and hanging perpendicularly;atrip; -- said of the anchor. Totten.
alum: A double sulphate formed of aluminium and some other element(esp. an alkali metal) or of aluminium. It has twenty-four moleculesof water of crystallization.
acacia: A roll or bag, filled with dust, borne by Byzantine emperors,as a memento of mortality. It is represented on medals.
assumptive: Assumed, or capable of being assumed; characterized byassumption; making unwarranted claims.-- As*sump"tive*ly, adv. Assumptive arms (Her.), originally, armswhich a person had a right to assume, in consequence of an exploit;now, those assumed without sanction of the Heralds' College. PercySmith.
arrogantly: In an arrogant manner; with undue pride or self-importance.
asterophyllite: A fossil plant from the coal formations of Europe and America,now regarded as the branchlets and foliage of calamites.
apprentice: A barrister, considered a learner of law till of sixteen years'standing, when he might be called to the rank of serjeant. [Obs.]Blackstone.
aero-: The combining form of the Greek word meaning air.
acetimeter: An instrument for estimating the amount of acetic acid invinegar or in any liquid containing acetic acid.
assault: An apparently violent attempt, or willful offer with force orviolence, to do hurt to another; an attempt or offer to beat another,accompanied by a degree of violence, but without touching his person,as by lifting the fist, or a cane, in a threatening manner, or bystriking at him, and missing him. If the blow aimed takes effect, itis a battery. Blackstone. Wharton.Practically, however, the word assault is used to include thebattery. Mozley & W.
angelhood: The state of being an angel; angelic nature. Mrs. Browning.
affiancer: One who makes a contract of marriage between two persons.
alidade: The portion of a graduated instrument, as a quadrant orastrolabe, carrying the sights or telescope, and showing the degreescut off on the arc of the instrument Whewell.
alkanet: A dyeing matter extracted from the roots of Alkanna tinctoria,which gives a fine deep red color.
astringer: A falconer who keeps a goschawk. [Obs.] Shak. Cowell. [Writtenalso austringer.]
amphibolous: Capable of two meanings.An amphibolous sentence is one that is capable of two meanings, notfrom the double sense of any of the words, but from its admitting ofa double construction; e. g., "The duke yet lives that Henry shalldepose." Whately.
arriere-ban: A proclamation, as of the French kings, calling not only theirimmediate feudatories, but the vassals of these feudatories, to takethe field for war; also, the body of vassals called or liable to becalled to arms, as in ancient France.
annual: A Mass for a deceased person or for some special object, saiddaily for a year or on the anniversary day.
activeness: The quality of being active; nimbleness; quickness of motion;activity.
apple-faced: Having a round, broad face, like an apple. "Apple-facedchildren." Dickens.
aerology: That department of physics which treats of the atmosphere.
apprise: To give notice, verbal or written; to inform; -- followed byof; as, we will apprise the general of an intended attack; heapprised the commander of what he had done.
alternating current: A current which periodically changes or reverses its directionof flow.
astonied: Stunned; astonished. See Astony. [Archaic]And I astonied fell and could not pray. Mrs. Browning.
aerobus: An aëroplane or airship designed to carry passengers.
acnode: An isolated point not upon a curve, but whose coördinatessatisfy the equation of the curve so that it is considered asbelonging to the curve.
azure: Sky-blue; resembling the clear blue color of the unclouded sky;cerulean; also, cloudless. Azure stone (Min.), the lapis lazuli;also, the lazulite.
avocado: The pulpy fruit of Persea gratissima, a tree of tropicalAmerica. It is about the size and shape of a large pear; -- calledalso avocado pear, alligator pear, midshipman's butter.
aposematic: Having or designating conspicuous or warning colors orstructures indicative of special means of defense against enemies, asin the skunk.
admittatur: The certificate of admission given in some American colleges.
albification: The act or process of making white. [Obs.]
aune: A French cloth measure, of different parts of the country (atParis, 0.95 of an English ell); -- now superseded by the meter.
anxiety: A state of restlessness and agitation, often with generalindisposition and a distressing sense of oppression at theepigastrium. Dunglison.
antisolar: Opposite to the sun; -- said of the point in the heavens 180distant from the sun.
arbitration: The hearing and determination of a cause between parties incontroversy, by a person or persons chosen by the parties.
abhor: To protest against; to reject solemnly. [Obs.]I utterly abhor, yea, from my soul Refuse you for my judge. Shak.
anthropography: That branch of anthropology which treats of the actualdistribution of the human race in its different divisions, asdistinguished by physical character, language, institutions, andcustoms, in contradistinction to ethnography, which treatshistorically of the origin and filiation of races and nations. P.Cyc.
acaroid: Shaped like or resembling a mite.
acciaccatura: A short grace note, one semitone below the note to which it isprefixed; -- used especially in organ music. Now used as equivalentto the short appoggiatura.
archetype: The standard weight or coin by which others are adjusted.
arango: A bead of rough carnelian. Arangoes were formerly imported fromBombay for use in the African slave trade. McCulloch.
antimoniureted: Combined with or containing antimony; as, antimoniuretedhydrogen. [Written also antimoniuretted.]
attic: Of or pertaining to Attica, in Greece, or to Athens, itsprincipal city; marked by such qualities as were characteristic ofthe Athenians; classical; refined. Attic base (Arch.), a peculiarform of molded base for a column or pilaster, described by Vitruvius,applied under the Roman Empire to the Ionic and Corinthian and "RomanDoric" orders, and imitated by the architects of the Renaissance.-- Attic faith, inviolable faith.-- Attic purity, special purity of language.-- Attic salt, Attic wit, a poignant, delicate wit, peculiar to theAthenians.-- Attic story. See Attic, n.-- Attic style, a style pure and elegant.
afternoon: The part of the day which follows noon, between noon andevening.
assignee: In England, the persons appointed, under a commission ofbankruptcy, to manage the estate of a bankrupt for the benefit of hiscreditors.
akinesia: Paralysis of the motor nerves; loss of movement. Foster.
adventuresome: Full of risk; adventurous; venturesome.-- Ad*ven"ture*some*ness, n.
antanagoge: A figure which consists in answering the charge of anadversary, by a counter charge.
abraid: To awake; to arouse; to stir or start up; also, to shout out.[Obs.] Chaucer.
affrontiveness: The quality that gives an affront or offense. [R.] Bailey.
assuefaction: The act of accustoming, or the state of being accustomed;habituation. [Obs.]Custom and studies efform the soul like wax, and by assuefactionintroduce a nature. Jer. Taylor.
assay pound: A small standard weight used in assaying bullion, etc.,sometimes equaling 0.5 gram, but varying with the assayer.
ascospore: One of the spores contained in the asci of lichens and fungi.[See Illust. of Ascus.]
abnet: The girdle of a Jewish priest or officer.
autophagi: Birds which are able to run about and obtain their own food assoon as hatched.
aftersensation: A sensation or sense impression following the removal of astimulus producing a primary sensation, and reproducing the primarysensation in positive, negative, or complementary form. Theaftersensation may be continuous with the primary sensation or followit after an interval.
avenaceous: Belonging to, or resembling, oats or the oat grasses.
amolition: Removal; a putting away. [Obs.] Bp. Ward (1673).
amblypoda: A group of large, extinct, herbivorous mammals, common in theTertiary formation of the United States.
angriness: The quality of being angry, or of being inclined to anger.Such an angriness of humor that we take fire at everything. WholeDuty of Man.
acropetal: Developing from below towards the apex, or from thecircumference towards the center; centripetal; -- said of certaininflorescence.
amblygon: An obtuse-angled figure, esp. and obtuse-angled triangle.[Obs.]
antlia: The spiral tubular proboscis of lepidopterous insects. SeeLepidoptera.
augmenter: One who, or that which, augments or increases anything.
accidentality: The quality of being accidental; accidentalness. [R.]Coleridge.
alloxan: An oxidation product of uric acid. It is of a pale reddishcolor, readily soluble in water or alcohol.
apposer: An examiner; one whose business is to put questions. Formerly,in the English Court of Exchequer, an officer who audited thesheriffs' accounts.
antimason: One opposed to Freemasonry.-- An`ti*ma*son"ic, a.
amortize: To alienate in mortmain, that is, to convey to a corporation.See Mortmain.
anthropomorphist: One who attributes the human form or other human attributes tothe Deity or to anything not human.
alimentary: Pertaining to aliment or food, or to the function of nutrition;nutritious; alimental; as, alimentary substances. Alimentary canal,the entire channel, extending from the mouth to the anus, by whichaliments are conveyed through the body, and the useless partsejected.
adjunctly: By way of addition or adjunct; in connection with.
axile: Situated in the axis of anything; as an embryo which lies inthe axis of a seed. Gray.
alepole: A pole set up as the sign of an alehouse. [Obs.]
agami: A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to thecranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breastedtrumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.
abuser: One who abuses [in the various senses of the verb].
asarabacca: An acrid herbaceous plant (Asarum Europæum), the leaves androots of which are emetic and cathartic. It is principally used incephalic snuffs.
adviso: Advice; counsel; suggestion; also, a dispatch or advice boat.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
abased: Borne lower than usual, as a fess; also, having the ends of thewings turned downward towards the point of the shield.
appropriative: Appropriating; making, or tending to, appropriation; as, anappropriative act.-- Ap*pro"pri*a*tive*ness, n.
amphoteric: Partly one and partly the other; neither acid nor alkaline;neutral. [R.] Smart.
attainableness: The quality of being attainable; attainability.
abater: One who, or that which, abates.
adversary: One who is turned against another or others with a design tooppose
aeolotropy: Difference of quality or property in different directions.
advocation: The process of removing a cause from an inferior court to thesupreme court. Bell.
aerobic: Growing or thriving only in the presence of oxygen; also,pertaining to, or induced by, aërobies; as, aërobic fermentation. --A`ër*o"bic*al*ly (#), adv.
aventurine: A variety of translucent quartz, spangled throughout withscales of yellow mica. ~= feldspar, a variety of oligoclase withinternal firelike reflections due to the presence of minute crystals,probably of hematite; sunstone.
arquebusier: A soldier armed with an arquebus.Soldiers armed with guns, of whatsoever sort or denomination, appearto have been called arquebusiers. E. Lodge.
aphaniptera: A group of wingless insects, of which the flea in the type. SeeFlea.
archaeography: A description of, or a treatise on, antiquity or antiquities.
annihilationist: One who believes that eternal punishment consists inannihilation or extinction of being; a destructionist.
apriority: The quality of being innate in the mind, or prior toexperience; a priori reasoning.
araneidan: Of or pertaining to the Araneina or spiders.-- n.
adobe: An unburnt brick dried in the sun; also used as an adjective,as, an adobe house, in Texas or New Mexico.
arithmetical: Of or pertaining to arithmetic; according to the rules ormethod of arithmetic. Arithmetical complement of a logarithm. SeeLogarithm.-- Arithmetical mean. See Mean.-- Arithmetical progression. See Progression.-- Arithmetical proportion. See Proportion.
audaciousness: The quality of being audacious; impudence; audacity.
avatar: The descent of a deity to earth, and his incarnation as a manor an animal; -- chiefly associated with the incarnations of Vishnu.
aphoristically: In the form or manner of aphorisms; pithily.
antimagistrical: Opposed to the office or authority of magistrates. [Obs.]South.
artesian: Of or pertaining to Artois (anciently called Artesium), inFrance. Artesian wells, wells made by boring into the earth till theinstrument reaches water, which, from internal pressure, flowsspontaneously like a fountain. They are usually of small diameter andoften of great depth.
araguato: A South American monkey, the ursine howler (Mycetes ursinus).See Howler, n., 2.
aldermanic: Relating to, becoming to, or like, an alderman; characteristicof an alderman.
antelucan: Held or being before light; -- a word applied to assemblies ofChristians, in ancient times of persecution, held before light in themorning. "Antelucan worship." De Quincey.
argonaut: A cephalopod of the genus Argonauta.
assign: To transfer, or make over to another, esp. to transfer to, andvest in, certain persons, called assignees, for the benefit ofcreditors. To assign dower, to set out by metes and bounds thewidow's share or portion in an estate. Kent.
applicative: Having of being applied or used; applying; applicatory;practical. Bramhall.-- Ap"pli*ca*tive*ly, adv.
ambush: To lie in wait, for the purpose of attacking by surprise; tolurk.Nor saw the snake that ambushed for his prey. Trumbull.
affeer: To assess or reduce, as an arbitrary penalty or amercement, toa certain and reasonable sum.Amercements . . . were affeered by the judges. Blackstone.
arabinose: A sugar of the composition C5H10O5, obtained from cherry gum byboiling it with dilute sulphuric acid.
auctary: That which is superadded; augmentation. [Obs.] Baxter.
align: To adjust or form to a line; to range or form in line; to bringinto line; to aline.
arbor dianae: A precipitation of silver, in a beautiful arborescent form.
amplexation: An embrace. [Obs.]An humble amplexation of those sacred feet. Bp. Hall.
alloyage: The act or art of alloying metals; also, the combination oralloy.
amylometer: Instrument for determining the amount of starch in a substance.
alder: A tree, usually growing in moist land, and belonging to thegenus Alnus. The wood is used by turners, etc.; the bark by dyers andtanners. In the U. S. the species of alder are usually shrubs orsmall trees. Black alder. (a) A European shrub (Rhamnus frangula);Alder buckthorn. (b) An American species of holly (Ilexverticillata), bearing red berries.
accessary: Accompanying, as a subordinate; additional; accessory; esp.,uniting in, or contributing to, a crime, but not as chief actor. SeeAccessory.To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary. Shak.Amongst many secondary and accessary causes that support monarchy,these are not of least reckoning. Milton.
alyssum: A genus of cruciferous plants; madwort. The sweet alyssum (A.maritimum), cultivated for bouquets, bears small, white, sweet-scented flowers.
aluminate: A compound formed from the hydrate of aluminium by thesubstitution of a metal for the hydrogen.
aerolite: A stone, or metallic mass, which has fallen to the earth fromdistant space; a meteorite; a meteoric stone.
anadrom: A fish that leaves the sea and ascends rivers.
appendiculate: Having small appendages; forming an appendage. Appendiculateleaf, a small appended leaf. Withering.
archetypally: With reference to the archetype; originally. "Partsarchetypally distinct." Dana.
agrarianize: To distribute according to, or to imbue with, the principles ofagrarianism.
asset: Any article or separable part of one's assets.
agriculture: The art or science of cultivating the ground, including theharvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of live stock;tillage; husbandry; farming.
achromatin: Tissue which is not stained by fluid dyes. W. Flemming.
affiant: One who makes an affidavit. [U. S.] Burrill.
adverbial: Of or pertaining to an adverb; of the nature of an adverb; as,an adverbial phrase or form.
ailment: Indisposition; morbid affection of the body; -- not appliedordinarily to acute diseases. "Little ailments." Landsdowne.
atom: The smallest particle of matter that can enter intocombination; one of the elementary constituents of a molecule.
alizarin: A coloring principle, C14H6O2(OH)2, found in madder, and nowproduced artificially from anthracene. It produces the Turkish reds.
augural: Of or pertaining to augurs or to augury; betokening; ominous;significant; as, an augural staff; augural books. "Portents augural."Cowper.
aphetism: An aphetized form of a word. New Eng. Dict.
ambulate: To walk; to move about. [R.] Southey.
arm-gret: Great as a man's arm. [Obs.]A wreath of gold, arm-gret. Chaucer.
acalephae: A group of Coelenterata, including the Medusæ or jellyfishes,and hydroids; -- so called from the stinging power they possess.Sometimes called sea nettles.
agouara: The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus), found in thetropical parts of America.
amnigenous: Born or bred in, of, or near a river. [Obs.] Bailey.
arbitrariness: The quality of being arbitrary; despoticalness; tyranny. Bp.Hall.
abstainer: One who abstains; esp., one who abstains from the use ofintoxicating liquors.
artificiality: The quality or appearance of being artificial; that which isartificial.
acouchy: A small species of agouti (Dasyprocta acouchy).
arbustive: Containing copses of trees or shrubs; covered with shrubs.Bartram.
abysmal: Pertaining to, or resembling, an abyss; bottomless; unending;profound.Geology gives one the same abysmal extent of time that astronomy doesof space. Carlyle.
acock: In a cocked or turned up fashion.
altitudinal: Of or pertaining to height; as, altitudinal measurements.
antiquist: An antiquary; a collector of antiques. [R.] Pinkerton.
ability: The quality or state of being able; power to perform, whetherphysical, moral, intellectual, conventional, or legal; capacity;skill or competence in doing; sufficiency of strength, skill,resources, etc.; -- in the plural, faculty, talent.Then the disciples, every man according to his ability, determined tosend relief unto the brethren. Acts xi. 29.Natural abilities are like natural plants, that need pruning bystudy. Bacon.The public men of England, with much of a peculiar kind of ability.Macaulay.
aloneness: A state of being alone, or without company; solitariness. [R.]Bp. Montagu.
aberration: A small periodical change of position in the stars and otherheavenly bodies, due to the combined effect of the motion of lightand the motion of the observer; called annual aberration, when theobserver's motion is that of the earth in its orbit, and dairy ordiurnal aberration, when of the earth on its axis; amounting whengreatest, in the former case, to 20.4'', and in the latter, to 0.3''.Planetary aberration is that due to the motion of light and themotion of the planet relative to the earth.
allantoidea: The division of Vertebrata in which the embryo develops anallantois. It includes reptiles, birds, and mammals.
alexipyretic: Serving to drive off fever; antifebrile.-- n.
anthophagous: Eating flowers; -- said of certain insects.
apology: To offer an apology. [Obs.]For which he can not well apology. J. Webster.
auriculars: A circle of feathers surrounding the opening of the ear ofbirds.
accessorily: In the manner of an accessory; auxiliary.
anatreptic: Overthrowing; defeating; -- applied to Plato's refutativedialogues. Enfield.
affright: To impress with sudden fear; to frighten; to alarm.Dreams affright our souls. Shak.A drear and dying sound Affrights the flamens at their servicequaint. Milton.
aristate: Having a pointed, beardlike process, as the glumes of wheat;awned. Gray.
arterialization: The process of converting venous blood into arterial bloodduring its passage through the lungs, oxygen being absorbed andcarbonic acid evolved; -- called also aëration and hematosis.
anonymously: In an anonymous manner; without a name. Swift.
apronful: The quality an apron can hold.
amortization: The act or right of alienating lands to a corporation, whichwas considered formerly as transferring them to dead hands, or inmortmain.
anthelmintic: Good against intestinal worms.-- An anthelmintic remedy. [Written also anthelminthic.]
astragalar: Of or pertaining to the astragalus.
annoy: A feeling of discomfort or vexation caused by what onedislikes; also, whatever causes such a feeling; as, to work annoy.Worse than Tantalus' is her annoy. Shak.
alto: Formerly the part sung by the highest male, or counter-tenor,voices; now the part sung by the lowest female, or contralto, voices,between in tenor and soprano. In instrumental music it now signifiesthe tenor.
answerless: Having no answer, or impossible to be answered. Byron.
anabolic: Pertaining to anabolism; an anabolic changes, or processes,more or less constructive in their nature.
anisometric: Not isometric; having unsymmetrical parts; -- said of crystalswith three unequal axes. Dana.
air gap: An air-filled gap in a magnetic or electric circuit; specif.,in a dynamo or motor, the space between the field-magnet poles andthe armature; clearance.
anemosis: A condition in the wood of some trees in which the rings areseparated, as some suppose, by the action of high winds upon thetrunk; wind shake.
amaurosis: A loss or decay of sight, from loss of power in the opticnerve, without any perceptible external change in the eye; -- calledalso gutta serena, the "drop serene" of Milton.
adriatic: Of or pertaining to a sea so named, the northwestern part ofwhich is known as the Gulf of Venice.
anagrammatism: The act or practice of making anagrams. Camden.
addictedness: The quality or state of being addicted; attachment.
advent: The period including the four Sundays before Christmas. AdventSunday (Eccl.), the first Sunday in the season of Advent, beingalways the nearest Sunday to the feast of St. Andrew (Now. 30).Shipley.
actinophonic: Pertaining to, or causing the production of, sound by means ofthe actinic, or ultraviolet, rays; as, actinophonic phenomena.
awe: To strike with fear and reverence; to inspire with awe; tocontrol by inspiring dread.That same eye whose bend doth awe the world. Shak.His solemn and pathetic exhortation awed and melted the bystanders.Macaulay.
assoilment: Act of assoiling, or state of being assoiled; absolution;acquittal.
ascham: A sort of cupboard, or case, to contain bows and otherimplements of archery.
aright: Rightly; correctly; in a right way or form; without mistake orcrime; as, to worship God aright.
axiomatically: By the use of axioms; in the form of an axiom.
apomecometry: The art of measuring the distance of objects afar off. [Obs. orR.]
antaphrodisiac: Capable of blunting the venereal appetite.-- n.
atomization: The reduction of fluids into fine spray.
acred: Possessing acres or landed property; -- used in composition;as, large-acred men.
alkali: One of a class of caustic bases, such as soda, potash, ammoma,and lithia, whose distinguishing peculiarities are solubility inalcohol and water, uniting with oils and fats to form soap,neutralizing and forming salts with acids, turning to brown severalvegetable yellows, and changing reddened litmus to blue. Fixedalkalies, potash and soda.-- Vegetable alkalies. Same as Alkaloids.-- Volatile alkali, ammonia, so called in distinction from the fixedalkalies.
armrack: A frame, generally vertical, for holding small arms.
amphiboly: Ambiguous discourse; amphibology.If it oracle contrary to our interest or humor, we will create anamphiboly, a double meaning where there is none. Whitlock.
astringency: The quality of being astringent; the power of contracting theparts of the body; that quality in medicines or other substanceswhich causes contraction of the organic textures; as, the astringencyof tannin.
agatize: To convert into agate; to make resemble agate. Dana.
arseniureted: Combined with arsenic; -- said some elementary substances orradicals; as, arseniureted hydrogen. [Also spelt arseniuretted.]
appeasement: The act of appeasing, or the state of being appeased;pacification. Hayward.
arthrogastra: A division of the Arachnida, having the abdomen annulated,including the scorpions, harvestmen, etc.; pedipalpi.
annuitant: One who receives, or its entitled to receive, an annuity. Lamb.
air cock: A faucet to allow escape of air.
alight: Lighted; lighted up; in a flame. "The lamps were alight."Dickens.
anthokyan: The blue coloring matter of certain flowers. Same as Cyanin.
amanuensis: A person whose employment is to write what another dictates, orto copy what another has written.
auriphrygiate: Embroidered or decorated with gold. [R.] Southey.
amelcorn: A variety of wheat from which starch is produced; -- calledalso French rice.
apogee: That point in the orbit of the moon which is at the greatestdistance from the earth.
acoustic: Pertaining to the sense of hearing, the organs of hearing, orthe science of sounds; auditory. Acoustic duct, the auditory duct, orexternal passage of the ear.-- Acoustic telegraph, a telegraph making audible signals; atelephone.-- Acoustic vessels, brazen tubes or vessels, shaped like a bell,used in ancient theaters to propel the voices of the actors, so as torender them audible to a great distance.
arioso: In the smooth and melodious style of an air; ariose.
alferes: An ensign; a standard bearer. [Obs.] J. Fletcher.
avant: The front of an army. [Obs.] See Van.
areola: The colored ring around the nipple, or around a vesicle orpustule.
assassin: One who kills, or attempts to kill, by surprise or secretassault; one who treacherously murders any one unprepared fordefense.
accidentalness: The quality of being accidental; casualness.
air brake: A railway brake operated by condensed air. Knight.
attractability: The quality or fact of being attractable. Sir W. Jones.
adverb: A word used to modify the sense of a verb, participle,adjective, or other adverb, and usually placed near it; as, he writeswell; paper extremely white.
acervative: Heaped up; tending to heap up.
anas: A genus of water fowls, of the order Anseres, including certainspecies of fresh-water ducks.
abate: (a) To bring entirely down or put an end to; to do away with;as, to abate a nuisance, to abate a writ. (b) (Eng. Law) To diminish;to reduce. Legacies are liable to be abated entirely or inproportion, upon a deficiency of assets. To abate a tax, to remit iteither wholly or in part.
adios: Adieu; farewell; good-by; -- chiefly used among Spanish-speaking people.
antepenultimate: Of or pertaining to the last syllable but two.-- n.
antiphrasis: The use of words in a sense opposite to their proper meaning;as when a court of justice is called a court of vengeance.
acicular: Needle-shaped; slender like a needle or bristle, as some leavesor crystals; also, having sharp points like needless. A*cic"u*lar*ly,adv.
alterableness: The quality of being alterable; variableness; alterability.
anthesis: The period or state of full expansion in a flower. Gray.
artsman: A man skilled in an art or in arts. [Obs.] Bacon.
archon: One of the chief magistrates in ancient Athens, especially, bypreëminence, the first of the nine chief magistrates.-- Ar*chon"tic, a.
acclimate: To habituate to a climate not native; to acclimatize. J. H.Newman.
aretology: That part of moral philosophy which treats of virtue, itsnature, and the means of attaining to it.
amazon: A name numerous species of South American parrots of the genusChrysotis Amazon ant (Zoöl.), a species of ant (Polyergus rufescens),of Europe and America. They seize by conquest the larvæ and nymphsother species and make slaves of them in their own nests.
aracanese: Of or pertaining to Aracan, a province of British Burmah.-- n. sing. & pl.
angled: Having an angle or angles; -- used in compounds; as, right-angled, many-angled, etc.The thrice three-angled beechnut shell. Bp. Hall.
aconitine: An intensely poisonous alkaloid, extracted from aconite.
arrowworm: A peculiar transparent worm of the genus Sagitta, living at thesurface of the sea. See Sagitta.
aller: Same as Alder, of all. [Obs.] Chaucer.
archchancellor: A chief chancellor; -- an officer in the old German empire, whopresided over the secretaries of the court.
agnostic: Professing ignorance; involving no dogmatic; pertaining to orinvolving agnosticism.-- Ag*nos"tic*al*ly, adv.
areopagite: A member of the Areopagus. Acts xvii. 34.
aeroclub: A club or association of persons interested in aëronautics.
advantage: To give an advantage to; to further; to promote; to benefit; toprofit.The truth is, the archbishop's own stiffness and averseness to complywith the court designs, advantaged his adversaries against him.Fuller.What is a man advantaged, if he gain the whole world, and losehimself, or be cast away Luke ix. 25.To advantage one's self of, to avail one's self of. [Obs.]
adjustment: Settlement of claims; an equitable arrangement of conflictingclaims, as in set-off, contribution, exoneration, subrogation, andmarshaling. Bispham.
amphipoda: A numerous group of fourteen -- footed Crustacea, inhabitingboth fresh and salt water. The body is usually compressed laterally,and the anterior pairs or legs are directed downward and forward, butthe posterior legs are usually turned upward and backward. The beachflea is an example. See Tetradecapoda and Arthrostraca.
argonautic: Of or pertaining to the Argonauts.
atacamite: An oxychloride of copper, usually in emerald-green prismaticcrystals.
allied: United; joined; leagued; akin; related. See Ally.
appendage: A subordinate or subsidiary part or organ; an external organ orlimb, esp. of the articulates.Antennæ and other appendages used for feeling. Carpenter.
abysm: An abyss; a gulf. "The abysm of hell." Shak.
anadiplosis: A repetition of the last word or any prominent word in asentence or clause, at the beginning of the next, with an adjunctidea; as, "He retained his virtues amidst all his misfortunes --misfortunes which no prudence could foresee or prevent."
approximator: One who, or that which, approximates.
aurate: A combination of auric acid with a base; as, aurate orpotassium.
aye: An affirmative vote; one who votes in the affirmative; as, "Tocall for the ayes and noes;" "The ayes have it."
academian: A member of an academy, university, or college.
adductor: A muscle which draws a limb or part of the body toward themiddle line of the body, or closes extended parts of the body; --opposed to abductor; as, the adductor of the eye, which turns the eyetoward the nose.In the bivalve shells, the muscles which close the values of theshell are called adductor muscles. Verrill.
amygdalin: A glucoside extracted from bitter almonds as a white,crystalline substance.
antheridium: The male reproductive apparatus in the lower, consisting of acell or other cavity in which spermatozoids are produced; -- calledalso spermary.-- An`ther*id"i*al, a.
assembler: One who assembles a number of individuals; also, one of anumber assembled.
administerial: Pertaining to administration, or to the executive part ofgovernment.
aphrodisiac: That which (as a drug, or some kinds of food) excites tovenery.
adrian: Pertaining to the Adriatic Sea; as, Adrian billows.
aeroplanist: One who flies in an aëroplane.
arsenide: A compound of arsenic with a metal, or positive element orradical; -- formerly called arseniuret.
alar: Axillary; in the fork or axil. Gray.
anilinism: A disease due to inhaling the poisonous fumes present in themanufacture of aniline.
amigo: A friend; -- a Spanish term applied in the Philippine Islandsto friendly natives.
aventail: The movable front to a helmet; the ventail.
antivenin: The serum of blood rendered antitoxic to a venom by repeatedinjections of small doses of the venom.
acceptilation: Gratuitous discharge; a release from debt or obligation withoutpayment; free remission.
annualist: One who writes for, or who edits, an annual. [R.]
archdeacon: In England, an ecclesiastical dignitary, next in rank below abishop, whom he assists, and by whom he is appointed, though withindependent authority. Blackstone.
ailette: A small square shield, formerly worn on the shoulders ofknights, -- being the prototype of the modern epaulet. Fairholt.
anaconda: A large South American snake of the Boa family (Eunectesmurinus), which lives near rivers, and preys on birds and smallmammals. The name is also applied to a similar large serpent (Pythontigris) of Ceylon.
assentive: Giving assent; of the nature of assent; complying.-- As*sent"ive*ness, n.
ambassadorial: Of or pertaining to an ambassador. H. Walpole.
alluring: That allures; attracting; charming; tempting.-- Al*lur"ing*ly, adv.-- Al*lur"ing*ness, n.
alloxanate: A combination of alloxanic acid and a base or base or positiveradical.
alert: An alarm from a real or threatened attack; a sudden attack;also, a bugle sound to give warning. "We have had an alert." Farrow.On the alert, on the lookout or watch against attack or danger; readyto act.
agoing: In motion; in the act of going; as, to set a mill agoing.
adenose: Like a gland; full of glands; glandulous; adenous.
antipyretic: Efficacious in preventing or allaying fever.-- n.
amen: An expression used at the end of prayers, and meaning, So beit. At the end of a creed, it is a solemn asseveration of belief.When it introduces a declaration, it is equivalent to truly, verily.It is used as a noun, to demote: (a) concurrence in belief, or in astatement; assent; (b) the final word or act; (c) Christ as being onewho is true and faithful.And let all the people say, Amen. Ps. cvi. 48.Amen, amen, I say to thee, except a man be born again, he can not seethe kingdom of God. John ii. 3. Rhemish Trans.To say amen to, to approve warmly; to concur in heartily oremphatically; to ratify; as, I say Amen to all.
assignor: An assigner; a person who assigns or transfers an interest; as,the assignor of a debt or other chose in action.
adight: To set in order; to array; to attire; to deck, to dress. [Obs.]
amate: To dismay; to dishearten; to daunt. [Obs. or Archaic]The Silures, to amate the new general, rumored the overthrow greaterthan was true. Milton.
appointive: Subject to appointment; as, an appointive office. [R.]
aposiopesis: A figure of speech in which the speaker breaks off suddenly, asif unwilling or unable to state what was in his mind; as, "I declareto you that his conduct -- but I can not speak of that, here."
attachable: Capable of being attached; esp., liable to be taken by writ orprecept.
apohyal: Of or pertaining to a portion of the horn of the hyoid bone.
annumerate: To add on; to count in. [Obs.] Wollaston.
areolar: Pertaining to, or like, an areola; filled with interstices orareolæ. reolar tissue (Anat.), a form of fibrous connective tissue inwhich the fibers are loosely arranged with numerous spaces, orareolæ, between them.
araceous: Of or pertaining to an order of plants, of which the genus Arumis the type.
astriction: An obligation to have the grain growing on certain lands groundat a certain mill, the owner paying a toll. Bell.
apanthropy: An aversion to the company of men; a love of solitude.
accept: To receive as obligatory and promise to pay; as, to accept abill of exchange. Bouvier.
adown: From a higher to a lower situation; downward; down, to or onthe ground. [Archaic] "Thrice did she sink adown." Spenser.
apiece: Each by itself; by the single one; to each; as the share ofeach; as, these melons cost a shilling apiece. "Fined . . . athousand pounds apiece." Hume.
adjournal: Adjournment; postponement. [R.] "An adjournal of the Diet." SirW. Scott.
ambassage: Same as Embassage. [Obs. or R.] Luke xiv. 32.
aviate: To fly, or navigate the air, in an aëroplane or heavier-than-air flying machine. [Colloq.]
autopneumatic: Acting or moving automatically by means of compressed air.
archaize: To make appear archaic or antique. Mahaffy.
acoustically: In relation to sound or to hearing. Tyndall.
admissive: Implying an admission; tending to admit. [R.] Lamb.
asitia: Want of appetite; loathing of food.
abominate: To turn from as ill-omened; to hate in the highest degree, asif with religious dread; loathe; as, to abominate all impiety.
accidental: Those fortuitous effects produced by luminous rays falling oncertain objects so that some parts stand forth in abnormal brightnessand other parts are cast into a deep shadow.
arthrodynic: Pertaining to arthrodynia, or pain in the joints; rheumatic.
aneroid: Containing no liquid; -- said of kind of barometer. Aneroidbarometer, a barometer the action of which depends on the varyingpressure of the atmosphere upon the elastic top of a metallic box(shaped like a watch) from which the air has been exhausted. An indexshows the variation of pressure.
amnesic: Of or pertaining to amnesia. "Amnesic or coördinate defects."Quian.
acephalocystic: Pertaining to, or resembling, the acephalocysts.
anthropotomical: Pertaining to anthropotomy, or the dissection of human bodies.
atheling: An Anglo-Saxon prince or nobleman; esp., the heir apparent or aprince of the royal family. [Written also Adeling and Ætheling.]
abstrusity: Abstruseness; that which is abstruse. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
adulatress: A woman who flatters with servility.
apparitor: A messenger or officer who serves the process of anecclesiastical court. Bouvier.
anabas: A genus of fishes, remarkable for their power of living longout of water, and of making their way on land for considerabledistances, and for climbing trees; the climbing fishes.
anion: An electro-negative element, or the element which, in electro-chemical decompositions, is evolved at the anode; -- opposed tocation. Faraday.
ara: The Altar; a southern constellation, south of the tail of theScorpion.
agrin: In the act of grinning. "His visage all agrin." Tennyson.
acinetae: A group of suctorial Infusoria, which in the adult stage arestationary. See Suctoria.
anhistous: Without definite structure; as, an anhistous membrane.
albertite: A bituminous mineral resembling asphaltum, found in the countyof A.
allision: The act of dashing against, or striking upon.The boisterous allision of the sea. Woodward.
acaulescent: Having no stem or caulis, or only a very short one concealed inthe ground. Gray.
anta: A species of pier produced by thickening a wall at itstermination, treated architecturally as a pilaster, with capital andbase.
azymite: One who administered the Eucharist with unleavened bread; -- aname of reproach given by those of the Greek church to the Latins.
accusative: Applied to the case (as the fourth case of Latin and Greeknouns) which expresses the immediate object on which the action orinfluence of a transitive verb terminates, or the immediate object ofmotion or tendency to, expressed by a preposition. It corresponds tothe objective case in English.
air cooling: In gasoline-engine motor vehicles, the cooling of the cylinderby increasing its radiating surface by means of ribs or radiators,and placing it so that it is exposed to a current of air. Cf. Watercooling. -- Air"-cooled`, a.
appointee: A person in whose favor a power of appointment is executed.Kent. Wharton.
accustomably: According to custom; ordinarily; customarily. Latimer.
aimer: One who aims, directs, or points.
antonomasia: The use of some epithet or the name of some office, dignity, orthe like, instead of the proper name of the person; as when hismajesty is used for a king, or when, instead of Aristotle, we say,the philosopher; or, conversely, the use of a proper name instead ofan appellative, as when a wise man is called a Solomon, or an eminentorator a Cicero.
anthropolite: A petrifaction of the human body, or of any portion of it.
aworking: At work; in action. [Archaic or Colloq.] Spenser.
armenian: Of or pertaining to Armenia. Armenian bole, a soft clayey earthof a bright red color found in Armenia, Tuscany, etc.-- Armenian stone. (a) The commercial name of lapis lazuli. (b)Emery.
adulterine: Proceeding from adulterous intercourse. Hence: Spurious;without the support of law; illegal.When any particular class of artificers or traders thought proper toact as a corporation without a charter, such were called adulterineguilds. Adam Smith.
ancon: The olecranon, or the elbow. Ancon sheep (Zoöl.), a breed ofsheep with short crooked legs and long back. It originated inMassachusetts in 1791; -- called also the otter breed.
admiring: Expressing admiration; as, an admiring glance.-- Ad*mir"ing*ly, adv. Shak.
accrescence: Continuous growth; an accretion. [R.]The silent accrescence of belief from the unwatched depositions of ageneral, never contradicted hearsy. Coleridge.
aslant: Toward one side; in a slanting direction; obliquely.[The shaft] drove through his neck aslant. Dryden.
aldehyde: A colorless, mobile, and very volatile liquid obtained fromalcohol by certain of oxidation.
apopemptic: Sung or addressed to one departing; valedictory; as, apoplecticsongs or hymns.
accolade: A brace used to join two or more staves.
articulative: Of or pertaining to articulation. Bush.
argand lamp: A lamp with a circular hollow wick and glass chimney whichallow a current of air both inside and outside of the flame. Argandburner, a burner for an Argand lamp, or a gas burner in which theprinciple of that lamp is applied.
arrogative: Making undue claims and pretension; prone to arrogance. [R.]Dr. H. More.
amplitude: The horizontal line which measures the distance to which aprojectile is thrown; the range.
asomatous: Without a material body; incorporeal. Todd.
astir: Stirring; in a state of activity or motion; out of bed.
acquiescent: Resting satisfied or submissive; disposed tacitly to submit;assentive; as, an acquiescent policy.
asseverate: To affirm or aver positively, or with solemnity.
artilize: To make resemble. [Obs.]If I was a philosopher, says Montaigne, I would naturalize artinstead of artilizing nature. Bolingbroke.
amphigory: A nonsense verse; a rigmarole, with apparent meaning, which onfurther attention proves to be meaningless. [Written alsoamphigouri.]
aulic: Pertaining to a royal court.Ecclesiastical wealth and aulic dignities. Landor.Aulic council (Hist.), a supreme court of the old German empire;properly the supreme court of the emperor. It ceased at the death ofeach emperor, and was renewed by his successor. It became extinctwhen the German empire was dissolved, in 1806. The term is nowapplied to a council of the war department of the Austrian empire,and the members of different provincial chanceries of that empire arecalled aulic councilors. P. Cyc.
ankle: The joint which connects the foot with the leg; the tarsus.Ankle bone, the bone of the ankle; the astragalus.
arundelian: Pertaining to an Earl of Arundel; as, Arundel or Arundelianmarbles, marbles from ancient Greece, bought by the Earl of Arundelin 1624.
angleworm: A earthworm of the genus Lumbricus, frequently used by anglersfor bait. See Earthworm.
abstractively: In a abstract manner; separately; in or by itself. Feltham.
article: One of the three words, a, an, the, used before nouns to limitor define their application. A (or an) is called the indefinitearticle, the the definite article.
after-mentioned: Mentioned afterwards; as, persons after-mentioned (in awriting).
advancing surface: The first of two or more surfaces arranged in tandem; -- contr.with following surface, which is the rear surface.
alike: Having resemblance or similitude; similar; without difference.[Now used only predicatively.]The darkness and the light are both alike to thee. Ps. cxxxix. 12.
anthropogeography: The science of the human species as to geographicaldistribution and environment. Broadly, it includes industrial,commercial, and political geography, and that part of ethnology whichdeals with distribution and physical environment. --An`thro*po*ge*og"ra*pher (#), n. -- An`thro*po*ge`o*graph"ic*al (#),a.
abiogenist: One who believes that life can be produced independently ofantecedent. Huxley.
aeruginous: Of the nature or color of verdigris, or the rust of copper.
acrotomous: Having a cleavage parallel with the base.
alexipharmic: An antidote against poison or infection; a counterpoison.
anecdotist: One who relates or collects anecdotes.
aventure: A mischance causing a person's death without felony, as bydrowning, or falling into the fire.
ambler: A horse or a person that ambles.
aristophanic: Of or pertaining to Aristophanes, the Athenian comic poet.
arithmetically: Conformably to the principles or methods of arithmetic.
affrontee: One who receives an affront. Lytton.
assuage: To soften, in a figurative sense; to allay, mitigate, ease, orlessen, as heat, pain, or grief; to appease or pacify, as passion ortumult; to satisfy, as appetite or desire.Refreshing winds the summer's heat assuage. Addison.To assuage the sorrows of a desolate old man Burke.The fount at which the panting mind assuages Her thirst of knowledge.Byron.
appropriament: What is peculiarly one's own; peculiar qualification.[Obs.]If you can neglect Your own appropriaments. Ford.
avignon berry: The fruit of the Rhamnus infectorius, eand of other species ofthe same genus; -- so called from the city of Avignon, in France. Itis used by dyers and painters for coloring yellow. Called also Frenchberry.
amazing: Causing amazement; very wonderful; as, amazing grace.-- A*maz"ing*ly, adv.
ancillary: Subservient or subordinate, like a handmaid; auxiliary.The Convocation of York seems to have been always considered asinferior, and even ancillary, to the greater province. Hallam.
abutilon: A genus of malvaceous plants of many species, found in thetorrid and temperate zones of both continents; -- called also Indianmallow.
ant cow: Any aphid from which ants obtain honeydew.
avocation: Pursuits; duties; affairs which occupy one's time; usualemployment; vocation.There are professions, among the men, no more favorable to thesestudies than the common avocations of women.
