Richardson.In a few hours, above thirty thousand men left his standard, andreturned to their ordinary avocations. Macaulay.An irregularity and instability of purpose, which makes them choosethe wandering avocations of a shepherd, rather than the more fixedpursuits of agriculture. Buckle.
audit: To examine and adjust, as an account or accounts; as, to auditthe accounts of a treasure, or of parties who have a suit dependingin court.
arena: The area in the central part of an amphitheater, in which thegladiators fought and other shows were exhibited; -- so calledbecause it was covered with sand.
arow: In a row, line, or rank; successively; in order. Shak.And twenty, rank in rank, they rode arow. Dryden.
abalienation: The act of abalienating; alienation; estrangement. [Obs.]
apportionateness: The quality of being apportioned or in proportion. [Obs. & R.]
abjectedness: A very abject or low condition; abjectness. [R.] Boyle.
aim: To direct or point, as a weapon, at a particular object; todirect, as a missile, an act, or a proceeding, at, to, or against anobject; as, to aim a musket or an arrow, the fist or a blow (atsomething); to aim a satire or a reflection (at some person or vice).
anacrusis: A prefix of one or two unaccented syllables to a verse properlybeginning with an accented syllable.
alliterate: To employ or place so as to make alliteration. Skeat.
accubation: The act or posture of reclining on a couch, as practiced by theancients at meals.
arboret: A small tree or shrub. [Obs.] Spenser.Among thick-woven arborets, and flowers Imbordered on each bank.Milton.
acrospore: A spore borne at the extremity of the cells of fructificationin fungi.
amadavat: The strawberry finch, a small Indian song bird (Estreldaamandava), commonly caged and kept for fighting. The female is olivebrown; the male, in summer, mostly crimson; -- called also redwaxbill. [Written also amaduvad and avadavat.]
account book: A book in which accounts are kept. Swift.
archiepiscopal: Of or pertaining to an archbishop; as, Canterbury is anarchiepiscopal see.
astroite: A radiated stone or fossil; star-stone. [Obs.] [Written alsoastrite and astrion.]
acquittal: A setting free, or deliverance from the charge of an offense,by verdict of a jury or sentence of a court. Bouvier.
antonomastic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, antonomasia.-- An`to*no*mas"tic*al*ly, adv.
ad-: As a prefix ad- assumes the forms ac-, af-, ag-, al-, an-, ap-,ar-, as-, at-, assimilating the d with the first letter of the wordto which ad- is prefixed. It remains unchanged before vowels, andbefore d, h, j, m, v. Examples: adduce, adhere, adjacent, admit,advent, accord, affect, aggregate, allude, annex, appear, etc. Itbecomes ac- before qu, as in acquiesce.
attask: To take to task; to blame. Shak.
advocateship: Office or duty of an advocate.
adduce: To bring forward or offer, as an argument, passage, orconsideration which bears on a statement or case; to cite; to allege.Reasons . . . were adduced on both sides. Macaulay.Enough could not be adduced to satisfy the purpose of illustration.De Quincey.
anisospore: A sexual spore in which the sexes differ in size; -- opposed toisospore.
allotment: The allowance of a specific amount of scrip or of a particularthing to a particular person. Cottage allotment, an allotment of asmall portion of land to a country laborer for garden cultivation.[Eng.]
archiepiscopality: The station or dignity of an archbishop; archiepiscopacy.Fuller.
alluvial: Pertaining to, contained in, or composed of, alluvium; relatingto the deposits made by flowing water; washed away from one place anddeposited in another; as, alluvial soil, mud, accumulations,deposits.
apocopate: To cut off or drop; as, to apocopate a word, or the lastletter, syllable, or part of a word.
a cheval: Astride; with a part on each side; -- used specif. indesignating the position of an army with the wings separated by someline of demarcation, as a river or road.
amplify: To enlarge by addition or discussion; to treat copiously byadding particulars, illustrations, etc.; to expand; to make much of.Troilus and Cressida was written by a Lombard author, but muchamplified by our English translator. Dryden.
amenableness: The quality or state of being amenable; liability to answercharges; answerableness.
aurous: Pertaining to, or derived from, gold; -- said of thosecompounds of gold in which this element has its lower valence; as,aurous oxide.
allopathy: That system of medical practice which aims to combat disease bythe use of remedies which produce effects different from thoseproduced by the special disease treated; -- a term invented byHahnemann to designate the ordinary practice, as opposed tohomeopathy.
abbess: A female superior or governess of a nunnery, or convent ofnuns, having the same authority over the nuns which the abbots haveover the monks. See Abbey.
auscultatory: Of or pertaining to auscultation. Dunglison.
acrogen: A plant of the highest class of cryptograms, including theferns, etc. See Cryptogamia. The Age of Acrogens (Geol.), the age ofcoal plants, or the carboniferous era.
assenting: Giving or implying assent.-- As*sent"ing*ly, adv.
archaean: Ancient; pertaining to the earliest period in geologicalhistory.
artotyrite: One of a sect in the primitive church, who celebrated theLord's Supper with bread and cheese, alleging that the firstoblations of men not only of the fruit of the earth, but of theirflocks. [Gen. iv. 3, 4.]
astound: Stunned; astounded; astonished. [Archaic] Spenser.Thus Ellen, dizzy and astound. As sudden ruin yawned around. Sir W.Scott.
archipterygium: The primitive form of fin, like that of Ceratodus.
aft: Near or towards the stern of a vessel; astern; abaft.
arsine: A compound of arsenic and hydrogen, AsH3, a colorless andexceedingly poisonous gas, having and odor like garlic; arseniuretedhydrogen.
astarte: A genus of bivalve mollusks, common on the coasts of Americaand Europe.
abaculus: A small tile of glass, marble, or other substance, of variouscolors, used in making ornamental patterns in mosaic pavements.Fairholt.
autonomic: Having the power of self-government; autonomous. Hickok.
agama: A genus of lizards, one of the few which feed upon vegetablesubstances; also, one of these lizards.
accompany: To perform an accompanying part or parts in a composition.
aurigation: The act of driving a chariot or a carriage. [R.] De Quincey.
amendable: Capable of being amended; as, an amendable writ or error.-- A*mend"a*ble*ness, n.
albertype: A picture printed from a kind of gelatine plate produced bymeans of a photographic negative.
accourt: To treat courteously; to court. [Obs.] Spenser.
adurol: Either of two compounds, a chlorine derivative and brominederivative, of hydroquinone, used as developers.
arthrodia: A form of diarthrodial articulation in which the articularsurfaces are nearly flat, so that they form only an imperfect balland socket.
aggest: To heap up. [Obs.]The violence of the waters aggested the earth. Fuller.
asclepiad: A choriambic verse, first used by the Greek poet Asclepias,consisting of four feet, viz., a spondee, two choriambi, and aniambus.
algum: Same as Almug (and etymologically preferable). 2 Chron. ii. 8.
accumulative: Characterized by accumulation; serving to collect or amass;cumulative; additional.-- Ac*cu"mu*la*tive*ly, adv.-- Ac*cu"mu*la*tive*ness, n.
antechapel: The outer part of the west end of a collegiate or other chapel.Shipley.
assayer: One who assays. Specifically: One who examines metallic ores orcompounds, for the purpose of determining the amount of anyparticular metal in the same, especially of gold or silver.
aggress: To commit the first act of hostility or offense; to begin aquarrel or controversy; to make an attack; -- with on.
antistrophon: An argument retorted on an opponent. Milton.
apostematous: Pertaining to, or partaking of the nature of, an aposteme.
attractor: One who, or that which, attracts. Sir T. Browne
adjourn: To put off or defer to another day, or indefinitely; topostpone; to close or suspend for the day; -- commonly said of themeeting, or the action, of convened body; as, to adjourn the meeting;to adjourn a debate.It is a common practice to adjourn the reformation of their lives toa further time. Barrow.'Tis a needful fitness That we adjourn this court till further day.Shak.
astucious: Subtle; cunning; astute. [R.] Sir W. Scott.-- As*tu"cious*ly, adv. [R.]
antemural: An outwork of a strong, high wall, with turrets, in frontgateway (as of an old castle), for defending the entrance.
allegretto: Quicker than andante, but not so quick as allegro.-- n.
arthroderm: The external covering of an Arthropod.
alcyonacea: A group of soft-bodied Alcyonaria, of which Alcyonium is thetype. See Illust. under Alcyonaria.
aristotelian: Of or pertaining to Aristotle, the famous Greek philosopher(384-322 b. c.).-- n.
alcyonium: A genus of fleshy Alcyonaria, its polyps somewhat resemblingflowers with eight fringed rays. The term was also formerly used forcertain species of sponges.
abundantly: In a sufficient degree; fully; amply; plentifully; in largemeasure.
abdominothoracic: Relating to the abdomen and the thorax, or chest.
afterthought: Reflection after an act; later or subsequent thought orexpedient.
anthrenus: A genus of small beetles, several of which, in the larvalstate, are very destructive to woolen goods, fur, etc. The common"museum pest" is A. varius; the carpet beetle is A. scrophulariæ. Thelarvæ are commonly confounded with moths.
ancile: The sacred shield of the Romans, said to have-fallen fromheaven in the reign of Numa. It was the palladium of Rome.
asceticism: The condition, practice, or mode of life, of ascetics.
accident: A property attached to a word, but not essential to it, asgender, number, case.
ant: A hymenopterous insect of the Linnæan genus Formica, which isnow made a family of several genera; an emmet; a pismire.
assyriologist: One versed in Assyriology; a student of Assyrian archæology.
archprelate: An archbishop or other chief prelate.
acanthopteri: A group of teleostean fishes having spiny fins. SeeAcanthopterygii.
algology: The study or science of algæ or seaweeds.
all hail: All health; -- a phrase of salutation or welcome.
anthracene: A solid hydrocarbon, C6H4.C2H2.C6H4, which accompaniesnaphthalene in the last stages of the distillation of coal tar. Itschief use is in the artificial production of alizarin. [Written alsoanthracin.]
apocalypse: Of or pertaining to a revelation, or, specifically, to theRevelation of St. John; containing, or of the nature of, a propheticrevelation. Apocolyptic number, the number 666, mentioned in Rev.xiii. 18. It has been variously interpreted.
ascititious: Supplemental; not inherent or original; adscititious;additional; assumed.Homer has been reckoned an ascititious name. Pope.
atheroid: Shaped like an ear of grain.
allogamy: Fertilization of the pistil of a plant by pollen from anotherof the same species; cross-fertilization.
apsis: One of the two points of an orbit, as of a planet or satellite,which are at the greatest and least distance from the central body,corresponding to the aphelion and perihelion of a planet, or to theapogee and perigee of the moon. The more distant is called the higherapsis; the other, the lower apsis; and the line joining them, theline of apsides.
aboard: On board; into or within a ship or boat; hence, into or withina railway car.
asphyxiate: To bring to a state of asphyxia; to suffocate.
angio-: A prefix, or combining form, in numerous compounds, usuallyrelating to seed or blood vessels, or to something contained in, orcovered by, a vessel.
arab: One of a swarthy race occupying Arabia, and numerous in Syria,Northern Africa, etc. Street Arab, a homeless vagabond in the streetsof a city, particularly and outcast boy or girl. Tylor.The ragged outcasts and street Arabs who are shivering in dampdoorways. Lond. Sat. Rev.
amicability: The quality of being amicable; friendliness; amicableness. Ash.
anacamptics: A group of teleostean fishes destitute of spiny fin-rays, asthe cod.
aquatic: Pertaining to water growing in water; living in, swimming in,or frequenting the margins of waters; as, aquatic plants and fowls.
augurous: Full of augury; foreboding. [Obs.] "Augurous hearts." Chapman.
alkoran: The Mohammedan Scriptures. Same as Alcoran and Koran.
aftergame: A second game; hence, a subsequent scheme or expedient. Wotton.Aftergame at Irish, an ancient game very nearly resemblingbackgammon. Beau. & Fl.
anaesthetic: That which produces insensibility to pain, as chloroform,ether, etc.
apis: A genus of insects of the order Hymenoptera, including thecommon honeybee (Apis mellifica) and other related species. SeeHoneybee.
adage: An old saying, which has obtained credit by long use; aproverb.Letting "I dare not" wait upon "I would," Like the poor cat i' theadage. Shak.
aristotype: Orig., a printing-out process using paper coated with silverchloride in gelatin; now, any such process using silver salts ineither collodion or gelatin; also, a print so made.
acrostically: After the manner of an acrostic.
announcement: The act of announcing, or giving notice; that which announces;proclamation; publication.
ascococcus: A form of micrococcus, found in putrid meat infusions,occurring in peculiar masses, each of which is inclosed in a hyalinecapsule and contains a large number of spherical micrococci.
anthrax: A microscopic, bacterial organism (Bacillus anthracis),resembling transparent rods. [See Illust. under Bacillus.]
ague: An intermittent fever, attended by alternate cold and hot fits.
ae: A diphthong in the Latin language; used also by the Saxonwriters. It answers to the Gr. æ was generally replaced by a, thelong e or ee. In derivatives from Latin words with ae, it is mostlysuperseded by e. For most words found with this initial combination,the reader will therefore search under the letter E.
arenicolite: An ancient wormhole in sand, preserved in the rocks. Dana.
assimilative: Tending to, or characterized by, assimilation; that assimilatesor causes assimilation; as, an assimilative process or substance.
angiotomy: Dissection of the blood vessels and lymphatics of the body.Dunglison.
alluminor: An illuminator of manuscripts and books; a limner. [Obs.]Cowell.
arreptitious: Snatched away; seized or possessed, as a demoniac; raving; mad;crack-brained. [Obs.]Odd, arreptitious, frantic extravagances. Howell.
anthracometer: An instrument for measuring the amount of carbonic acid in amixture.
arenation: A sand bath; application of hot sand to the body. Dunglison.
anthemis: Chamomile; a genus of composite, herbaceous plants.
antares: The principal star in Scorpio: -- called also the Scorpion'sHeart.
annulet: A small, flat fillet, encircling a column, etc., used byitself, or with other moldings. It is used, several times repeated,under the Doric capital.
aceric: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the maple; as, aceric acid.Ure.
arrowheaded: Shaped like the head of an arow; cuneiform. Arrowheadedcharacters, characters the elements of which consist of strokesresembling arrowheads, nailheads, or wedges; -- hence called alsonail-headed, wedge-formed, cuneiform, or cuneatic characters; theoldest written characters used in the country about the Tigris andEuphrates, and subsequently in Persia, and abounding among the ruinsof Persepolis, Nineveh, and Babylon. See Cuneiform.
agitator: One of a body of men appointed by the army, in Cromwell's time,to look after their interests; -- called also adjutators. Clarendon.
acicula: One of the needlelike or bristlelike spines or prickles of someanimals and plants; also, a needlelike crystal.
afront: In front; face to face.-- prep. In front of. Shak.
anaglyph: Any sculptured, chased, or embossed ornament worked in lowrelief, as a cameo.
agrarianism: An equal or equitable division of landed property; theprinciples or acts of those who favor a redistribution of land.
apogeotropism: The apogeotropic tendency of some leaves, and other parts.
aruspice: A soothsayer of ancient Rome. Same as Aruspex. [Written alsoharuspice.]
acquit: Acquitted; set free; rid of. [Archaic] Shak.
azureous: Of a fine blue color; azure.
abditive: Having the quality of hiding. [R.] Bailey.
arachnoid: Pertaining to a thin membrane of the brain and spinal cord,between the dura mater and pia mater.
archly: In an arch manner; with attractive slyness or roguishness;slyly; waggishly.Archly the maiden smiled. Longfellow.
amarine: A characteristic crystalline substance, obtained from oil ofbitter almonds.
absume: To consume gradually; to waste away. [Obs.] Boyle.
amity: Friendship, in a general sense, between individuals, societies,or nations; friendly relations; good understanding; as, a treaty ofamity and commerce; the amity of the Whigs and Tories.To live on terms of amity with vice. Cowper.
angariation: Exaction of forced service; compulsion. [Obs.] Speed.
aerodonetics: The science of gliding and soaring flight.
axially: In relation to, or in a line with, an axis; in the axial(magnetic) line.
aphthous: Pertaining to, or caused by, aphthæ; characterized by aphtæ;as, aphthous ulcers; aphthous fever.
arcual: Of or pertaining to an arc. Arcual measure of an angle (Math.),that in which the unit angle has its measuring arc equal to theradius of the circle.
adipocere: A soft, unctuous, or waxy substance, of a light brown color,into which the fat and muscle tissue of dead bodies sometimes areconverted, by long immersion in water or by burial in moist places.It is a result of fatty degeneration.
allograph: A writing or signature made by some person other than any ofthe parties thereto; -- opposed to autograph.
athetize: To set aside or reject as spurious, as by marking with anobelus.
archonship: The office of an archon. Mitford.
alternant: Composed of alternate layers, as some rocks.
airometer: A hollow cylinder to contain air. It is closed above and openbelow, and has its open end plunged into water.
apennine: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the Apennines, a chain ofmountains extending through Italy.
adonist: One who maintains that points of the Hebrew word translated"Jehovah" are really the vowel points of the word "Adonai." SeeJehovist.
anodyne: Serving to assuage pain; soothing.The anodyne draught of oblivion. Burke.
apprehensible: Capable of being apprehended or conceived. "Apprehensible byfaith." Bp. Hall.-- Ap`*pre*hen"si*bly, adv.
am: The first person singular of the verb be, in the indicativemode, present tense. See Be.God said unto Moses, I am that am. Exod. iii. 14.
alloquy: A speaking to another; an address. [Obs.]
asininity: The quality of being asinine; stupidity combined withobstinacy.
agronomics: The science of the distribution and management of land.
araneina: The order of Arachnida that includes the spiders.
appurtenant: Annexed or pertaining to some more important thing; accessory;incident; as, a right of way appurtenant to land or buildings.Blackstone. Common appurtenatn. (Law) See under Common, n.
advancing edge: The front edge (in direction of motion) of a supportingsurface; -- contr. with following edge, which is the rear edge.
atheize: To render atheistic or godless. [R.]They endeavored to atheize one another. Berkeley.
appetitive: Having the quality of desiring gratification; as, appetitivepower or faculty. Sir M. Hale.
ai: The three-toed sloth (Bradypus tridactylus) of South America.See Sloth.
amends: Compensation for a loss or injury; recompense; reparation. [Nowconst. with sing. verb.] "An honorable amends." Addison.Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends. Shak.
angularity: The quality or state of being angular; angularness.
atoll: A coral island or islands, consisting of a belt of coral reef,partly submerged, surrounding a central lagoon or depression; alagoon island.
ablactation: The process of grafting now called inarching, or grafting byapproach.
africanism: A word, phrase, idiom, or custom peculiar to Africa orAfricans. "The knotty Africanisms . . . of the fathers." Milton.
apace: With a quick pace; quick; fast; speedily.His dewy locks did drop with brine apace. Spenser.A visible triumph of the gospel drawapace. I. Taylor.
adjunction: The act of joining; the thing joined or added.
affinal: Related by marriage; from the same source.
antecedency: The state or condition of being antecedent; priority.Fothherby.
athwart: Across the direction or course of; as, a fleet standing athwartour course. Athwart hawse, across the stem of another vessel, whetherin contact or at a small distance.-- Athwart ships, across the ship from side to side, or in thatdirection; -- opposed to fore and aft.
azotometer: An apparatus for measuring or determining the proportion ofnitrogen; a nitrometer.
acardiac: Without a heart; as, an acardiac fetus.
alphabetarian: A learner of the alphabet; an abecedarian. Abp. Sancroft.
apollinarian: In honor of Apollo; as, the Apollinarian games.
archaeostomatous: Applied to a gastrula when the blastorope does not entirely up.
aptychus: A shelly plate found in the terminal chambers of ammoniteshells. Some authors consider them to be jaws; others, opercula.
american protective association: A secret organization in the United States, formed in Iowa in1887, ostensibly for the protection of American institutions bykeeping Roman Catholics out of public office. Abbrev. commonly to A.P .A.
astronomical: Of or pertaining to astronomy; in accordance with the methodsor principles of astronomy.-- As`tro*nom"ic*al*ly, adv. Astronomical clock. See under Clock.-- Astronomical day. See under Day.-- Astronomical fractions, Astronomical numbers. See underSexagesimal.
angerly: Angrily. [Obs. or Poetic]Why, how now, Hecate! you look angerly. Shak.
abolition: The act of abolishing, or the state of being abolished; anannulling; abrogation; utter destruction; as, the abolition ofslavery or the slave trade; the abolition of laws, decrees,ordinances, customs, taxes, debts, etc.
artfully: In an artful manner; with art or cunning; skillfully;dexterously; craftily.
amphigen: An element that in combination produces amphid salt; -- appliedby Berzelius to oxygen, sulphur, selenium, and tellurium. [R.]
agenesis: Any imperfect development of the body, or any anomaly oforganization.
arm: To provide one's self with arms, weapons, or means of attack orresistance; to take arms. " 'Tis time to arm." Shak.
ante-: A Latin preposition and prefix; akin to Gr. anti, Goth. and-,anda- (only in comp.), AS. and-, ond-, (only in comp.: cf. Answer,Along), G. ant-, ent- (in comp.). The Latin ante is generally used inthe sense of before, in regard to position, order, or time, and theGr. opposite, or in the place of.
acosmism: A denial of the existence of the universe as distinct from God.
areca: A genus of palms, one species of which produces the areca nut,or betel nut, which is chewed in India with the leaf of the PiperBetle and lime.
aurora: The Roman personification of the dawn of day; the goddess ofthe morning. The poets represented her a rising out of the ocean, ina chariot, with rosy fingers dropping gentle dew.
autoclave: A kind of French stewpan with a steamtight lid. Knight.
assessorship: The office or function of an assessor.
araneiform: Having the form of a spider. Kirby.
antimonic: Pertaining to, or derived from, antimony; -- said of thosecompounds of antimony in which this element has its highestequivalence; as, antimonic acid.
antacrid: Corrective of acrimony of the humors.
arride: To please; to gratify. [Archaic] B. Jonson.Above all thy rarities, old Oxenford, what do most arride and solaceme are thy repositories of moldering learning. Lamb.
assecure: To make sure or safe; to assure. [Obs.] Hooker.
asphaltic: Pertaining to, of the nature of, or containing, asphalt;bituminous. "Asphaltic pool." "Asphaltic slime." Milton.
arreption: The act of taking away. [Obs.] "This arreption was sudden." Bp.Hall.
aggroupment: Arrangement in a group or in groups; grouping.
anthodium: The inflorescence of a compound flower in which many floretsare gathered into a involucrate head.
aldebaran: A red star of the first magnitude, situated in the eye ofTaurus; the Bull's Eye. It is the bright star in the group called theHyades.Now when Aldebaran was mounted high Above the shiny Cassiopeia'schair. Spenser.
antiguggler: A crooked tube of metal, to be introduced into the neck of abottle for drawing out the liquid without disturbing the sediment orcausing a gurgling noise.
allyl: An organic radical, C3H5, existing especially in oils of garlicand mustard.
analogically: In an analogical sense; in accordance with analogy; by way ofsimilitude.A prince is analogically styled a pilot, being to the state as apilot is to the vessel. Berkeley.
arctisca: A group of Arachnida. See Illust. in Appendix.
abigail: A lady's waiting-maid. Pepys.Her abigail reported that Mrs. Gutheridge had a set of night curlsfor sleeping in. Leslie.
archival: Pertaining to, or contained in, archives or records. Tooke.
archership: The art or skill of an archer.
aurited: Having lobes like the ear; auriculate.
asbestine: Of or pertaining to asbestus, or partaking of its nature;incombustible; asbestic.
adonis: A youth beloved by Venus for his beauty. He was killed in thechase by a wild boar.
ammonal: An explosive consisting of a mixture of powdered aluminium andnitrate of ammonium.
authorial: Of or pertaining to an author. "The authorial Hare.
air bed: A sack or matters inflated with air, and used as a bed.
activity: The state or quality of being active; nimbleness; agility;vigorous action or operation; energy; active force; as, an increasingvariety of human activities. "The activity of toil." Palfrey.
atomically: In an atomic manner; in accordance with the atomic philosophy.
adopter: A receiver, with two necks, opposite to each other, one ofwhich admits the neck of a retort, and the other is joined to anotherreceiver. It is used in distillations, to give more space to elasticvapors, to increase the length of the neck of a retort, or to unitetwo vessels whose openings have different diameters. [Written alsoadapter.]
after: To ward the stern of the ship; -- applied to any object in therear part of a vessel; as the after cabin, after hatchway.
aforesaid: Said before, or in a preceding part; already described oridentified.
amotus: Elevated, -- as a toe, when raised so high that the tip doesnot touch the ground.
adversative: Expressing contrariety, opposition, or antithesis; as, anadversative conjunction (but, however, yet, etc. ); an adversativeforce.-- Ad*ver"sa*tive*ly, adv.
assurance: Any written or other legal evidence of the conveyance ofproperty; a conveyance; a deed.
avoke: To call from or back again. [Obs.] Bp. Burnet.
absist: To stand apart from; top leave off; to desist. [Obs.] Raleigh.
asper: Rough; rugged; harsh; bitter; stern; fierce. [Archaic] "Anasper sound." Bacon.
auto-intoxication: Poisoning, or the state of being poisoned, from toxicsubstances produced within the body; autotoxæmia.
awhile: For a while; for some time; for a short time.
acquaintedness: State of being acquainted; degree of acquaintance. [R.] Boyle.
adduct: To draw towards a common center or a middle line. Huxley.
antagonism: Opposition of action; counteraction or contrariety of things orprinciples.
appraisement: The act of setting the value; valuation by an appraiser;estimation of worth.
axial: Belonging to the axis of the body; as, the axial skeleton; orto the axis of any appendage or organ; as, the axial bones. Axialline (Magnetism), the line taken by the magnetic force in passingfrom one pole of a horseshoe magnet to the other. Faraday.
assure: To insure; to covenant to indemnify for loss, or to pay aspecified sum at death. See Insure.
apparentness: Plainness to the eye or the mind; visibleness; obviousness.[R.] Sherwood.
assuring: That assures; tending to assure; giving confidence.-- As*sur"ing*ly, adv.
aneurism: A soft, pulsating, hollow tumor, containing blood, arising fromthe preternatural dilation or rupture of the coats of an artery.[Written also aneurysm.]
apieces: In pieces or to pieces. [Obs.] "Being torn apieces." Shak.
adductive: Adducing, or bringing towards or to something.
a posteriori: Characterizing that kind of reasoning which derivespropositions from the observation of facts, or by generalizationsfrom facts arrives at principles and definitions, or infers causesfrom effects. This is the reverse of a priori reasoning.
anthotaxy: The arrangement of flowers in a cluster; the science of therelative position of flowers; inflorescence.
artlessness: The quality of being artless, or void of art or guile;simplicity; sincerity.
alongside: Along or by the side; side by side with; -- often with of; as,bring the boat alongside; alongside of him; alongside of the tree.
astragalus: The ankle bone, or hock bone; the bone of the tarsus whicharticulates with the tibia at the ankle.
antecedaneous: Antecedent; preceding in time. "Capable of antecedaneousproof." Barrow.
arrose: To drench; to besprinkle; to moisten. [Obs.]The blissful dew of heaven does arrose you. Two N. Kins.
ancony: A piece of malleable iron, wrought into the shape of a bar inthe middle, but unwrought at the ends.
ay: Ah! alas! "Ay me! I fondly dream `Had ye been there.'" Milton.
accommodable: That may be accommodated, fitted, or made to agree. [R.] I.Watts.
anchovy: A small fish, about three inches in length, of the Herringfamily (Engraulis encrasicholus), caught in vast numbers in theMediterranean, and pickled for exportation. The name is also appliedto several allied species.
accipitral: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a falcon or hawk; hawklike.Lowell.
analysis: The separation of a compound substance, by chemical processes,into its constituents, with a view to ascertain either (a) whatelements it contains, or (b) how much of each element is present. Theformer is called qualitative, and the latter quantitative analysis.
acetamide: A white crystalline solid, from ammonia by replacement of anequivalent of hydrogen by acetyl.
admission: Acquiescence or concurrence in a statement made by another, anddistinguishable from a confession in that an admission presupposesprior inquiry by another, but a confession may be made without suchinquiry.
arms: Anything which a man takes in his hand in anger, to strike orassault another with; an aggressive weapon. Cowell. Blackstone.
albata: A white metallic alloy; which is made into spoons, forks,teapots, etc. British plate or German silver. See German silver,under German.
aviary: A house, inclosure, large cage, or other place, for keepingbirds confined; a bird house.Lincolnshire may be termed the aviary of England. Fuller.
avestan: Of or pertaining to the Avesta or the language of the Avesta. --n.
ash: A genus of trees of the Olive family, having opposite pinnateleaves, many of the species furnishing valuable timber, as theEuropean ash (Fraxinus excelsior) and the white ash (F. Americana).Prickly ash (Zanthoxylum Americanum) and Poison ash (Rhus venenata)are shrubs of different families, somewhat resembling the true ashesin their foliage.-- Mountain ash. See Roman tree, and under Mountain.
accordantly: In accordance or agreement; agreeably; conformably; -- followedby with or to.
acyl: An acid radical, as acetyl, malonyl, or benzoyl.
allopathically: In a manner conformable to allopathy; by allopathic methods.
acidific: Producing acidity; converting into an acid. Dana.
accentual: Of or pertaining to accent; characterized or formed by accent.
antinomy: A contradiction or incompatibility of thought or language; --in the Kantian philosophy, such a contradiction as arises from theattempt to apply to the ideas of the reason, relations or attributeswhich are appropriate only to the facts or the concepts ofexperience.
ancestral: Of, pertaining to, derived from, or possessed by, an ancestoror ancestors; as, an ancestral estate. "Ancestral trees." Hemans.
applause: The act of applauding; approbation and praise publiclyexpressed by clapping the hands, stamping or tapping with the feet,acclamation, huzzas, or other means; marked commendation.The brave man seeks not popular applause. Dryden.
abdominalia: A group of cirripeds having abdominal appendages.
aerobiotic: Related to, or of the nature of, aërobies; as, aërobioticplants, which live only when supplied with free oxygen.
adversaria: A miscellaneous collection of notes, remarks, or selections; acommonplace book; also, commentaries or notes.These parchments are supposed to have been St. Paul's adversaria. Bp.Bull.
armpit: The hollow beneath the junction of the arm and shoulder; theaxilla.
animadversal: The faculty of perceiving; a percipient. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
absurd: Contrary to reason or propriety; obviously and fiatly opposedto manifest truth; inconsistent with the plain dictates of commonsense; logically contradictory; nonsensical; ridiculous; as, anabsurd person, an absurd opinion; an absurd dream.This proffer is absurd and reasonless. Shak.'This phrase absurd to call a villain great. Pope.p. 9
ajutage: A tube through which is water is discharged; an efflux tube;as, the ajutage of a fountain.
adept: One fully skilled or well versed in anything; a proficient; as,adepts in philosophy.
authotype: A type or block containing a facsimile of an autograph. Knight.
aniline: An organic base belonging to the phenylamines. It may beregarded as ammonia in which one hydrogen atom has been replaced bythe radical phenyl. It is a colorless, oily liquid, originallyobtained from indigo by distillation, but now largely manufacturedfrom coal tar or nitrobenzene as a base from which many brilliantdyes are made.
after-note: One of the small notes occur on the unaccented parts of themeasure, taking their time from the preceding note.
anagoge: Mystical; having a secondary spiritual meaning; as, the rest ofthe Sabbath, in an anagogical sense, signifies the repose of thesaints in heaven; an anagogical explication.-- An`a*gog"ic*al*ly, adv.
amphiarthrosis: A form of articulation in which the bones are connected byintervening substance admitting slight motion; symphysis.
asterisk: The figure of a star, thus,
acorn cup: The involucre or cup in which the acorn is fixed.
appellatory: Containing an appeal.An appellatory libel ought to contain the name of the partyappellant. Ayliffe.
arborescence: The state of being arborescent; the resemblance to a tree inminerals, or crystallizations, or groups of crystals in that form;as, the arborescence produced by precipitating silver.
abracadabra: A mystical word or collocation of letters written as in thefigure. Worn on an amulet it was supposed to ward off fever. Atpresent the word is used chiefly in jest to denote something withoutmeaning; jargon.
angora: A city of Asia Minor (or Anatolia) which has given its name toa goat, a cat, etc. Angora cat (Zoöl.), a variety of the domestic catwith very long and silky hair, generally of the brownish white color.Called also Angola cat. See Cat.-- Angora goat (Zoöl.), a variety of the domestic goat, reared forits long silky hair, which is highly prized for manufacture.
allness: Totality; completeness. [R.]The allness of God, including his absolute spirituality, supremacy,and eternity. R. Turnbull.
antiquation: The act of making antiquated, or the state of being antiquated.Beaumont.
anticlinal: The crest or line in which strata slope or dip in oppositedirections.
alliciency: Attractive power; attractiveness. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
amove: To dismiss from an office or station.
ambilevous: Left-handed on both sides; clumsy; -- opposed to ambidexter.[R.] Sir T. Browne.
actinograph: An instrument for measuring and recording the variations in theactinic or chemical force of rays of light. Nichol.
atechnic: Without technical or artistic knowledge.Difficult to convey to the atechnic reader. Etching & Engr.
aggeration: A heaping up; accumulation; as, aggerations of sand. [R.]
acclamation: A representation, in sculpture or on medals, of peopleexpressing joy. Acclamation medals are those on which laudatoryacclamations are recorded. Elmes.
amphictyons: Deputies from the confederated states of ancient Greece to acongress or council. They considered both political and religiousmatters.
airsick: Affected with aërial sickness. -- Air"sick`ness, n.
apish: Having the qualities of an ape; prone to imitate in a servilemanner. Hence: Apelike; fantastically silly; foppish; affected;trifling.The apish gallantry of a fantastic boy. Sir W. Scott.
autobiographer: One who writers his own life or biography.
allodium: Freehold estate; land which is the absolute property of theowner; real estate held in absolute independence, without beingsubject to any rent, service, or acknowledgment to a superior. It isthus opposed to feud. Blackstone. Bouvier.
assimilation: The conversion of nutriment into the fluid or solid substanceof the body, by the processes of digestion and absorption, whether inplants or animals.Not conversing the body, not repairing it by assimilation, butpreserving it by ventilation. Sir T. Browne.
acosmist: One who denies the existence of the universe, or of a universeas distinct from God. G. H. Lewes.
alkalimetry: The art or process of ascertaining the strength of alkalies, orthe quantity present in alkaline mixtures.
apathist: One who is destitute of feeling.
amasthenic: Uniting the chemical rays of light into one focus, as a certainkind of lens; amacratic.
altruism: Regard for others, both natural and moral; devotion to theinterests of others; brotherly kindness; -- opposed to egoism orselfishness. [Recent] J. S. Mill.
amercement: The infliction of a penalty at the discretion of the court;also, a mulct or penalty thus imposed. It differs from a fine,in thatthe latter is, or was originally, a fixed and certain sum prescribedby statue for an offense; but an amercement is arbitrary. Hence, theact or practice of affeering. [See Affeer.] Blackstone.
anywhither: To or towards any place. [Archaic] De Foe.
ablative: Applied to one of the cases of the noun in Latin and some otherlanguages, -- the fundamental meaning of the case being removal,separation, or taking away.
arsenical: Of or pertaining to, or containing, arsenic; as, arsenicalvapor; arsenical wall papers. Arsenical silver, an ore of silvercontaining arsenic.
altimeter: An instrument for taking altitudes, as a quadrant, sextant,etc. Knight.
alcaldia: The jurisdiction or office of an alcalde; also, the building orchamber in which he conducts the business of his office.
anchusin: A resinoid coloring matter obtained from alkanet root.
aplacophora: A division of Amphineura in which the body is naked or coveredwith slender spines or setæ, but is without shelly plates.
augurate: To make or take auguries; to augur; to predict. [Obs.] C.Middleton.
accommodableness: The quality or condition of being accommodable. [R.] Todd.
aruspex: One of the class of diviners among the Etruscans and Romans,who foretold events by the inspection of the entrails of victimsoffered on the altars of the gods.
amphineura: A division of Mollusca remarkable for the bilateral symmetry ofthe organs and the arrangement of the nerves.
abib: The first month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year,corresponding nearly to our April. After the Babylonish captivitythis month was called Nisan. Kitto.
adelaster: A provisional name for a plant which has not had its flowersbotanically examined, and therefore has not been referred to itsproper genus.
agedly: In the manner of an aged person.
appertainment: That which appertains to a person; an appurtenance. [Obs. orR.] Shak.
astray: Out of the right, either in a literal or in a figurative sense;wandering; as, to lead one astray.Ye were as sheep going astray. 1 Pet. ii. 25.
antispast: A foot of four syllables, the first and fourth short, and thesecond and third long.
anaerobiotic: Related to, or of the nature of, anaërobies.
atomize: To reduce to atoms, or to fine spray.The liquids in the form of spray are said to be pulverized,nebulized, or atomized. Dunglison.
albumose: A compound or class of compounds formed from albumin by diluteacids or by an acid solution of pepsin. Used also in combination, asantialbumose, hemialbumose.
antestomach: A cavity which leads into the stomach, as in birds. Ray.
accensor: One of the functionaries who light and trim the tapers.
acidimeter: An instrument for ascertaining the strength of acids. Ure.
acidulous: Slightly sour; sub-acid; sourish; as, an acidulous tincture. E.Burke. Acidulous mineral waters, such as contain carbonic anhydride.
alburn: The bleak, a small European fish having scales of a peculiarlysilvery color which are used in making artificial pearls.
anastomose: To inosculate; to intercommunicate by anastomosis, as thearteries and veins.The ribbing of the leaf, and the anastomosing network of its vessels.I. Taylor.
ablatitious: Diminishing; as, an ablatitious force. Sir J. Herschel.
adorn: To deck or dress with ornaments; to embellish; to set off toadvantage; to render pleasing or attractive.As a bride adorneth herself with her jewels. Isa. lxi. 10.At church, with meek and unaffected grace, His looks adorned thevenerable place. Goldsmith.
astructive: Building up; constructive; -- opposed to destructive. [Obs.]
aforehand: Beforehand; in anticipation. [Archaic or Dial.]She is come aforehand to anoint my body. Mark xiv. 8.
appreciative: Having or showing a just or ready appreciation or perception;as, an appreciative audience.-- Ap*pre"ci*a*tive*ly, adv.
asexual: Having no distinct; without sexual action; as, asexualreproduction. See Fission and Gemmation.
amateurism: The practice, habit, or work of an amateur.
autopathic: Dependent upon, or due or relating to, the structure andcharacteristics of the diseased organism; endopathic; as, anautopathic disease; an autopathic theory of diseases.
antiquarianism: Character of an antiquary; study or love of antiquities.Warburton.
abnegator: One who abnegates, denies, or rejects anything. [R.]
alkarsin: A spontaneously inflammable liquid, having a repulsive odor,and consisting of cacodyl and its oxidation products; -- called alsoCadel's fuming liquid.
albert ware: A soft ornamental terra-cotta pottery, sold in the biscuitstate for decorating.
adjunctive: Joining; having the quality of joining; forming an adjunct.
atropine: A poisonous, white, crystallizable alkaloid, extracted from theAtropa belladonna, or deadly nightshade, and the Datura Stramonium,or thorn apple. It is remarkable for its power in dilating the pupilof the eye. Called also daturine.
anopheles: A genus of mosquitoes which are secondary hosts of the malariaparasites, and whose bite is the usual, if not the only, means ofinfecting human beings with malaria. Several species are found in theUnited States. They may be distinguished from the ordinary mosquitoesof the genus Culex by the long slender palpi, nearly equaling thebeak in length, while those of the female Culex are very short. Theyalso assume different positions when resting, Culex usually holdingthe body parallel to the surface on which it rests and keeping thehead and beak bent at an angle, while Anopheles holds the body at anangle with the surface and the head and beak in line with it. Unlessthey become themselves infected by previously biting a subjectaffected with malaria, the insects cannot transmit the disease.
albicore: A name applied to several large fishes of the Mackerel family,esp. Orcynus alalonga. One species (Orcynus thynnus), common in theMediterranean and Atlantic, is called in New England the horsemackerel; the tunny. [Written also albacore.]
atomy: An atom; a mite; a pigmy.
apertion: The act of opening; an opening; an aperture. [Archaic] Wiseman.
amphigenous: Increasing in size by growth on all sides, as the lichens.
anthophyllite: A mineral of the hornblende group, of a yellowish gray or clovebrown color.-- An`tho*phyl*lit"ic, a.
aphid: One of the genus Aphis; an aphidian.
antipyrine: An artificial alkaloid, believed to be efficient in abatingfever.
athenian: Of or pertaining to Athens, the metropolis of Greece.-- n. A native or citizen of Athens.
abdicate: To disclaim and expel from the family, as a father his child;to disown; to disinherit.
alburnum: The white and softer part of wood, between the inner bark andthe hard wood or duramen; sapwood.
ametropia: Any abnormal condition of the refracting powers of the eye.-- Am`e*trop"ic, a.
absentee: One who absents himself from his country, office, post, orduty; especially, a landholder who lives in another country ordistrict than that where his estate is situated; as, an Irishabsentee. Macaulay.
attemperation: The act of attempering or regulating. [Archaic] Bacon.
apartment house: A building comprising a number of suites designed for separatehousekeeping tenements, but having conveniences, such as heat, light,elevator service, etc., furnished in common; -- often distinguishedin the United States from a flat house.
aryanize: To make Aryan (a language, or in language). K. Johnston.
amphibrach: A foot of three syllables, the middle one long, the first andlast short (as, h. In modern prosody the accented syllable takes theplace of the long and the unaccented of the short; as, pro-phet''ic.
apheresis: The dropping of a letter or syllable from the beginning of aword; e. g., cute for acute.
accountantship: The office or employment of an accountant.
argean: Pertaining to the ship Argo. See Argo.
ashore: On shore or on land; on the land adjacent to water; to theshore; to the land; aground (when applied to a ship); -- sometimesopposed to aboard or afloat.Here shall I die ashore. Shak.I must fetch his necessaries ashore. Shak.
acquiescency: The quality of being acquiescent; acquiescence.
analogist: One who reasons from analogy, or represent, by analogy. Cheyne.
antisacerdotal: Hostile to priests or the priesthood. Waterland.
ancome: A small ulcerous swelling, coming suddenly; also, a whitlow.[Obs.] Boucher.
aspection: The act of viewing; a look. [Obs.]
alem: The imperial standard of the Turkish Empire.
ambassadorship: The state, office, or functions of an ambassador.
assizer: An officer who has the care or inspection of weights andmeasures, etc.
aperture: The diameter of the exposed part of the object glass of atelescope or other optical instrument; as, a telescope of four-inchaperture.
avow: To acknowledge and justify, as an act done. See Avowry.Blackstone.
awarder: One who awards, or assigns by sentence or judicialdetermination; a judge.
abirritation: A pathological condition opposite to that of irritation;debility; want of strength; asthenia.
augustness: The quality of being august; dignity of mien; grandeur;magnificence.
ablution: A small quantity of wine and water, which is used to wash thepriest's thumb and index finger after the communion, and which then,as perhaps containing portions of the consecrated elements, is drunkby the priest.
ambigu: An entertainment at which a medley of dishes is set on at thesame time.
air bladder: An air sac, sometimes double or variously lobed, in thevisceral cavity of many fishes. It originates in the same way as thelungs of air-breathing vertebrates, and in the adult may retain atubular connection with the pharynx or esophagus.
argol: Crude tartar; an acidulous salt from which cream of tartar isprepared. It exists in the juice of grapes, and is deposited fromwines on the sides of the casks. Ure.
annuloida: A division of the Articulata, including the annelids and alliedgroups; sometimes made to include also the helminths and echinoderms.[Written also Annuloidea.]
advocatory: Of or pertaining to an advocate. [R.]
austromancy: Soothsaying, or prediction of events, from observation of thewinds.
anabasis: The first period, or increase, of a disease; augmentation.[Obs.]
accentually: In an accentual manner; in accordance with accent.
auspicial: Of or pertaining to auspices; auspicious. [R.]
auld lang syne: A Scottish phrase used in recalling recollections of times longsince past. "The days of auld lang syne."
appositional: Pertaining to apposition; put in apposition syntactically.Ellicott.
acclivity: A slope or inclination of the earth, as the side of a hill,considered as ascending, in opposition to declivity, or descending;an upward slope; ascent.
alway: Always. [Archaic or Poetic]I would not live alway. Job vii. 16.
aeromechanic: A mechanic or mechanician expert in the art and practice ofaëronautics.
anabolism: The constructive metabolism of the body, as distinguished fromkatabolism.
alouatte: One of the several species of howling monkeys of South America.See Howler, 2.
aladinist: One of a sect of freethinkers among the Mohammedans.
archeus: The vital principle or force which (according to theParacelsians) presides over the growth and continuation of livingbeings; the anima mundi or plastic power of the old philosophers.[Obs.] Johnson.
academicals: The articles of dress prescribed and worn at some colleges anduniversities.
arbitress: A female arbiter; an arbitratrix. Milton.
atmologist: One who is versed in atmology.
argonauta: A genus of Cephalopoda. The shell is called paper nautilus orpaper sailor.
amioidei: An order of ganoid fishes of which Amis is type. See Bowfin andGanoidei.
ataman: A hetman, or chief of the Cossacks.
ascendant: The horoscope, or that degree of the ecliptic which rises abovethe horizon at the moment of one's birth; supposed to have acommanding influence on a person's life and fortune.
anthropomorphology: The application to God of terms descriptive of human beings.
accent: Stress laid on certain syllables of a verse.
amniotic: Of or pertaining to the amnion; characterized by an amnion; as,the amniotic fluid; the amniotic sac. Amniotic acid. (Chem.) [R.] SeeAllantoin.
abovedeck: On deck; and hence, like aboveboard, without artifice. Smart.
abrogative: Tending or designed to abrogate; as, an abrogative law.
aquarium: An artificial pond, or a globe or tank (usually with glasssides), in which living specimens of aquatic animals or plants arekept.
apocodeine: An alkaloid, , prepared from codeine. In its effects itresembles apomorphine.
agonist: One who contends for the prize in public games. [R.]
air stove: A stove for heating a current of air which is directed againstits surface by means of pipes, and then distributed through abuilding.
apollyon: The Destroyer; -- a name used (Rev. ix. 11) for the angel ofthe bottomless pit, answering to the Hebrew Abaddon.
afeard: Afraid. [Obs.]Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises. Shak.
abolitionism: The principles or measures of abolitionists. Wilberforce.
absorption: An imbibing or reception by molecular or chemical action; as,the absorption of light, heat, electricity, etc.
apothegmatist: A collector or maker of apothegms. Pope.
autotropism: The tendency of plant organs to grow in a straight line whenuninfluenced by external stimuli.
alloxantin: A substance produced by acting upon uric with warm and verydilute nitric acid.
alderney: One of a breed of cattle raised in Alderney, one of the ChannelIslands. Alderneys are of a dun or tawny color and are often calledJersey cattle. See Jersey, 3.
anhima: A South American aquatic bird; the horned screamer or kamichi(Palamedea cornuta). See Kamichi.
acrodactylum: The upper surface of the toes, individually.
acceptably: In an acceptable manner; in a manner to please or givesatisfaction.
autoclastic: Broken in place; -- said of rocks having a broken or brecciatedstructure due to crushing, in contrast to those of brecciatedmaterials brought from a distance.
arietation: A short aria, or air. "A military ariette." Sir W. Scott.
albigensian: Of or pertaining to the Albigenses.
asperne: To spurn; to despise. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
armature: A piece of soft iron used to connect the two poles of a magnet,or electro-magnet, in order to complete the circuit, or to receiveand apply the magnetic force. In the ordinary horseshoe magnet, itserves to prevent the dissipation of the magnetic force.
adiaphorist: One of the German Protestants who, with Melanchthon, held someopinions and ceremonies to be indifferent or nonessential, whichLuther condemned as sinful or heretical. Murdock.
ablegation: The act of sending abroad. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
artemisia: A genus of plants including the plants called mugwort,southernwood, and wormwood. Of these A. absinthium, or commonwormwood, is well known, and A. tridentata is the sage brush of theRocky Mountain region.
analogize: To employ, or reason by, analogy.
amit: To lose. [Obs.]A lodestone fired doth presently amit its proper virtue. Sir T.Browne.
abscess: A collection of pus or purulent matter in any tissue or organof the body, the result of a morbid process. Cold abscess, an abscessof slow formation, unattended with the pain and heat characteristicof ordinary abscesses, and lasting for years without exhibiting anytendency towards healing; a chronic abscess.
amende: A pecuniary punishment or fine; a reparation or recantation.Amende honorable(#). (Old French Law) A species of infamouspunishment in which the offender, being led into court with a ropeabout his neck, and a lighted torch in his hand, begged pardon of hisGod, the court, etc. In popular language, the phrase now denotes apublic apology or recantation, and reparation to an injured party,for improper language or treatment.
accoucheur: A man who assists women in childbirth; a man midwife; anobstetrician.
anthropologist: One who is versed in anthropology.
attendment: An attendant circumstance. [Obs.]The uncomfortable attendments of hell. Sir T. Browne.
adroit: Dexterous in the use of the hands or in the exercise of themental faculties; exhibiting skill and readiness in avoiding dangeror escaping difficulty; ready in invention or execution; -- appliedto persons and to acts; as, an adroit mechanic, an adroit reply."Adroit in the application of the telescope and quadrant." Horsley."He was adroit in intrigue." Macaulay.
acatalepsy: Incomprehensibility of things; the doctrine held by the ancientSkeptic philosophers, that human knowledge never amounts tocertainty, but only to probability.
anisostemonous: Having unequal stamens; having stamens different in number fromthe petals.
agnosticism: That doctrine which, professing ignorance, neither asserts nordenies. Specifically: (Theol.)
along: By the length of, as distinguished from across. "Along thelowly lands." Dryden.The kine . . . went along the highway. 1 Sam. vi. 12.
abortional: Pertaining to abortion; miscarrying; abortive. Carlyle.
alloo: To incite dogs by a call; to halloo. [Obs.]
alimentally: So as to serve for nourishment or food; nourishing quality. SirT. Browne.
anaplerotic: Filling up; promoting granulation of wounds or ulcers.-- n.
anhydrite: A mineral of a white a slightly bluish color, usually massive.It is anhydrous sulphate of lime, and differs from gypsum in notcontaining water (whence the name).
arthrostraca: One of the larger divisions of Crustacea, so called because thethorax and abdomen are both segmented; Tetradecapoda. It includes theAmphipoda and Isopoda.
avener: An officer of the king's stables whose duty it was to provideoats for the horses. [Obs.]
acidic: Containing a high percentage of silica; -- opposed to basic. anacidic solution.
alkali soil: Any one of various soils found in arid and semiarid regions,containing an unusual amount of soluble mineral salts whicheffloresce in the form of a powder or crust (usually white) in dryweather following rains or irrigation. The basis of these salts ismainly soda with a smaller amount of potash, and usually a littlelime and  magnesia. Two main classes of alkali are commonlydistinguished: black alkali, which may be any alkaline carbonate, butwhich practically consists of sodium carbonate (sal soda), which ishighly corrosive and destructive to vegetation; and white alkali,characterized by the presence of sodium sulphate (Glauber's salt),which is less injurious to vegetation. Black alkali is so calledbecause water containing it dissolves humus, forming a dark-coloredsolution which, when it collects in puddles and evaporates, producescharacteristic black spots.
agnation: Consanguinity by a line of males only, as distinguished fromcognation. Bouvier.
actinal: Pertaining to the part of a radiate animal which contains themouth. L. Agassiz.
amorphozoa: Animals without a mouth or regular internal organs, as thesponges.
arsenite: A salt formed by the union of arsenious acid with a base.
assay: The act or process of ascertaining the proportion of aparticular metal in an ore or alloy; especially, the determination ofthe proportion of gold or silver in bullion or coin.
adulator: A servile or hypocritical flatterer. Carlyle.
aesculapius: The god of medicine. Hence, a physician.
assuredness: The state of being assured; certainty; full confidence.
air cell: A cavity in the cellular tissue of plants, containing air only.
anythingarian: One who holds to no particular creed or dogma.
acromegaly: Chronic enlargement of the extremities and face.
ashtoreth: The principal female divinity of the Phoenicians, as Baal wasthe principal male divinity. W. Smith.
achromic: Free from color; colorless; as, in Physiol. Chem., the achromicpoint of a starch solution acted upon by an amylolytic enzyme is thepoint at which it fails to give any color with iodine.
apocryphalness: The quality or state of being apocryphal; doubtfulness ofcredit or genuineness.
antiquary: Pertaining to antiquity. [R.] "Instructed by the antiquarytimes." Shak.
adoptive: Pertaining to adoption; made or acquired by adoption; fitted toadopt; as, an adoptive father, an child; an adoptive language.-- A*dopt"ive*ly, adv.
alquifou: A lead ore found in Cornwall, England, and used by potters togive a green glaze to their wares; potter's ore.
airwoman: A woman who ascends or flies in an aircraft.
allow: To admit; to concede; to make allowance or abatement.Allowing still for the different ways of making it. Addison.To allow of, to permit; to admit. Shak.
auto-: A combining form, with the meaning of self, one's self, one'sown, itself, its own.
acinaceous: Containing seeds or stones of grapes, or grains like them.
aryan: Of or pertaining to the people called Aryans; Indo-European;Indo-Germanic; as, the Aryan stock, the Aryan languages.
arianize: To admit or accept the tenets of the Arians; to become anArian.
alienee: One to whom the title of property is transferred; -- opposed toalienor.It the alienee enters and keeps possession. Blackstone.
anemographic: Produced by an anemograph; of or pertaining to anemography.
appreciatingly: In an appreciating manner; with appreciation.
awaken: To rouse from sleep or torpor; to awake; to wake.[He] is dispatched Already to awaken whom thou nam'st. Cowper.Their consciences are thoroughly awakened. Tillotson.
are: The present indicative plural of the substantive verb to be;but etymologically a different word from be, or was. Am, art, are,and is, all come from the root as.
accomplishable: Capable of being accomplished; practicable. Carlyle.
aberr: To wander; to stray. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
admarginate: To write in the margin. [R.] Coleridge.
antitheist: A disbeliever in the existence of God.
adipoceriform: Having the form or appearance of adipocere; as, anadipoceriform tumor.
abut: To project; to terminate or border; to be contiguous; to meet;-- with on, upon, or against; as, his land abuts on the road.
arthen: Same as Earthen. [Obs.] "An arthen pot." Holland.
appositive: Of or relating to apposition; in apposition.-- n.
apheliotropic: Turning away from the sun; -- said of leaves, etc. Darwin.
anacoenosis: A figure by which a speaker appeals to his hearers or opponentsfor their opinion on the point in debate. Walker.
alate: Lately; of late. [Archaic]There hath been alate such tales spread abroad. Latimer.
amygdalic: Of or pertaining to almonds; derived from amygdalin; as,amygdalic acid.
antilopine: Of or relating to the antelope.
adenography: That part of anatomy which describes the glands.
affuse: To pour out or upon. [R.]I first affused water upon the compressed beans. Boyle.
adventuress: A female adventurer; a woman who tries to gain position byequivocal means.
agog: In eager desire; eager; astir.All agog to dash through thick and thin. Cowper.
algid: Cold; chilly. Bailey. Algid cholera (Med.), Asiatic cholera.
after damp: An irrespirable gas, remaining after an explosion of fire dampin mines; choke damp. See Carbonic acid.
antacid: A remedy for acidity of the stomach, as an alkali or absorbent.-- a.
astute: Critically discerning; sagacious; shrewd; subtle; crafty.
ash wednesday: The first day of Lent; -- so called from a custom in the RomanCatholic church of putting ashes, on that day, upon the foreheads ofpenitents.
acutorsion: The twisting of an artery with a needle to arrest hemorrhage.
azured: Of an azure color; sky-blue. "The azured harebell." Shak.
arrant: Notoriously or preëminently bad; thorough or downright, in abad sense; shameless; unmitigated; as, an arrant rogue or coward.I discover an arrant laziness in my soul. Fuller.
albolith: A kind of plastic cement, or artificial stone, consistingchiefly of magnesia and silica; -- called also albolite.
admonitory: That conveys admonition; warning or reproving; as, anadmonitory glance.-- Ad*mon"i*to*ri*ly,, adv.
alumina: One of the earths, consisting of two parts of aluminium andthree of oxygen, Al2O3.
anvil: the incus. See Incus. To be on the anvil, to be in a state ofdiscussion, formation, or preparation, as when a scheme or measure isforming, but not matured. Swift.
amidogen: A compound radical, NH2, not yet obtained in a separate state,which may be regarded as ammonia from the molecule of which one ofits hydrogen atoms has been removed; -- called also the amido group,and in composition represented by the form amido.
alecithal: Applied to those ova which segment uniformly, and which havelittle or no food yelk embedded in their protoplasm. Balfour.
apothecary: One who prepares and sells drugs or compounds for medicinalpurposes.
anisol: Methyl phenyl ether, C6H5OCH3, got by distilling anisic acid orby the action of methide on potassium phenolate.
acrotarsium: The instep or front of the tarsus.
advoke: To summon; to call. [Obs.]Queen Katharine had privately prevailed with the pope to advoke thecause to Rome. Fuller.
affix: That which is affixed; an appendage; esp. one or more lettersor syllables added at the end of a word; a suffix; a postfix.
aerometry: The science of measuring the air, including the doctrine of itspressure, elasticity, rarefaction, and condensation; pneumatics.
appromt: To quicken; to prompt. [Obs.]To appromt our invention. Bacon.
angustation: The act or making narrow; a straitening or contacting. Wiseman.
ascertainable: That may be ascertained.-- As`cer*tain"a*ble*ness, n.-- As`cer*tain"a*bly, adv.
accumulation: The concurrence of several titles to the same proof.Accumulation of energy or power, the storing of energy by means ofweights lifted or masses put in motion; electricity stored.-- An accumulation of degrees (Eng. Univ.), the taking of severaltogether, or at smaller intervals than usual or than is allowed bythe rules.
air line: A path through the air made easy for aërial navigation bysteady winds.
abrood: In the act of brooding. [Obs.] Abp. Sancroft.
arborous: Formed by trees. [Obs.]From under shady, arborous roof. Milton.
anomaliped: One of a group of perching birds, having the middle toe more orless united to the outer and inner ones.
athleticism: The practice of engaging in athletic games; athletism.
azurn: Azure. [Obs.]Thick set with agate, and the azurn sheen Of turkis blue, and emeraldgreen. Milton.
autoharp: A zitherlike musical instrument, provided with dampers which,when depressed, deaden some strings, leaving free others that form achord.
aphesis: The loss of a short unaccented vowel at the beginning of aword; -- the result of a phonetic process; as, squire for esquire.New Eng. Dict.
absentness: The quality of being absent-minded. H. Miller.
alcazar: A fortress; also, a royal palace. Prescott.
archbishop: A chief bishop; a church dignitary of the first class (oftencalled a metropolitan or primate) who superintends the conduct of thesuffragan bishops in his province, and also exercises episcopalauthority in his own diocese.
amalgam: A native compound of mercury and silver.
attender: One who, or that which, attends.
aboon: and adv. Above. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]Aboon the pass of Bally-Brough. Sir W. Scott.The ceiling fair that rose aboon. J. R. Drake.
asclepiadaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, plants of the Milkweedfamily.
amnion: A thin membrane surrounding the embryos of mammals, birds, andreptiles.
alliant: An ally; a confederate. [Obs. & R.] Sir H. Wotton.
aquamarine: A transparent, pale green variety of beryl, used as a gem. SeeBeryl.
alimony: An allowance made to a wife out of her husband's estate orincome for her support, upon her divorce or legal separation fromhim, or during a suit for the same. Wharton. Burrill.
anomia: A genus of bivalve shells, allied to the oyster, so called fromtheir unequal valves, of which the lower is perforated forattachment.
antiphone: The response which one side of the choir makes to the other ina chant; alternate chanting or signing.
associationist: One who explains the higher functions and relations of the soulby the association of ideas; e. g., Hartley, J. C. Mill.
alpha paper: A sensitized paper for obtaining positives by artificial light.It is coated with gelatin containing silver bromide and chloride.[Eng.]
anchor watch: A detail of one or more men who keep watch on deck at nightwhen a vessel is at anchor.
aphakia: An anomalous state of refraction caused by the absence of thecrystalline lens, as after operations for cataract. The remedy is theuse of powerful convex lenses. Dunglison.
anglify: To convert into English; to anglicize. Franklin. Darwin.
aerocyst: One of the air cells of algals.
allatrate: To bark as a dog. [Obs.] Stubbes.
abaciscus: One of the tiles or squares of a tessellated pavement; anabaculus.
accompanier: He who, or that which, accompanies. Lamb.
anthocarpous: Having some portion of the floral envelopes attached to thepericarp to form the fruit, as in the checkerberry, the mulberry, andthe pineapple.
agriculturalist: An agriculturist (which is the preferred form.)
african: Of or pertaining to Africa. African hemp, a fiber prerared fromthe leaves of the Sanseviera Guineensis, a plant found in Africa andIndia.-- African marigold, a tropical American plant (Tagetes erecta).-- African oak or African teak, a timber furnished by OldfieldiaAfricana, used in ship building. African violet African-American, aUnited States citizen of African descent.
aprocta: A group of Turbellaria in which there is no anal aperture.
amyl nitrite: A yellowish oily volatile liquid, C5H11NO2, used in medicine asa heart stimulant and a vasodilator. The inhalation of its vaporinstantly produces flushing of the face.
ab: The fifth month of the Jewish year according to theecclesiastical reckoning, the eleventh by the civil computation,coinciding nearly with August. W. Smith.
anaerobies: Microörganisms which do not require oxygen, but are killed byit. Sternberg.
abroach: To set abroach; to let out, as liquor; to broach; to tap.[Obs.] Chaucer.
ambulant: Walking; moving from place to place. Gayton.
arteriosclerosis: Abnormal thickening and hardening of the walls of the arteries,esp. of the intima, occurring mostly in old age. --Ar*te`ri*o*scle*rot"ic (#), a.
attaint: To find guilty; to convict; -- said esp. of a jury on trial forgiving a false verdict. [Obs.]Upon sufficient proof attainted of some open act by men of his owncondition. Blackstone.
acetimetry: The act or method of ascertaining the strength of vinegar, orthe proportion of acetic acid contained in it. Ure.
assignat: One of the notes, bills, or bonds, issued as currency by therevolutionary government of France (1790-1796), and based on thesecurity of the lands of the church and of nobles which had beenappropriated by the state.
agglutinant: Uniting, as glue; causing, or tending to cause, adhesion.-- n.
anseres: A Linnæan order of aquatic birds swimming by means of webbedfeet, as the duck, or of lobed feet, as the grebe. In this order wereincluded the geese, ducks, auks, divers, gulls, petrels, etc.
assaying: The act or process of testing, esp. of analyzing or examiningmetals and ores, to determine the proportion of pure metal.
aloetic: Consisting chiefly of aloes; of the nature of aloes.
acritical: Having no crisis; giving no indications of a crisis; as,acritical symptoms, an acritical abscess.
androcephalous: Having a human head (upon an animal's body), as the Egyptiansphinx.
apeak: In a vertical line. The anchor in apeak, when the cable hasbeen sufficiently hove in to bring the ship over it, and the ship isthem said to be hove apeak. [Spelt also apeek.]
archaeopteryx: A fossil bird, of the Jurassic period, remarkable for having along tapering tail of many vertebræ with feathers along each side,and jaws armed with teeth, with other reptilian characteristics.
antimacassar: A cover for the back or arms of a chair or sofa, etc., toprevent them from being soiled by macassar or other oil from thehair.
apprehensibiity: The quality of being apprehensible. [R.] De Quincey.
atavic: Pertaining to a remote ancestor, or to atavism.
auditorium: The part of a church, theater, or other public building,assigned to the audience.
aviation: The art or science of flying.
accessorial: Of or pertaining to an accessory; as, accessorial agency,accessorial guilt.
acetabuliferous: Furnished with fleshy cups for adhering to bodies, ascuttlefish, etc.
aphorist: A writer or utterer of aphorisms.
analogic: Of or belonging to analogy. Geo. Eliot.
aspersive: Tending to asperse; defamatory; slanderous.-- As*pers"ive*ly, adv.
antichlor: Any substance (but especially sodium hyposulphite) used inremoving the excess of chlorine left in paper pulp or stuffs afterbleaching.
amplexicaul: Clasping or embracing a stem, as the base of some leaves. Gray.
approbatory: Containing or expressing approbation; commendatory. Sheldon.
air gun: A kind of gun in which the elastic force of condensed air isused to discharge the ball. The air is powerfully compressed into areservoir attached to the gun, by a condensing pump, and iscontrolled by a valve actuated by the trigger.
antistrumous: Good against scrofulous disorders. Johnson. Wiseman.
answerably: In an answerable manner; in due proportion or correspondence;suitably.
alveolus: A small cavity in a coral, shell, or fossil
ask: A water newt. [Scot. & North of Eng.]
accipiter: A genus of rapacious birds; one of the Accipitres or Raptores.
arch-: A prefix signifying chief, as in archbuilder, archfiend.
art union: An association for promoting art (esp. the arts of design), andgiving encouragement to artists.
amalgama: Same as Amalgam.They divided this their amalgama into a number of incoherentrepublics. Burke.
autotransformer: A transformer in which part of the primary winding is used as asecondary winding, or vice versa; -- called also a compensator orbalancing coil.
adry: In a dry or thirsty condition. "A man that is adry." Burton.
admaxillary: Near to the maxilla or jawbone.
amorosa: A wanton woman; a courtesan. Sir T. Herbert.
acupuncture: Pricking with a needle; a needle prick. Specifically (Med.):
antibubonic: Good or used against bubonic plague; as, antibubonic serum,obtained from immunized horses; antibubonic vaccine, a sterilizedbouillon culture of the plague bacillus; antibubonic measures.
accompanist: The performer in music who takes the accompanying part. Busby.
alpha: The first letter in the Greek alphabet, answering to A, andhence used to denote the beginning.In am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end, the first and thelast. Rev. xxii. 13.
actinosome: The entire body of a coelenterate.
awakening: Rousing from sleep, in a natural or a figurative sense; rousinginto activity; exciting; as, the awakening city; an awakeningdiscourse; the awakening dawn.-- A*wak"en*ing*ly, adv.
aphrodisian: Pertaining to Aphrodite or Venus. "Aphrodisian dames" [that is,courtesans]. C. Reade.
antilithic: Tending to prevent the formation of urinary calculi, or todestroy them when formed.-- n.
aching: That aches; continuously painful. See Ache.-- Ach"ing*ly, adv.The aching heart, the aching head. Longfellow.
aleatory: Depending on some uncertain contingency; as, an aleatorycontract. Bouvier.
absonous: Discordant; inharmonious; incongruous. [Obs.] "Absonous to ourreason." Glanvill.
arthrodynia: An affection characterized by pain in or about a joint, notdependent upon structural disease.
accuracy: The state of being accurate; freedom from mistakes, thisexemption arising from carefulness; exact conformity to truth, or toa rule or model; precision; exactness; nicety; correctness; as, thevalue of testimony depends on its accuracy.The professed end [of logic] is to teach men to think, to judge, andto reason, with precision and accuracy. Reid.The accuracy with which the piston fits the sides. Lardner.
alvine: Of, from, in, or pertaining to, the belly or the intestines;as, alvine discharges; alvine concretions.
ammonium: A compound radical, NH4, having the chemical relations of astrongly basic element like the alkali metals.
arenulous: Full of fine sand; like sand. [Obs.]
affranchise: To make free; to enfranchise. Johnson.
anteversion: A displacement of an organ, esp. of the uterus, in such mannerthat its whole axis is directed further forward than usual.
anisomerous: Having the number of floral organs unequal, as four petals andsix stamens.
alphabet: To designate by the letters of the alphabet; to arrangealphabetically. [R.]
angelology: A discourse on angels, or a body of doctrines in regard toangels.The same mythology commanded the general consent; the sameangelology, demonology. Milman.
angiopathy: Disease of the vessels, esp. the blood vessels.
anise: An umbelliferous plant (Pimpinella anisum) growing naturally inEgypt, and cultivated in Spain, Malta, etc., for its carminative andaromatic seeds.
adultery: The fine and penalty imposed for the offense of adultery.
artillerist: A person skilled in artillery or gunnery; a gunner; anartilleryman.
archenemy: A principal enemy. Specifically, Satan, the grand adversary ofmankind. Milton.
abandonee: One to whom anything is legally abandoned.
alga: A kind of seaweed; pl. the class of cellular cryptogamic plantswhich includes the black, red, and green seaweeds, as kelp, dulse,sea lettuce, also marine and fresh water confervæ, etc.
addendum: A thing to be added; an appendix or addition. Addendum circle(Mech.), the circle which may be described around a circular spurwheel or gear wheel, touching the crests or tips of the teeth.Rankine.
asian: Of or pertaining to Asia; Asiatic. "Asian princes." Jer.Taylor.-- n.
admire: To wonder; to marvel; to be affected with surprise; --sometimes with at.To wonder at Pharaoh, and even admire at myself. Fuller.
air engine: An engine driven by heated or by compressed air. Knight.
aerostatics: The science that treats of the equilibrium of elastic fluids,or that of bodies sustained in them. Hence it includes aëronautics.
argentan: An alloy of nicked with copper and zinc; German silver.
assident: Usually attending a disease, but not always; as, assidentsigns, or symptoms.
amphiaster: The achromatic figure, formed in mitotic cell-division,consisting of two asters connected by a spindle-shaped bundle ofrodlike fibers diverging from each aster, and called the spindle.
associated: Joined as a companion; brought into association; accompanying;combined. Associated movements (Physiol.), consensual movements whichaccompany voluntary efforts without our consciousness. Dunglison.
antiae: The two projecting feathered angles of the forehead of somebirds; the frontal points.
anchoress: A female anchoret.And there, a saintly anchoress, she dwelt. Wordsworth.
apastron: That point in the orbit of a double star where the smaller staris farthest from its primary.
allonymous: Published under the name of some one other than the author.
abies: A genus of coniferous trees, properly called Fir, as the balsamfir and the silver fir. The spruces are sometimes also referred tothis genus.
ankh: A tau cross with a loop at the top, used as an attribute orsacred emblem, symbolizing generation or enduring life. Called alsocrux ansata.
ark: The oblong chest of acacia wood, overlaid with gold, whichsupported the mercy seat with its golden cherubs, and occupied themost sacred place in the sanctuary. In it Moses placed the two tablesof stone containing the ten commandments. Called also the Ark of theCovenant.
asphalt: To cover with asphalt; as, to asphalt a roof; asphaltedstreets.
annihilator: One who, or that which, annihilates; as, a fire annihilator.
anoa: A small wild ox of Celebes (Anoa depressicornis), allied to thebuffalo, but having long nearly straight horns.
abra: A narrow pass or defile; a break in a mesa; the mouth of acañon. [Southwestern U. S.]
allusively: Figuratively [Obs.]; by way of allusion; by implication,suggestion, or insinuation.
amplification: The enlarging of a simple statement by particularity ofdescription, the use of epithets, etc., for rhetorical effect;diffuse narrative or description, or a dilating upon all theparticulars of a subject.Exaggeration is a species of amplification. Brande & C.I shall summarily, without any amplification at all, show in whatmanner defects have been supplied. Sir J. Davies.
arpentator: The Anglicized form of the French arpenteur, a land surveyor.[R.]
abuseful: Full of abuse; abusive. [R.] "Abuseful names." Bp. Barlow.
arctic: Pertaining to, or situated under, the northern constellationcalled the Bear; northern; frigid; as, the arctic pole, circle,region, ocean; an arctic expedition, night, temperature.
alum root: A North American herb (Heuchera Americana) of the Saxifragefamily, whose root has astringent properties.
apprehensiveness: The quality or state of being apprehensive.
aleberry: A beverage, formerly made by boiling ale with spice, sugar, andsops of bread.Their aleberries, caudles, possets. Beau. & Fl.
altrices: Nursers, -- a term applied to those birds whose young arehatched in a very immature and helpless condition, so as to requirethe care of their parents for some time; -- opposed to præcoces.
autophony: An auscultatory process, which consists in noting the tone ofthe observer's own voice, while he speaks, holding his head close tothe patient's chest. Dunglison.
a-good: In earnest; heartily. [Obs.] "I made her weep agood." Shak.
apogean: Connected with the apogee; as, apogean (neap) tides, whichoccur when the moon has passed her apogee.
adenotomy: Dissection of, or incision into, a gland or glands.
aliphatic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, fat; fatty; -- applied tocompounds having an openc-hain structure. The aliphatic compoundsthus include not only the fatty acids and other derivatives of theparaffin hydrocarbons, but also unsaturated compounds, as theethylene and acetylene series.
azoic: Destitute of any vestige of organic life, or at least of animallife; anterior to the existence of animal life; formed when there wasno animal life on the globe; as, the azoic. rocks. Azoic age (Geol.),the age preceding the existence of animal life, or anterior to thepaleozoic tome. Azoic is also used as a noun, age being understood.See Archæan, and Eozoic.
alligation: A rule relating to the solution of questions concerning thecompounding or mixing of different ingredients, or ingredients ofdifferent qualities or values.
affusion: The act of pouring upon, or sprinkling with a liquid, as waterupon a child in baptism. Specifically: (Med)
apotelesm: The calculation and explanation of a nativity. [Obs.] Bailey.
aggrate: To please. [Obs.]Each one sought his lady to aggrate. Spenser.
