aquarelle: A design or painting in thin transparent water colors; also,the mode of painting in such colors.
anglo-saxon: The Teutonic people (Angles, Saxons, Jutes) of England, or theEnglish people, collectively, before the Norman Conquest.It is quite correct to call Æthelstan "King of the Anglo-Saxons," butto call this or that subject of Æthelstan "an Anglo-Saxon" is simplynonsense. E. A. Freeman.
astraddle: In a straddling position; astride; bestriding; as, to sitastraddle a horse.
apocalyptically: By revelation; in an apocalyptic manner.
any: To any extent; in any degree; at all.You are not to go loose any longer. Shak.Before you go any farther. Steele.
apologetics: That branch of theology which defends the Holy Scriptures, andsets forth the evidence of their divine authority.
antimeter: A modification of the quadrant, for measuring small angles.[Obs.]
adonai: A Hebrew name for God, usually translated in the Old Testamentby the word "Lord".
autoptically: By means of ocular view, or one's own observation. Sir T.Browne.
ambrosin: An early coin struck by the dukes of Milan, and bearing thefigure of St. Ambrose on horseback.
asynartete: Disconnected; not fitted or adjusted.-- A*syn"ar*tet"ic, a. Asynartete verse (Pros.), a verse of twomembers, having different rhythms; as when the first consists ofiambuses and the second of trochees.
agrostology: That part of botany which treats of the grasses.
approver: One who confesses a crime and accuses another. See 1stApprovement, 2.
airless: Not open to a free current of air; wanting fresh air, orcommunication with the open air.
anthracoid: Resembling anthrax in action; of the nature of anthrax; as, ananthracoid microbe.
alacrious: Brisk; joyously active; lively.'T were well if we were a little more alacrious. Hammond.
autobiographist: One who writes his own life; an autobiographer. [R.]
adosculation: Impregnation by external contact, without intromission.
appose: To put questions to; to examine; to try. [Obs.] See Pose.To appose him without any accuser, and that secretly. Tyndale.
astatki: A thick liquid residuum obtained in the distillation of Russianpetroleum, much used as fuel.
avowal: An open declaration; frank acknowledgment; as, an avowal ofsuch principles. Hume.
acoustics: The science of sounds, teaching their nature, phenomena, andlaws.Acoustics, then, or the science of sound, is a very considerablebranch of physics. Sir J. Herschel.
amphidisc: A peculiar small siliceous spicule having a denticulated wheelat each end; -- found in freshwater sponges.
a-tiptoe: On tiptoe; eagerly expecting.We all feel a-tiptoe with hope and confidence. F. Harrison.
abort: To become checked in normal development, so as either to remainrudimentary or shrink away wholly; to become sterile.
actiniform: Having a radiated form, like a sea anemone.
argentic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, silver; -- said ofcertain compounds of silver in which this metal has its lowestproportion; as, argentic chloride.
ahull: With the sails furled, and the helm lashed alee; -- applied toships in a storm. See Hull, n.
arillode: A false aril; an aril originating from the micropyle instead offrom the funicle or chalaza of the ovule. The mace of the nutmeg isan arillode.
ant egg: One of the small white egg-shaped pupæ or cocoons of the ant,often seen in or about ant-hills, and popularly supposed to be eggs.
argument: The quantity on which another quantity in a table depends; as,the altitude is the argument of the refraction.
average: That service which a tenant owed his lord, to be done by thework beasts of the tenant, as the carriage of wheat, turf, etc.
angling: The act of one who angles; the art of fishing with rod andline. Walton.
augustinian: Of or pertaining to St. Augustine, bishop of Hippo in NorthernAfrica (b. 354 -- d. 430), or to his doctrines. Augustinian canons,an order of monks once popular in England and Ireland; -- called alsoregular canons of St. Austin, and black canons.-- Augustinian hermits or Austin friars, an order of friarsestablished in 1265 by Pope Alexander IV. It was introduced into theUnited States from Ireland in 1790.-- Augustinian nuns, an order of nuns following the rule of St.Augustine.-- Augustinian rule, a rule for religious communities based upon the109th letter of St. Augustine, and adopted by the Augustinian orders.
asp: Same as Aspen. "Trembling poplar or asp." Martyn.
abidance: The state of abiding; abode; continuance; compliance (with).The Christians had no longer abidance in the holy hill of Palestine.Fuller.A judicious abidance by rules. Helps.
aroph: A barbarous word used by the old chemists to designate variousmedical remedies. [Obs.]
amiableness: The quality of being amiable; amiability.
anoplura: A group of insects which includes the lice.
areal: Of or pertaining to an area; as, areal interstices (the areasor spaces inclosed by the reticulate vessels of leaves).
adult: Having arrived at maturity, or to full size and strength;matured; as, an adult person or plant; an adult ape; an adult age.
aerofoil: A plane or arched surface for sustaining bodies by its movementthrough the air; a spread wing, as of a bird.
archiater: Chief physician; -- a term applied, on the continent of Europe,to the first or body physician of princes and to the first physicianof some cities. P. Cyc.
aspergilliform: Resembling the aspergillum in form; as, an aspergilliformstigma. Gray.
aboveboard: Above the board or table. Hence: in open sight; without trick,concealment, or deception. "Fair and aboveboard." Burke.
archenteron: The primitive enteron or undifferentiated digestive sac of agastrula or other embryo. See Illust. under Invagination.
alpenglow: A reddish glow seen near sunset or sunrise on the summits ofmountains; specif., a reillumination sometimes observed after thesummits have passed into shadow, supposed to be due to a curvingdownward (refraction) of the light rays from the west resulting fromthe cooling of the air.
acetosity: The quality of being acetous; sourness.
abbotship: The state or office of an abbot.
attitudinize: To assume affected attitudes; to strike an attitude; to pose.Maria, who is the most picturesque figure, was put to attitudinize atthe harp. Hannah More.
amylolytic: Effecting the conversion of starch into soluble dextrin andsugar; as, an amylolytic ferment. Foster.
anonymous: Nameless; of unknown name; also, of unknown /or unavowedauthorship; as, an anonymous benefactor; an anonymous pamphlet orletter.
aerator: That which supplies with air; esp. an apparatus used forcharging mineral waters with gas and in making soda water.
artery: One of the vessels or tubes which carry either venous orarterial blood from the heart. They have tricker and more muscularwalls than veins, and are connected with them by capillaries.
affreight: To hire, as a ship, for the transportation of goods or freight.
adamantine: Like the diamond in hardness or luster.
anhydrous: Destitute of water; as, anhydrous salts or acids.
absoluteness: The quality of being absolute; independence of everythingextraneous; unlimitedness; absolute power; independent reality;positiveness.
affluent: A stream or river flowing into a larger river or into a lake; atributary stream.
anapest: A metrical foot consisting of three syllables, the first twoshort, or unaccented, the last long, or accented; the reverse of thedactyl. In Latin d, and in English in-ter-vene, are examples ofanapests.
aspartic: Pertaining to, or derived, asparagine; as, aspartic acid.
ale silver: A duty payable to the lord mayor of London by the sellers ofale within the city.
almagest: The celebrated work of Ptolemy of Alexandria, which containsnearly all that is known of the astronomical observations andtheories of the ancients. The name was extended to other similarworks.
all-hail: To salute; to greet. [Poet.]Whiles I stood rapt in the wonder of it, came missives from the king,who all-hailed me "Thane of Cawdor." Shak.
aerolitic: Of or pertaining to aërolites; meteoric; as, aërolitic iron.Booth.
apparition: The first appearance of a star or other luminary after havingbeen invisible or obscured; -- opposed to occultation. Circle ofperpetual apparition. See under Circle.
assurgency: Act of rising.The . . . assurgency of the spirit through the body. Coleridge.
alalia: Inability to utter articulate sounds, due either to paralysisof the larynx or to that form of aphasia, called motor, or ataxis,aphasia, due to loss of control of the muscles of speech.
air pipe: A pipe for the passage of air; esp. a ventilating pipe.
anathematize: To pronounce an anathema against; to curse. Hence: To condemnpublicly as something accursed. Milton.
afterings: The last milk drawn in milking; strokings. [Obs.] Grose.
air-slacked: Slacked, or pulverized, by exposure to the air; as, air-slackedlime.
antinomian: Of or pertaining to the Antinomians; opposed to the doctrinethat the moral law is obligatory.
anthraconite: A coal-black marble, usually emitting a fetid smell whenrubbed; -- called also stinkstone and swinestone.
alkekengi: An herbaceous plant of the nightshade family (Physalisalkekengi) and its fruit, which is a well flavored berry, the size ofa cherry, loosely inclosed in a enlarged leafy calyx; -- also calledwinter cherry, ground cherry, and strawberry tomato. D. C. Eaton.
angle of entry: The angle between the tangent to the advancing edge (of anaërocurve) and the line of motion; -- contrasted with angle of trail,which is the angle between the tangent to the following edge and theline of motion.
amorphozoic: Of or pertaining to the Amorphozoa.
adeem: To revoke, as a legacy, grant, etc., or to satisfy it by someother gift.
apozemical: Pertaining to, or resembling, a decoction. [Obs.] J. Whitaker.
arachnidium: The glandular organ in which the material for the web ofspiders is secreted.
alienation: A transfer of title, or a legal conveyance of property toanother.
acuity: Sharpness or acuteness, as of a needle, wit, etc.
auriferous: Gold-bearing; containing or producing gold.Whence many a bursting stream auriferous plays. Thomson.~= pyrites, iron pyrites (iron disulphide), containing some golddisseminated through it.
arsenicate: To combine with arsenic; to treat or impregnate with arsenic.
arnicine: An alkaloid obtained from the arnica plant.
austrian: Of or pertaining to Austria, or to its inhabitants.-- n.
antepredicament: A prerequisite to a clear understanding of the predicaments andcategories, such as definitions of common terms. Chambers.
acuminate: Tapering to a point; pointed; as, acuminate leaves, teeth, etc.
antecede: To go before in time or place; to precede; to surpass. Sir M.Hale.
alcyonic: Of or pertaining to the Alcyonaria.
albyn: Scotland; esp. the Highlands of Scotland. T. Cambell.
ambrotype: A picture taken on a place of prepared glass, in which thelights are represented in silver, and the shades are produced by adark background visible through the unsilvered portions of the glass.
anime: Of a different tincture from the animal itself; -- said of theeyes of a rapacious animal. Brande & C.
antisabbatarian: One of a sect which opposes the observance of the ChristianSabbath.
anaglyptograph: An instrument by which a correct engraving of any embossedobject, such as a medal or cameo, can be executed. Brande & C.
abstraction: The act process of leaving out of consideration one or moreproperties of a complex object so as to attend to others; analysis.Thus, when the mind considers the form of a tree by itself, or thecolor of the leaves as separate from their size or figure, the act iscalled abstraction. So, also, when it considers whiteness, softness,virtue, existence, as separate from any particular objects.
animus: Animating spirit; intention; temper. nimus furandi Etym: [L.](Law), intention of stealing.
ascending: Rising; moving upward; as, an ascending kite.-- As*cend"ing*ly, adv. Ascending latitude (Astron.), the increasinglatitude of a planet. Ferguson.-- Ascending line (Geneol.), the line of relationship tracedbackward or through one's ancestors. One's father and mother,grandfather and grandmother, etc., are in the line direct ascending.-- Ascending node having, that node of the moon or a planet whereinit passes the ecliptic to proceed northward. It is also called thenorthern node. Herschel.-- Ascending series. (Math.) (a) A series arranged according to theascending powers of a quantity. (b) A series in which each term isgreater than the preceding.-- Ascending signs, signs east of the meridian.
appetizing: Exciting appetite; as, appetizing food.The appearance of the wild ducks is very appetizing. Sir W. Scott.
aphis: A genus of insects belonging to the order Hemiptera and familyAphidæ, including numerous species known as plant lice and greenflies.
ampere foot: A unit, employed in calculating fall of pressure indistributing mains, equivalent to a current of one ampère flowingthrough one foot of conductor.
aeriform: Having the form or nature of air, or of an elastic fluid;gaseous. Hence fig.: Unreal.
admeasure: To determine the proper share of, or the proper apportionment;as, to admeasure dower; to admeasure common of pasture. Blackstone.
astringent: A medicine or other substance that produces contraction in thesoft organic textures, and checks discharges of blood, mucus, etc.External astringents are called styptics. Dunglison.
anthracitic: Of, pertaining to, or like, anthracite; as, anthraciticformations.
air vessel: A vessel, cell, duct, or tube containing or conducting air; asthe air vessels of insects, birds, plants, etc.; the air vessel of apump, engine, etc. For the latter, see Air chamber. The air vesselsof insects are called tracheæ, of plants spiral vessels.
anticlimax: A sentence in which the ideas fall, or become less importantand striking, at the close; -- the opposite of climax. It produces aridiculous effect. Example:Next comes Dalhousie, the great god of war,Lieutenant-colonel to the Earl ANTICLINALAn`ti*cli"nal, a. Etym: [Pref. anti- + Gr.
anachorism: An error in regard to the place of an event or a thing; areferring something to a wrong place. [R.]
anthropoidea: The suborder of primates which includes the monkeys, apes, andman.
analogue: A word in one language corresponding with one in another; ananalogous term; as, the Latin "pater" is the analogue of the English"father."
alchemist: One who practices alchemy.You are alchemist; make gold. Shak.
amphipneust: One of a tribe of Amphibia, which have both lungs and gills atthe same time, as the proteus and siren.
apologizer: One who makes an apology; an apologist.
alternativeness: The quality of being alternative, or of offering a choicebetween two.
appete: To seek for; to desire. [Obs.] Chaucer.
arcuation: A mode of propagating trees by bending branches to the ground,and covering the small shoots with earth; layering. Chambers.
anacamptically: By reflection; as, echoes are sound produced anacamptically.Hutton.
antipetalous: Standing before a petal, as a stamen.
articulation: A joint or juncture between bones in the skeleton.
anaglyptography: The art of copying works in relief, or of engraving as to givethe subject an embossed or raised appearance; -- used in representingcoins, bas-reliefs, etc.
animated: Endowed with life; full of life or spirit; indicatinganimation; lively; vigorous. "Animated sounds." Pope. "Animatedbust." Gray. "Animated descriptions." Lewis.
astay: An anchor is said to be astay, in heaving it, an acute angle isformed between the cable and the surface of the water.
aestivation: The state of torpidity induced by the heat and dryness ofsummer, as in certain snails; -- opposed to hibernation.
ambrein: A fragrant substance which is the chief constituent ofambergris.
archaeologist: One versed in archæology; an antiquary. Wright.
admiral: A handsome butterfly (Pyrameis Atalanta) of Europe and America.The larva feeds on nettles. Admiral shell (Zoöl.), the popular nameof an ornamental cone shell (Conus admiralis). Lord High Admiral, agreat officer of state, who (when this rare dignity is conferred) isat the head of the naval administration of Great Britain.
abysmally: To a fathomless depth; profoundly. "Abysmally ignorant." G.Eliot.
adjure: To charge, bind, or command, solemnly, as if under oath, orunder the penalty of a curse; to appeal to in the most solemn orimpressive manner; to entreat earnestly.Joshua adjured them at that time, saying, Cursed be the man beforethe Lord, that riseth up and buildeth this city Jericho. Josh. vi.26.The high priest . . . said . . . I adjure thee by the living God,that thou tell us whether thou be the Christ. Matt. xxvi. 63.The commissioners adjured them not to let pass so favorable anopportunity of securing their liberties. Marshall.
aecidium: A form of fruit in the cycle of development of the Rusts orBrands, an order of fungi, formerly considered independent plants.
ahold: Near the wind; as, to lay a ship ahold. [Obs.] Shak.
accite: To cite; to summon. [Obs.]Our heralds now accited all that were Endamaged by the Elians.Chapman.
archbutler: A chief butler; -- an officer of the German empire.
appurtenance: That which belongs to something else; an adjunct; an appendage;an accessory; something annexed to another thing more worthy; incommon parlance and legal acceptation, something belonging to anotherthing as principal, and which passes as incident to it, as a right ofway, or other easement to land; a right of common to pasture, anouthouse, barn, garden, or orchard, to a house or messuage. In astrict legal sense, land can never pass as an appurtenance to land.Tomlins. Bouvier. Burrill.Globes . . . provided as appurtenances to astronomy. Bacon.The structure of the eye, and of its appurtenances. Reid.
avid: Longing eagerly for; eager; greedy. "Avid of gold, yet greedierof renown." Southey.
achromatism: The state or quality of being achromatic; as, the achromatismof a lens; achromaticity. Nichol.
asker: One who asks; a petitioner; an inquirer. Shak.
adherent: Congenitally united with an organ of another kind, as calyxwith ovary, or stamens with petals.
abalone: A univalve mollusk of the genus Haliotis. The shell is linedwith mother-of-pearl, and used for ornamental purposes; the sea-ear.Several large species are found on the coast of California, clingingclosely to the rocks.
aspect ratio: The ratio of the long to the short side of an aëroplane,aërocurve, or wing.
azonic: Confined to no zone or region; not local.
agone: Ago. [Archaic. & Poet.]Three days agone I fell sick. 1 Sam. xxx. 13.
arthritis: Any inflammation of the joints, particularly the gout.
adjective: A word used with a noun, or substantive, to express a qualityof the thing named, or something attributed to it, or to limit ordefine it, or to specify or describe a thing, as distinct fromsomething else. Thus, in phrase, "a wise ruler," wise is theadjective, expressing a property of ruler.
anamese: Of or pertaining to Anam, to southeastern Asia.-- n.
angiology: That part of anatomy which treats of blood vessels andlymphatics.
amphigean: Extending over all the zones, from the tropics to the polarzones inclusive.
anthozoa: The class of the Coelenterata which includes the corals and seaanemones. The three principal groups or orders are Acyonaria,Actinaria, and Madreporaria.
alliterative: Pertaining to, or characterized by, alliteration; as,alliterative poetry.-- Al*lit"er*a*tive*ly, adv.-- Al*lit"er*a*tive*ness, n.
asymmetral: Incommensurable; also, unsymmetrical. [Obs.] D. H. More.
antiquarianize: To act the part of an antiquary. [Colloq.]
antimephitic: Good against mephitic or deletplwious gases.-- n.
arraign: To call or set as a prisoner at the bar of a court to answer tothe matter charged in an indictment or complaint. Blackstone.
appendant: Appended by prescription, that is, a personal usage for aconsiderable time; -- said of a thing of inheritance belonging toanother inheritance which is superior or more worthy; as, anadvowson, common, etc. , which may be appendant to a manor, common offishing to a freehold, a seat in church to a house. Wharton. Coke.
anthology: A service book containing a selection of pieces for thefestival services.
alewife: A woman who keeps an alehouse. Gay.
appalling: Such as to appall; as, an appalling accident.-- Ap*pall"ing*ly, adv.
anthropometry: Measurement of the height and other dimensions of human beings,especially at different ages, or in different races, occupations,etc. Dunglison.
aluminography: Art or process of producing, and printing from, aluminiumplates, after the manner of ordinary lithography. --A*lu`mi*no*graph"ic (#), a.
aldermanlike: Like or suited to an alderman.
artfulness: The quality of being artful; art; cunning; craft.
airol: A grayish green antiseptic powder, consisting of a basic iodideand gallate of bismuth, sometimes used in place of iodoform. [ATrademark]
ambergris: A substance of the consistence of wax, found floating in theIndian Ocean and other parts of the tropics, and also as a morbidsecretion in the intestines of the sperm whale (Physetermacrocephalus), which is believed to be in all cases its true origin.In color it is white, ash-gray, yellow, or black, and oftenvariegated like marble. The floating masses are sometimes from sixtyto two hundred and twenty-five pounds in weight. It is whollyvolatilized as a white vapor at 212º Fahrenheit, and is highly valuedin perfumery. Dana.
angostura bark: An aromatic bark used as a tonic, obtained from a SouthAmerican of the rue family (Galipea cusparia, or officinalis). U. S.Disp.
arse: The buttocks, or hind part of an animal; the posteriors; thefundament; the bottom.
asterism: An optical property of some crystals which exhibit a star-shaped by reflected light, as star sapphire, or by transmitted light,as some mica.
actinology: The science which treats of rays of light, especially of theactinic or chemical rays.
appalachian: Of or pertaining to a chain of mountains in the United States,commonly called the Allegheny mountains.
arsis: The elevation of the hand, or that part of the bar at which itis raised, in beating time; the weak or unaccented part of the bar; -- opposed to thesis. Moore.
alborak: The imaginary milk-white animal on which Mohammed was said tohave been carried up to heaven; a white mule.
abduction: The movement which separates a limb or other part from theaxis, or middle line, of the body.
ampelopsis: A genus formerly including the Virginia creeper.
attractivity: The quality or degree of attractive power.
affectibility: The quality or state of being affectible. [R.]
ansa: A name given to either of the projecting ends of Saturn's ring.
anelectrode: The positive pole of a voltaic battery.
arthurian: Of or pertaining to King Arthur or his knights.  J. R. Symonds.
ancient: Those who lived in former ages, as opposed to the moderns.
avuncular: Of or pertaining to an uncle.In these rare instances, the law of pedigree, whether direct oravuncular, gives way. I. Taylor.
ambrosiac: Having the qualities of ambrosia; delicious. [R.]"Ambrosiacodors." B. Jonson.
afoam: In a foaming state; as, the sea is all afoam.
anapestic: Pertaining to an anapest; consisting of an anapests; as, ananapestic meter, foot, verse.-- n.
anurous: Destitute of a tail, as the frogs and toads. [Also writtenanourous.]
abaiser: Ivory black or animal charcoal. Weale.
atrypa: A extinct genus of Branchiopoda, very common in Silurianlimestones.
alliteration: The repetition of the same letter at the beginning of two ormore words immediately succeeding each other, or at short intervals;as in the following lines: -Behemoth, biggest born of earth, upheaved His vastness. Milton.Fly o'er waste fens and windy fields. Tennyson.
attracter: One who, or that which, attracts.
arctogeal: Of or pertaining to arctic lands; as, the arctogeal fauna.
auric: Pertaining to, or derived from, gold; -- said of thosecompounds of gold in which this element has its higher valence; as,auric oxide; auric chloride.
atonic: Characterized by atony, or want of vital energy; as, an atonicdisease.
altarwise: In the proper position of an altar, that is, at the east of achurch with its ends towards the north and south. Shipley.
abarticulation: Articulation, usually that kind of articulation which admits offree motion in the joint; diarthrosis. Coxe.
appointer: One who appoints, or executes a power of appointment. Kent.
aumery: A form of Ambry, a closet; but confused with Almonry, as if aplace for alms.
album: A white tablet on which anything was inscribed, as a list ofnames, etc.
adaptive: Suited, given, or tending, to adaptation; characterized byadaptation; capable of adapting. Coleridge.-- A*dapt"ive*ly, adv.
acyclic: Not cyclic; not disposed in cycles or whorls; as: (a) (Bot.)
autophoby: Fear of one's self; fear of being egotistical. [R.] Hare.
aggression: The first attack, or act of hostility; the first act of injury,or first act leading to a war or a controversy; unprovoked attack;assault; as, a war of aggression. "Aggressions of power."  Hallam
autopsy: Dissection of a dead body, for the purpose of ascertaining thecause, seat, or nature of a disease; a post-mortem examination.
apneumona: An order of holothurians in which the internal respiratoryorgans are wanting; -- called also Apoda or Apodes.
appreciativeness: The quality of being appreciative; quick recognition ofexcellence.
anlaut: An initial sound, as of a word or syllable.
archencephala: The division that includes man alone. R. Owen.
aretaics: The ethical theory which excludes all relations between virtueand happiness; the science of virtue; -- contrasted with eudemonics.J. Grote.
ablaut: The substitution of one root vowel for another, thus indicatinga corresponding modification of use or meaning; vowel permutation;as, get, gat, got; sing, song; hang, hung. Earle.
acequia: A canal or trench for irrigating land. [Sp. Amer.]
antibrachium: That part of the fore limb between the brachium and the carpus;the forearm.
albeit: Even though; although; notwithstanding. Chaucer.Albeit so masked, Madam, I love the truth. Tennyson.
alow: Below; in a lower part. "Aloft, and then alow." Dryden.
abstractiveness: The quality of being abstractive; abstractive property.
andantino: Rather quicker than andante; between that allegretto.
adiabatic: Not giving out or receiving heat.-- Ad`i*a*bat`ic*al*ly, adv. Adiabatic line or curve, a curveexhibiting the variations of pressure and volume of a fluid when itexpands without either receiving or giving out heat. Rankine.
amber room: A room formerly in the Czar's Summer Palace in Russia, whichwas richly decorated with walls and fixtures made from amber.  Theamber was removed by occupying German troops during the Second WorldWar and has, as of 1997, never been recovered.  The room is beingrecreated from old photographs by Russian artisans. PJC
anyone: One taken at random rather than by selection; anybody.
aurochs: The European bison (Bison bonasus, or Europæus), once widelydistributed, but now nearly extinct, except where protected in theLithuanian forests, and perhaps in the Caucasus. It is distinct fromthe Urus of Cæsar, with which it has often been confused.
affrighten: To frighten. [Archaic] "Fit tales . . . to affrighten babes."Southey.
atwain: In twain; asunder. [Obs. or Poetic] "Cuts atwain the knots."Tennyson.
authentically: In an authentic manner; with the requisite or genuineauthority.
annotatory: Pertaining to an annotator; containing annotations. [R.]
armillary: Pertaining to, or resembling, a bracelet or ring; consisting ofrings or circles. Armillary sphere, an ancient astronomical machinecomposed of an assemblage of rings, all circles of the same sphere,designed to represent the positions of the important circles of thecelestial sphere. Nichol.
abbatial: Belonging to an abbey; as, abbatial rights.
albinoism: The state or condition of being an albino; albinism.
anemoscope: An instrument which shows the direction of the wind; a windvane; a weathercock; -- usually applied to a contrivance consistingof a vane above, connected in the building with a dial or index withpointers to show the changes of the wind.
anthroposcopy: The art of discovering or judging of a man's character,passions. and inclinations from a study of his visible features. [R.]
adscriptive: Attached or annexed to the glebe or estate and transferablewith it. Brougham.
athecata: A division of Hydroidea in which the zooids are naked, or notinclosed in a capsule. See Tubularian.
aestho-physiology: The science of sensation in relation to nervous action. H.Spenser.
again: Against; also, towards (in order to meet). [Obs.]Albeit that it is again his kind. Chaucer.
amphoral: Pertaining to, or resembling, an amphora.
achiote: Seeds of the annotto tree; also, the coloring matter, annotto.
aegis: A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to theshield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva. Also fig.: A shield; aprotection.
aftertaste: A taste which remains in the mouth after eating or drinking.
acclimature: The act of acclimating, or the state of being acclimated. [R.]Caldwell.
aviseful: Watchful; circumspect. [Obs.]With sharp, aviseful eye. Spenser.
assonance: A peculiar species of rhyme, in which the last accented voweland those which follow it in one word correspond in sound with thevowels of another word, while the consonants of the two words areunlike in sound; as, calamo and platano, baby and chary.The assonance is peculiar to the Spaniard. Hallam.
asaphus: A genus of trilobites found in the Lower Silurian formation.See Illust. in Append.
acuminose: Terminating in a flat, narrow end. Lindley.
ardurous: Burning; ardent. [R.]Lo! further on, Where flames the arduous Spirit of Isidore. Cary.
actinozoal: Of or pertaining to the Actinozoa.
acrogenous: Increasing by growth from the extremity; as, an acrogenousplant.
arrow: A missile weapon of offense, slender, pointed, and usuallyfeathered and barbed, to be shot from a bow. Broad arrow. (a) Anarrow with a broad head. (b) A mark placed upon British ordnance andgovernment stores, which bears a rude resemblance to a broadarrowhead.
anchored: Having the extremities turned back, like the flukes of ananchor; as, an anchored cross. [Sometimes spelt ancred.]
archive: The place in which public records or historic documents arekept.Our words . . . . become records in God's court, and are laid up inhis archives as witnesses. Gov. of Tongue.
alertness: The quality of being alert or on the alert; briskness;nimbleness; activity.
alco: A small South American dog, domesticated by the aborigines.
agglomerate: To wind or collect into a ball; hence, to gather into a mass oranything like a mass.Where he builds the agglomerated pile. Cowper.
anil: A West Indian plant (Indigofera anil), one of the originalsources of indigo; also, the indigo dye.
aminol: A colorless liquid prepared from herring brine and containingamines, used as a local antiseptic.
absque hoc: . Etym: [L., without this.] (Law) The technical words of denialused in traversing what has been alleged, and is repeated.
answer: A counter-statement of facts in a course of pleadings; aconfutation of what the other party has alleged; a responsivedeclaration by a witness in reply to a question. In Equity, it is theusual form of defense to the complainant's charges in his bill.Bouvier.
almost: Nearly; well nigh; all but; for the greatest part.Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian. Acts xxvi. 28.Almost never, scarcely ever.-- Almost nothing, scarcely anything.
archaic: Of or characterized by antiquity or archaism; antiquated;obsolescent.
acetification: The act of making acetous or sour; the process of converting,or of becoming converted, into vinegar.
assentation: Insincere, flattering, or obsequious assent; hypocritical orpretended concurrence.Abject flattery and indiscriminate assentation degrade as much asindiscriminate contradiction and noisy debate disgust. Ld.Chesterfield.
arrowwood: A shrub (Viburnum dentatum) growing in damp woods and thickets;-- so called from the long, straight, slender shoots.
algol: A fixed star, in Medusa's head, in the constellation Perseus,remarkable for its periodic variation in brightness.
appay: To pay; to satisfy or appease. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
aisled: Furnished with an aisle or aisles.
a-mornings: In the morning; every morning. [Obs.]And have such pleasant walks into the woods A-mornings. J. Fletcher.
alinasal: Pertaining to expansions of the nasal bone or cartilage.
abrupt: Suddenly terminating, as if cut off. Gray.
argillo-areenaceous: Consisting of, or containing, clay and sand, as a soil.
animist: One who maintains the doctrine of animism.
axinite: A borosilicate of alumina, iron, and lime, commonly found inglassy, brown crystals with acute edges.
altercate: The contend in words; to dispute with zeal, heat, or anger; towrangle.
articularly: In an articular or an articulate manner.
aperient: Gently opening the bowels; laxative.-- n.
assythment: Indemnification for injury; satisfaction. [Chiefly in Scotslaw]
antitheism: The doctrine of antitheists.-- An`ti*the*is"tic, a.
antenuptial: Preceding marriage; as, an antenuptial agreement. Kent.
animalcule: An animal, invisible, or nearly so, to the naked eye. SeeInfusoria.
antipope: One who is elected, or claims to be, pope in opposition to thepope canonically chosen; esp. applied to those popes who resided atAvignon during the Great Schism.
all: The whole number, quantity, or amount; the entire thing;everything included or concerned; the aggregate; the whole; totality;everything or every person; as, our all is at stake.Death, as the Psalmist saith, is certain to all. Shak.All that thou seest is mine. Gen. xxxi. 43.
aline: To range or place in a line; to bring into line; to align.Evelyn.
accountability: The state of being accountable; liability to be called on torender an account; accountableness. "The awful idea ofaccountability." R. Hall.
appui: A support or supporter; a stay; a prop. [Obs.]If a be to climb trees that are of any great height, there would bestays and appuies set to it. Holland.Point d'appui. Etym: [F., a point of support.] (Mil.) (a) A givenpoint or body, upon which troops are formed, or by which are marchedin line or column. (b) An advantageous defensive support, as acastle, morass, wood, declivity, etc.
audiphone: An instrument which, placed against the teeth, conveys sound tothe auditory nerve and enables the deaf to hear more or lessdistinctly; a dentiphone.
arest: A support for the spear when couched for the attack. [Obs.]Chaucer.
avowable: Capable of being avowed, or openly acknowledged, withconfidence. Donne.
art: The second person singular, indicative mode, present tense, ofthe substantive verb Be; but formed after the analogy of the pluralare, with the ending -t, as in thou shalt, wilt, orig. an ending ofthe second person sing. pret. Cf. Be. Now used only in solemn orpoetical style.
amblyopic: Of or pertaining to amblyopy. Quain.
abjunctive: Exceptional. [R.]It is this power which leads on from the accidental and abjunctive tothe universal. I. Taylor.
agential: Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency. Fitzed. Hall.
adjudgment: The act of adjudging; judicial decision; adjudication. Sir W.Temple.
affair: An action or engagement not of sufficient magnitude to becalled a battle.
agnus scythicus: The Scythian lamb, a kind of woolly-skinned rootstock. SeeBarometz.
abutter: One who, or that which, abuts. Specifically, the owner of acontiguous estate; as, the abutters on a street or a river.
astrophotometer: A photometer for measuring the brightness of stars.
algonkian: The Algonkian period or era, or system or group of systems.
affectionateness: The quality of being affectionate; fondness; affection.
arborization: The appearance or figure of a tree or plant, as in minerals orfossils; a dendrite.
anthropidae: The group that includes man only.
agrom: A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the EastIndies, in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.
anallantoidea: The division of Vertebrata in which no allantois is developed.It includes amphibians, fishes, and lower forms.
arose: The past or preterit tense of Arise.
acclamatory: Pertaining to, or expressing approval by, acclamation.
audile: One whose thoughts take the form of mental sounds or ofinternal discourse rather than of visual or motor images.
anthropoid: Resembling man; -- applied especially to certain apes, as theourang or gorilla.-- n.
arendator: In some provinces of Russia, one who farms the rents orrevenues.
aponeurosis: Any one of the thicker and denser of the deep fasciæ whichcover, invest, and the terminations and attachments of, many muscles.They often differ from tendons only in being flat and thin. SeeFascia.
anti: A prefix meaning against, opposite or opposed to, contrary, orin place of; -- used in composition in many English words. It isoften shortened to ant-; as, antacid, antarctic.
apyretic: Without fever; -- applied to days when there is an intermissionof fever. Dunglison.
affectible: That may be affected. [R.]Lay aside the absolute, and, by union with the creaturely, becomeaffectible. Coleridge.
assembly: A beat of the drum or sound of the bugle as a signal to troopsto assemble.
acontias: Anciently, a snake, called dart snake; now, one of a genus ofreptiles closely allied to the lizards.
aerodynamics: The science which treats of the air and other gaseous bodiesunder the action of force, and of their mechanical effects.
abnormity: Departure from the ordinary type; irregularity; monstrosity."An abnormity . . . like a calf born with two heads." Mrs. Whitney.
anaemia: A morbid condition in which the blood is deficient in qualityor in quantity.
aclinic: Without inclination or dipping; -- said the magnetic needlebalances itself horizontally, having no dip. The aclinic line is alsotermed the magnetic equator. Prof. August.
argentry: Silver plate or vessels. [Obs.]Bowls of frosted argentry. Howell.
admissible: Entitled to be admitted, or worthy of being admitted; that maybe allowed or conceded; allowable; as, the supposition is hardlyadmissible.-- Ad*mis"si*ble*ness, n.-- Ad*mis"si*bly, adv.
asse: A small foxlike animal (Vulpes cama) of South Africa, valuedfor its fur.
ant-hill: A mound thrown up by ants or by termites in forming theirnests.
antler: The entire horn, or any branch of the horn, of a cervineanimal, as of a stag.Huge stags with sixteen antlers. Macaulay.
adorner: He who, or that which, adorns; a beautifier.
acceptability: The quality of being acceptable; acceptableness. "Acceptabilityof repentance." Jer. Taylor.
aggrandizement: The act of aggrandizing, or the state of being aggrandized orexalted in power, rank, honor, or wealth; exaltation; enlargement;as, the emperor seeks only the aggrandizement of his own family.
almandine: The common red variety of garnet.
abnegation: a denial; a renunciation.With abnegation of God, of his honor, and of religion, they mayretain the friendship of the court. Knox.
aland: On land; to the land; ashore. "Cast aland." Sir P. Sidney.
aboma: A large South American serpent (Boa aboma).
amphid: A salt of the class formed by the combination of an acid and abase, or by the union of two oxides, two sulphides, selenides, ortellurides, as distinguished from a haloid compound. [R.] Berzelius.
acuteness: Violence of a disease, which brings it speedily to a crisis.
armament: All the cannon and small arms collectively, with theirequipments, belonging to a ship or a fortification.
acetabulifera: The division of Cephalopoda in which the arms are furnishedwith cup-shaped suckers, as the cuttlefishes, squids, and octopus;the Dibranchiata. See Cephalopoda.
azurite: Blue carbonate of copper; blue malachite.
abrasion: A superficial excoriation, with loss of substance under theform of small shreds. Dunglison.
al-phitomancy: Divination by means of barley meal. Knowles.
anemonin: An acrid, poisonous, crystallizable substance, obtained fromsome species of anemone.
avant-guard: The van or advanced body of an army. See Vanguard.
antipodean: Pertaining to the antipodes, or the opposite side of the world;antipodal.
anthracene oil: A heavy green oil (partially solidifying on cooling), whichdistills over from coal tar at a temperature above 270º. It is theprincipal source of anthracene.
august: Of a quality inspiring mingled admiration and reverence; havingan aspect of solemn dignity or grandeur; sublime; majestic; havingexalted birth, character, state, or authority. "Forms august." Pope."August in visage." Dryden. "To shed that august blood." Macaulay.So beautiful and so august a spectacle. Burke.To mingle with a body so august. Byron.
apporter: A bringer in; an importer. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
allhallow eve: The evening before Allhallows. See Halloween.
artillery wheel: A kind of heavily built dished wheel with a long axle box, usedon gun carriages, usually having 14 spokes and 7 felloes; hence, awheel of similar construction for use on automobiles, etc.
aurantiaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, the Aurantiaceæ, an order ofplants (formerly considered natural), of which the orange is thetype.
anathematization: The act of anathematizing, or denouncing as accursed;imprecation. Barrow.
amylopsin: The diastase of the pancreatic juice.
apposition: The state of two nouns or pronouns, put in the same case,without a connecting word between them; as, I admire Cicero, theorator. Here, the second noun explains or characterizes the first.Growth by apposition (Physiol.), a mode of growth characteristic ofnon vascular tissues, in which nutritive matter from the blood istransformed on the surface of an organ into solid unorganizedsubstance.
afar: At, to, or from a great distance; far away; -- often used withfrom preceding, or off following; as, he was seen from afar; I sawhim afar off.The steep where Fame's proud temple shines afar. Beattie.
acclimatization: The act of acclimatizing; the process of inuring to a newclimate, or the state of being so inured. Darwin.
anthophilous: Lit., fond of flowers; hence, feeding upon, or living among,flowers.
avicularia: See prehensile processes on the cells of some Bryozoa, oftenhaving the shape of a bird's bill.
arabism: An Arabic idiom peculiarly of language. Stuart.
adelphous: Having coalescent or clustered filaments; -- said of stamens;as, adelphous stamens. Usually in composition; as, monadelphous.Gray.
absenteeism: The state or practice of an absentee; esp. the practice ofabsenting one's self from the country or district where one's estateis situated.
aludel: One of the pear-shaped pots open at both ends, and so formed asto be fitted together, the neck of one into the bottom of another insuccession; -- used in the process of sublimation. Ure.
astrogeny: The creation or evolution of the stars or the heavens. H.Spencer.
assuming: Pretentious; taking much upon one's self; presumptuous. Burke.
anthelion: A halo opposite the sun, consisting of a colored ring or ringsaround the shadow of the spectator's own head, as projected on acloud or on an opposite fog bank.
albumen: Nourishing matter stored up within the integuments of the seedin many plants, but not incorporated in the embryo. It is the flourypart in corn, wheat, and like grains, the oily part in poppy seeds,the fleshy part in the cocoanut, etc.
amber seed: Seed of the Hibiscus abelmoschus, somewhat resembling millet,brought from Egypt and the West Indies, and having a flavor like thatof musk; musk seed. Chambers.
anserated: Having the extremities terminate in the heads of eagles, lions,etc.; as, an anserated cross.
aerie: The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also abrood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence orresting place perched like an eagle's nest.
agglutination: Combination in which root words are united with little or nochange of form or loss of meaning. See Agglutinative, 2.
adarce: A saltish concretion on reeds and grass in marshy grounds inGalatia. It is soft and porous, and was formerly used for cleansingthe skin from freckles and tetters, and also in leprosy. Dana.
allemande: A dance in moderate twofold time, invented by the French in thereign of Louis XIV.; -- now mostly found in suites of pieces, likethose of Bach and Handel.
auricularia: A kind of holothurian larva, with soft, blunt appendages. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
astigmatism: A defect of the eye or of a lens, in consequence of which therays derived from one point are not brought to a single focal point,thus causing imperfect images or indistictness of vision.
adar: The twelfth month of the Hebrew ecclesiastical year, and thesixth of the civil. It corresponded nearly with March.
acanthaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of whichthe acanthus is the type.
applier: He who, or that which, applies.
apocarpous: Either entirely of partially separate, as the carpels of acompound pistil; -- opposed to syncarpous. Lindley.
apprizer: A creditor for whom an appraisal is made. Sir W. Scott.
adducible: Capable of being adduced.Proofs innumerable, and in every imaginable manner diversified, areadducible. I. Taylor.
appropriator: A spiritual corporation possessed of an appropriated benefice;also, an impropriator.
antiburgher: One who seceded from the Burghers (1747), deeming it improperto take the Burgess oath.
anemometry: The act or process of ascertaining the force or velocity of thewind.
averpenny: Money paid by a tenant in lieu of the service of average.
ascomycetes: A large class of higher fungi distinguished by septate hyphæ,and by having their spores formed in asci, or spore sacs. Itcomprises many orders, among which are the yeasts, molds, mildews,truffles, morels, etc. -- As`co*my*ce"tous (#), a.
aweary: Weary. [Poetic] "I begin to be aweary of thee." Shak.
adonic: Relating to Adonis, famed for his beauty.-- n.
alienability: Capability of being alienated. "The alienability of thedomain." Burke.
accendible: Capable of being inflamed or kindled; combustible; inflammable.Ure.
acetate: A salt formed by the union of acetic acid with a base orpositive radical; as, acetate of lead, acetate of potash.
authorized: , to rely for authority. [Obs.]Authorizing himself, for the most part, upon other histories. Sir P.Sidney.
amaurotic: Affected with amaurosis; having the characteristics ofamaurosis.
atokous: Producing only asexual individuals, as the eggs of certainannelids.
auget: A priming tube connecting the charge chamber with the gallery,or place where the slow match is applied. Knight.
adversion: A turning towards; attention. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
adipoma: A mass of fat found internally; also, a fatty tumor. --Ad`i*pom"a*tous, a.
aftergrass: The grass that grows after the first crop has been mown;aftermath.
apiked: Trimmed. [Obs.]Full fresh and new here gear apiked was. Chaucer.
acetin: A combination of acetic acid with glycerin. Brande & C.
aesthesia: Perception by the senses; feeling; -- the opposite ofanæsthesia.
atony: Want of tone; weakness of the system, or of any organ,especially of such as are contractile.
apostate: One who, after having received sacred orders, renounces hisclerical profession.
apheliotropism: The habit of bending from the sunlight; -- said of certainplants.
asquint: With the eye directed to one side; not in the straight line ofvision; obliquely; awry, so as to see distortedly; as, to lookasquint.
asthenopia: Weakness of sight. Quain.-- As`the*nop"ic, a.
admortization: The reducing or lands or tenements to mortmain. See Mortmain.
arresting: Striking; attracting attention; impressive.This most solemn and arresting occurrence. J. H. Newman.
aurelian: Of or pertaining to the aurelia.
algonquian: Pertaining to or designating the most extensive of thelinguistic families of North American Indians, their territoryformerly including practically all of Canada east of the 115thmeridian and south of Hudson's Bay and the part of the United Stateseast of the Mississippi and north of Tennessee and Virginia, with theexception of the territory occupied by the northern Iroquoian tribes.There are nearly 100,000 Indians of the Algonquian tribes, of whichthe strongest are the Ojibwas (Chippewas), Ottawas, Crees,Algonquins, Micmacs, and Blackfeet. -- n.
antiarin: A poisonous principle obtained from antiar. Watts.
annotator: A writer of annotations; a commentator.
astrometer: An instrument for comparing the relative amount of the light ofstars.
accomplicity: The act or state of being an accomplice. [R.]
argentation: A coating or overlaying with silver. [R.] Johnson.
acanthocephala: A group of intestinal worms, having the proboscis armed withrecurved spines.
axled: Having an axle; -- used in composition.Merlin's agate-axled car. T. Warton.
actinomycosis: A chronic infectious disease of cattle and man due to thepresence of Actinomyces bovis. It causes local suppurating tumors,esp. about the jaw. Called also lumpy jaw or big jaw. --Ac`ti*no*my*cot"ic (#), a.
aqueduct: A canal or passage; as, the aqueduct of Sylvius, a channelconnecting the third and fourth ventricles of the brain.
antiparallels: Straight lines or planes which make angles in some respectopposite in character to those made by parallel lines or planes.
anaglyptographic: Of or pertaining to anaglyptography; as, analyptographicengraving.
araneose: Of the aspect of a spider's web; arachnoid.
aruspicy: Prognostication by inspection of the entrails of victims slainsacrifice.
annunciable: That may be announced or declared; declarable. [R.]
antagonist: A muscle which acts in opposition to another; as a flexor,which bends a part, is the antagonist of an extensor, which extendsit.
accessoriness: The state of being accessory, or connected subordinately.
amenity: The quality of being pleasant or agreeable, whether in respectto situation, climate, manners, or disposition; pleasantness;civility; suavity; gentleness.A sweetness and amenity of temper. Buckle.This climate has not seduced by its amenities. W. Howitt.
adaw: To subdue; to daunt. [Obs.]The sight whereof did greatly him adaw. Spenser.
archchamberlain: A chief chamberlain; -- an officer of the old German empire,whose office was similar to that of the great chamberlain in England.
ambrosially: After the manner of ambrosia; delightfully. "Smeltambrosially." Tennyson.
aam: A Dutch and German measure of liquids, varying in differentcities, being at Amsterdam about 41 wine gallons, at Antwerp 36½, atHamburg 38¼. [Written also Aum and Awm.]
aculeolate: Having small prickles or sharp points. Gray.
alcoholometry: The process or method of ascertaining the proportion of purealcohol which spirituous liquors contain.
aeromancy: Divination from the state of the air or from atmosphericsubstances; also, forecasting changes in the weather.
acrania: Partial or total absence of the skull.
alamire: The lowest note but one in Guido Aretino's scale of music.
anacharis: A fresh-water weed of the frog's-bit family (Hydrocharidaceæ),native to America. Transferred to England it became an obstruction tonavigation. Called also waterweed and water thyme.
appropriately: In an appropriate or proper manner; fitly; properly.
angevine: Of or pertaining to Anjou in France.-- n. A native of Anjou.
alife: On my life; dearly. [Obs.] "I love that sport alife." Beau. &Fl.
acturience: Tendency or impulse to act. [R.]Acturience, or desire of action, in one form or another, whether asrestlessness, ennui, dissatisfaction, or the imagination of somethingdesirable. J. Grote.
agaric: A fungus of the genus Agaricus, of many species, of which thecommon mushroom is an example.
assyriology: The science or study of the antiquities, language, etc., ofancient Assyria.
allerion: Am eagle without beak or feet, with expanded wings. Burke.
affected: Made up of terms involving different powers of the unknownquantity; adfected; as, an affected equation.
absorptiveness: The quality of being absorptive; absorptive power.
apologist: One who makes an apology; one who speaks or writes in defenseof a faith, a cause, or an institution; especially, one who argues indefense of Christianity.
adverbially: In the manner of an adverb.
amygdalaceous: Akin to, or derived from, the almond.
appellant: Relating to an appeal; appellate. "An appellant jurisdiction."Hallam. Party appellant (Law), the party who appeals; appellant; --opposed to respondent, or appellee. Tomlins.
acanthopterygious: Having fins in which the rays are hard and spinelike; spiny-finned.
althing: The national assembly or parliament of Iceland. See Thing, n.,8.
archtraitor: A chief or transcendent traitor. I. Watts.
alimentiveness: The instinct or faculty of appetite for food. [Chiefly inPhrenol.]
amitosis: Cell division in which there is first a simple cleavage of thenucleus without change in its structure (such as the formation ofchromosomes), followed by the division of the cytoplasm; direct celldivision; -- opposed to mitosis. It is not the usual mode ofdivision, and is believed by many to occur chiefly in highlyspecialized cells which are incapable of long-continuedmultiplication, in transitory structures, and in those in earlystages of degeneration.
acolyctine: An organic base, in the form of a white powder, obtained fromAconitum lycoctonum. Eng. Cyc.
austral: Southern; lying or being in the south; as, austral land;austral ocean. Austral signs (Astron.), the last six signs of thezodiac, or those south of the equator.
abranchiata: A group of annelids, so called because the species composing ithave no special organs of respiration.
anorthoclase: A feldspar closely related to orthoclase, but triclinic. It ischiefly a silicate of sodium, potassium, and aluminium. Sp. gr., 2.57-- 2.60.
apt: To fit; to suit; to adapt. [Obs.] " To apt their places." B.Jonson.That our speech be apted to edification. Jer. Taylor.
athink: To repent; to displease; to disgust. [Obs.] Chaucer.
arbor: A kind of latticework formed of, or covered with, vines,branches of trees, or other plants, for shade; a bower. Sir P.Sidney.
achromatic: Free from color; transmitting light without decomposing it intoits primary colors.
aedile: A magistrate in ancient Rome, who had the superintendence ofpublic buildings, highways, shows, etc.; hence, a municipal officer.
anglo-catholic: Of or pertaining to a church modeled on the EnglishReformation; Anglican; -- sometimes restricted to the ritualistic orHigh Church section of the Church of England.
arousal: The act of arousing, or the state of being aroused.Whatever has associated itself with the arousal and activity of ourbetter nature. Hare.
attollent: Lifting up; raising; as, an attollent muscle. Derham.
autostylic: Having the mandibular arch articulated directly to the cranium,as in the skulls of the Amphibia.
atmo: The standard atmospheric pressure used in certain physicalmeasurements calculations; conventionally, that pressure under whichthe barometer stands at 760 millimeters, at a temperature of 0ºCentigrade, at the level of the sea, and in the latitude of Paris.Sir W. Thomson.
ajar: Slightly turned or opened; as, the door was standing ajar.
appertain: To belong or pertain, whether by right, nature, appointment, orcustom; to relate.Things appertaining to this life. Hooker.Give it unto him to whom it appertaineth. Lev. vi. 5.
assemblyman: A member of an assembly, especially of the lower branch of astate legislature.
anxiously: In an anxious manner; with painful uncertainty; solicitously.
acquisitiveness: The faculty to which the phrenologists attribute the desire ofacquiring and possessing. Combe.
abord: Manner of approaching or accosting; address. Chesterfield.
allhallow: The evening before Allhallows. See Halloween.
agate: On the way; agoing; as, to be agate; to set the bells agate.[Obs.] Cotgrave.
attenuate: To become thin, slender, or fine; to grow less; to lessen.The attention attenuates as its sphere contracts. Coleridge.
adreamed: Visited by a dream; -- used in the phrase, To be adreamed, todream. [Obs.]
atramentaceous: Black, like ink; inky; atramental. [Obs.] Derham.
abrenunciation: Absolute renunciation or repudiation. [Obs.]An abrenunciation of that truth which he so long had professed, andstill believed. Fuller.
abietene: A volatile oil distilled from the resin or balsam of the nutpine (Pinus sabiniana) of California.
asexually: In an asexual manner; without sexual agency.
aeroplane: A flying machine, or a small plane for experiments on flying,which floats in the air only when propelled through it.
abstersiveness: The quality of being abstersive. Fuller.
aurin: A red coloring matter derived from phenol; -- called also, incommerce, yellow coralin.
ammonite: A fossil cephalopod shell related to the nautilus. There aremany genera and species, and all are extinct, the typical formshaving existed only in the Mesozoic age, when they were exceedinglynumerous. They differ from the nautili in having the margins of thesepta very much lobed or plaited, and the siphuncle dorsal. Alsocalled serpent stone, snake stone, and cornu Ammonis.
apothem: The perpendicular from the center to one of the sides of aregular polygon.
amissibility: The quality of being amissible; possibility of being lost. [R.]Notions of popular rights and the amissibility of sovereign power formisconduct were alternately broached by the two great religiousparties of Europe. Hallam.
alioth: A star in the tail of the Great Bear, the one next the bowl inthe Dipper.
avoyer: A chief magistrate of a free imperial city or canton ofSwitzerland. [Obs.]
adversely: In an adverse manner; inimically; unfortunately; contrariwise.
aliner: One who adjusts things to a line or lines or brings them intoline. Evelyn.
achromatization: The act or process of achromatizing.
absinthic: Relating to the common wormwood or to an acid obtained from it.
amylic: Pertaining to, or derived from, amyl; as, amylic ether. Amylicalcohol (Chem.), one of the series of alcohols, a transparent,colorless liquid, having a peculiar odor. It is the hydroxide ofamyl.-- Amylic fermentation (Chem.), a process of fermentation in starchor sugar in which amylic alcohol is produced. Gregory.
amice: A square of white linen worn at first on the head, but nowabout the neck and shoulders, by priests of the Roman Catholic Churchwhile saying Mass.
abandon: To relinquish all claim to; -- used when an insured persongives up to underwriters all claim to the property covered by apolicy, which may remain after loss or damage by a peril insuredagainst.
advocacy: The act of pleading for or supporting; work of advocating;intercession.
adventure: To try the chance; to take the risk.I would adventure for such merchandise. Shak.
aricine: An alkaloid, first found in white cinchona bark.
abortive: Imperfectly formed or developed; rudimentary; sterile; as, anabortive organ, stamen, ovule, etc.
antidiphtheritic: Destructive to, or hindering the growth of, diphtheria bacilli.-- n.
alcoholism: A diseased condition of the system, brought about by thecontinued use of alcoholic liquors.
ambreate: A salt formed by the combination of ambreic acid with a base orpositive radical.
ana-: A prefix in words from the Greek, denoting up, upward,throughout, backward, back, again, anew.
ambient: Encompassing on all sides; circumfused; investing. "Ambientair." Milton. "Ambient clouds." Pope.
attestation: The act of attesting; testimony; witness; a solemn or officialdeclaration, verbal or written, in support of a fact; evidence. Thetruth appears from the attestation of witnesses, or of the properofficer. The subscription of a name to a writing as a witness, is anattestation.
agglutinative: Formed or characterized by agglutination, as a language or acompound.In agglutinative languages the union of words may be compared tomechanical compounds, in inflective languages to chemical compounds.R. Morris.Cf. man-kind, heir-loom, war-like, which are agglutinative compounds.The Finnish, Hungarian, Turkish, the Tamul, etc., are agglutinativelanguages. R. Morris.Agglutinative languages preserve the consciousness of their roots.Max Müller.
aweather: On the weather side, or toward the wind; in the direction fromwhich the wind blows; -- opposed to alee; as, helm aweather ! Totten.
alee: On or toward the lee, or the side away from the wind; theopposite of aweather. The helm of a ship is alee when pressed closeto the lee side. Hard alee, or Luff alee, an order to put the helm tothe lee side.
allowableness: The quality of being allowable; permissibleness; lawfulness;exemption from prohibition or impropriety. South.
alarmed: Aroused to vigilance; excited by fear of approaching danger;agitated; disturbed; as, an alarmed neighborhood; an alarmed modesty.The white pavilions rose and fell On the alarmed air. Longfellow.
aard-wolf: A carnivorous quadruped (Proteles Lalandii), of South Africa,resembling the fox and hyena. See Proteles.
arear: To raise; to set up; to stir up. [Obs.]
asunder: Apart; separate from each other; into parts; in two;separately; into or in different pieces or places.I took my staff, even Beauty, and cut it asunder. Zech. xi. 10.As wide asunder as pole and pole. Froude.
axis: The spotted deer (Cervus axis or Axis maculata) of India, whereit is called hog deer and parrah (Moorish name).
arborist: One who makes trees his study, or who is versed in theknowledge of trees. Howell.
additament: An addition, or a thing added. Fuller.My persuasion that the latter verses of the chapter were anadditament of a later age. Coleridge.
ascetic: Extremely rigid in self-denial and devotions; austere; severe.The stern ascetic rigor of the Temple discipline. Sir W. Scott.
acute: Attended with symptoms of some degree of severity, and comingspeedily to a crisis; -- opposed to chronic; as, an acute disease.Acute angle (Geom.), an angle less than a right angle.
acidity: The quality of being sour; sourness; tartness; sharpness to thetaste; as, the acidity of lemon juice.
adequacy: The state or quality of being adequate, proportionate, orsufficient; a sufficiency for a particular purpose; as, the adequacyof supply to the expenditure.
axinomancy: A species of divination, by means of an ax or hatchet.
a-sea: On the sea; at sea; toward the sea.
acherontic: Of or pertaining to Acheron; infernal; hence, dismal, gloomy;moribund.
apochromatic: Free from chromatic and spherical aberration; -- said esp. of alens in which rays of three or more colors are brought to the samefocus, the degree of achromatism thus obtained being more completethan where two rays only are thus focused, as in the ordinaryachromatic objective. --Ap`o*chro"ma*tism (#), n.
agio: The premium or percentage on a better sort of money when it isgiven in exchange for an inferior sort. The premium or discount onforeign bills of exchange is sometimes called agio.
actuarial: Of or pertaining to actuaries; as, the actuarial value of anannuity.
annotation: A note, added by way of comment, or explanation; -- usually inthe plural; as, annotations on ancient authors, or on a word or apassage.
alcoran: The Mohammedan Scriptures; the Koran (now the usual form).[Spelt also Alcoran.]
ant-lion: A neuropterous insect, the larva of which makes in the sand apitfall to capture ants, etc. The common American species isMyrmeleon obsoletus, the European is M. formicarius.
astoop: In a stooping or inclined position. Gay.
adytum: The innermost sanctuary or shrine in ancient temples, whenceoracles were given. Hence: A private chamber; a sanctum.
archpriest: A chief priest; also, a kind of vicar, or a rural dean.
abreuvoir: The joint or interstice between stones, to be filled withmortar. Gwilt.
administratorship: The position or office of an administrator.
autoplasty: The process of artificially repairing lesions by taking a pieceof healthy tissue, as from a neighboring part, to supply thedeficiency caused by disease or wounds.
accurse: To devote to destruction; to imprecate misery or evil upon; tocurse; to execrate; to anathematize.And the city shall be accursed. Josh. vi. 17.Thro' you, my life will be accurst. Tennyson.
amphibia: One of the classes of vertebrates.
arabin: A carbohydrate, isomeric with cane sugar, contained in gumarabic, from which it is extracted as a white, amorphous substance.
auxiliar: Auxiliary. [Archaic]The auxiliar troops and Trojan hosts appear. Pope.
ayah: A native nurse for children; also, a lady's maid. [India]
aggrade: To bring, or tend to bring, to a uniform grade, or slope, byaddition of material; as, streams aggrade their beds by depositingsediment.
able-minded: Having much intellectual power.-- A`ble-mind"ed*ness, n.
analogism: an argument from the cause to the effect; an a priori argument.Johnson.
administrative: Pertaining to administration; administering; executive; as, anadministrative body, ability, or energy.-- Ad*min"is*tra`tive*ly, adv.
agitato: Sung or played in a restless, hurried, and spasmodic manner.
arminian: Of or pertaining to Arminius of his followers, or to theirdoctrines. See note under Arminian, n.
anthropomorphic: Of or pertaining to anthromorphism. Hadley.-- An`thro*po*mor"phic*al*ly, adv.
abligate: To tie up so as to hinder from. [Obs.]
alehouse: A house where ale is retailed; hence, a tippling house.Macaulay.
apiculture: Rearing of bees for their honey and wax.
archangel: A term applied to several different species of plants (Angelicaarchangelica, Lamium album, etc.).
abb: Among weaves, yarn for the warp. Hence, abb wool is wool forthe abb.
arras: Tapestry; a rich figured fabric; especially, a screen orhangings of heavy cloth with interwoven figures.Stateliest couches, with rich arras spread. Cowper.Behind the arras I'll convey myself. Shak.
asteriscus: The smaller of the two otoliths found in the inner ear of manyfishes.
antepone: To put before; to prefer. [Obs.] Bailey.
averment: A positive statement of facts; an allegation; an offer tojustify or prove what is alleged.
ametabola: A group of insects which do not undergo any metamorphosis.[Written also Ametabolia.]
aider: One who, or that which, aids.
acrimoniousness: The quality of being acrimonious; asperity; acrimony.
argumental: Of, pertaining to, or containing, argument; argumentative.
awakener: One who, or that which, awakens.
alimentariness: The quality of being alimentary; nourishing quality. [R.]
acoumetry: The measuring of the power or extent of hearing.
adelantadillo: A Spanish red wine made of the first ripe grapes.
arthrozoic: Of or pertaining to the Articulata; articulate.
assumpt: To take up; to elevate; to assume. [Obs.] Sheldon.
alcove: A recessed portion of a room, or a small room opening into alarger one; especially, a recess to contain a bed; a lateral recessin a library.
aspiratory: Of or pertaining to breathing; suited to the inhaling of air
armor-plated: Covered with defensive plates of metal, as a ship of war;steel-clad.This day will be launched . . . the first armor-plated steam frigatein the possession of Great Britain. Times (Dec. 29, 1860).
alloy: To form a metallic compound.Gold and iron alloy with ease. Ure.
away-going: Sown during the last years of a tenancy, but not ripe untilafter its expiration; -- said of crops. Wharton.
acipenser: A genus of ganoid fishes, including the sturgeons, having thebody armed with bony scales, and the mouth on the under side of thehead. See Sturgeon.
accused: Charged with offense; as, an accused person.
abelmosk: An evergreen shrub (Hibiscus -- formerly Abelmoschus-moschatus), of the East and West Indies and Northern Africa, whosemusky seeds are used in perfumery and to flavor coffee; -- sometimescalled musk mallow.
atomistic: Of or pertaining to atoms; relating to atomism. [R.]It is the object of the mechanical atomistic philosophy to confoundsynthesis with synartesis. Coleridge.
appendicularia: A genus of small free-swimming Tunicata, shaped somewhat like atadpole, and remarkable for resemblances to the larvæ of otherTunicata. It is the type of the order Copelata or Larvalia. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
absorber: One who, or that which, absorbs.
agent: Actingpatient, or sustaining, action. [Archaic] "The bodyagent." Bacon.
assigner: One who assigns, appoints, allots, or apportions.
aquapuncture: The introduction of water subcutaneously for the relief ofpain.
alebench: A bench in or before an alehouse. Bunyan.
accumulate: To heap up in a mass; to pile up; to collect or bring together;to amass; as, to accumulate a sum of money.
archway: A way or passage under an arch.
apocryphalist: One who believes in, or defends, the Apocrypha. [R.]
auxiliary: Conferring aid or help; helping; aiding; assisting; subsidiary;as auxiliary troops. Auxiliary scales (Mus.), the scales of relativeor attendant keys. See under Attendant, a.-- Auxiliary verbs (Gram.). See Auxiliary, n., 3.
assertory: Affirming; maintaining.Arguments . . . assertory, not probatory. Jer. Taylor.An assertory, not a promissory, declaration. Bentham.A proposition is assertory, when it enounces what is known as actual.Sir W. Hamilton.
accordant: Agreeing; consonant; harmonious; corresponding; conformable; --followed by with or to.Strictly accordant with true morality. Darwin.And now his voice accordant to the string. Coldsmith.
appetition: Desire; a longing for, or seeking after, something. Holland.
aposteme: An abscess; a swelling filled with purulent matter. [Writtencorruptly imposthume.]
articulate: An animal of the subkingdom Articulata.
almuce: Same as Amice, a hood or cape.
attractive: That which attracts or draws; an attraction; an allurement.Speaks nothing but attractives and invitation. South.
archduchess: The consort of an archduke; also, a princess of the imperialfamily of Austria. See Archduke.
adjectively: In the manner of an adjective; as, a word used adjectively.
aromatic: A plant, drug, or medicine, characterized by a fragrant smell,and usually by a warm, pungent taste, as ginger, cinnamon spices.
anorthosite: A granular igneous rock composed almost exclusively of a soda-lime feldspar, usually labradorite.
arbitratrix: A female who arbitrates or judges.
age: To grow aged; to become old; to show marks of age; as, he grewfat as he aged.They live one hundred and thirty years, and never age for all that.Holland.I am aging; that is, I have a whitish, or rather a light-colored,hair here and there. Landor.
asparagine: A white, nitrogenous, crystallizable substance, C4H8N2O3+H2O,found in many plants, and first obtained from asparagus. It isbelieved to aid in the disposition of nitrogenous matter throughoutthe plant; -- called also altheine.
agglutinate: To unite, or cause to adhere, as with glue or other viscoussubstance; to unite by causing an adhesion of substances.
adaptedness: The state or quality of being adapted; suitableness; specialfitness.
antiphonal: Of or pertaining to antiphony, or alternate singing; sungalternately by a divided choir or opposite choirs. Wheatly.-- An*tiph"o*nal*ly, adv.
actinophone: An apparatus for the production of sound by the action of theactinic, or ultraviolet, rays.
absonant: Discordant; contrary; -- opposed to consonant. "Absonant tonature." Quarles.
associator: An associate; a confederate or partner in any scheme.How Pennsylvania's air agrees with Quakers, And Carolina's withassociators. Dryden.
antisocial: Tending to interrupt or destroy social intercourse; averse tosociety, or hostile to its existence; as, antisocial principles.
abreast: Side by side; also, opposite; over against; on a line with thevessel's beam; -- with of.
ambiparous: Characterized by containing the rudiments of both flowers andleaves; -- applied to a bud.
amphirhina: A name applied to the elasmobranch fishes, because the nasalsac is double.
artiste: One peculiarly dexterous and tasteful in almost any employment,as an opera dancer, a hairdresser, a cook.
admirer: One who admires; one who esteems or loves greatly. Cowper.
antihelix: The curved elevation of the cartilage of the ear, within or infront of the helix. See Ear.
affreighter: One who hires or charters a ship to convey goods.
annulus: Ring-shaped structures or markings, found in, or upon, variousanimals.
abasement: The act of abasing, humbling, or bringing low; the state ofbeing abased or humbled; humiliation.
abiogenesis: The supposed origination of living organisms from lifelessmatter; such genesis as does not involve the action of livingparents; spontaneous generation; -- called also abiogeny, and opposedto biogenesis.I shall call the . . . doctrine that living matter may be produced bynot living matter, the hypothesis of abiogenesis. Huxley, 1870.
anodon: A genus of fresh-water bivalves, having to teeth at the hinge.[Written also Anodonta.]
acheron: A river in the Nether World or infernal regions; also, theinfernal regions themselves. By some of the English poets it wassupposed to be a flaming lake or gulf. Shak.
ampullaceous: Like a bottle or inflated bladder; bottle-shaped; swelling.Kirby. Ampullaceous sac (Zoöl.), one of the peculiar cavities in thetissues of sponges, containing the zooidal cells.
absorptive: Having power, capacity, or tendency to absorb or imbibe. E.Darwin.
accustom: To make familiar by use; to habituate, familiarize, or inure; -- with to.I shall always fear that he who accustoms himself to fraud in littlethings, wants only opportunity to practice it in greater. Adventurer.
aura: The peculiar sensation, as of a light vapor, or cold air,rising from the trunk or limbs towards the head, a premonitorysymptom of epilepsy or hysterics. Electric ~, a supposed electricfluid, emanating from an electrified body, and forming a masssurrounding it, called the electric atmosphere. See Atmosphere, 2.
antichronism: Deviation from the true order of time; anachronism. [R.]Selden.
adder: One who, or that which, adds; esp., a machine for addingnumbers.
atmiatry: Treatment of disease by vapors or gases, as by inhalation.
affabrous: Executed in a workmanlike manner; ingeniously made. [R.]Bailey.
alleviator: One who, or that which, alleviaties.
ablaqueate: To lay bare, as the roots of a tree. [Obs.] Bailey.
accuser: One who accuses; one who brings a charge of crime or fault.
ambrite: A fossil resin occurring in large masses in New Zealand.
asserter: One who asserts; one who avers pr maintains; an assertor.The inflexible asserter of the rights of the church. Milman.
ashamed: Affected by shame; abashed or confused by guilt, or aconviction or consciousness of some wrong action or impropriety. "Iam ashamed to beg." Wyclif.All that forsake thee shall be ashamed. Jer. xvii. 13.I began to be ashamed of sitting idle. Johnson.Enough to make us ashamed of our species. Macaulay.An ashamed person can hardly endure to meet the gaze of thosepresent. Darwin.
altruistic: Regardful of others; beneficent; unselfish; -- opposed to Ant:egoistic or Ant: selfish. Bain.-- Al`tru*is"tic*al*ly, adv.
associate: Connected by habit or sympathy; as, associate motions, such asoccur sympathetically, in consequence of preceding motions. E.Darwin.
after-wit: Wisdom or perception that comes after it can be of use. "After-wit comes too late when the mischief is done." L'Estrange.
antimonious: Pertaining to, or derived from, antimony; -- said of thosecompounds of antimony in which this element has an equivalence nextlower than the highest; as, antimonious acid.
assured: Made sure; safe; insured; certain; indubitable; not doubting;bold to excess.
aspersed: Having an indefinite number of small charges scattered orstrewed over the surface. Cussans.
architective: Used in building; proper for building. Derham.
acquest: Property acquired by purchase, gift, or otherwise than byinheritance. Bouvier.
azygous: Odd; having no fellow; not one of a pair; single; as, theazygous muscle of the uvula.
adatis: A fine cotton cloth of India.
astrography: The art of describing or delineating the stars; a descriptionor mapping of the heavens.
air jacket: A jacket having air-tight cells, or cavities which can befilled with air, to render persons buoyant in swimming.
accretive: Relating to accretion; increasing, or adding to, by growth.Glanvill.
alcoranic: Of or pertaining to the Koran.
apostemate: To form an abscess; to swell and fill with pus. Wiseman.
agamogenetic: Reproducing or produced without sexual union.-- Ag`a*mo*ge*net"ic*al*ly, adv.All known agamogenetic processes end in a complete return to theprimitive stock. Huxley.
anode: The positive pole of an electric battery, or more strictly theelectrode by which the current enters the electrolyte on its way tothe other pole; -- opposed to cathode.
absorbent: Absorbing; swallowing; absorptive. Absorbent ground (Paint.), aground prepared for a picture, chiefly with distemper, or watercolors, by which the oil is absorbed, and a brilliancy is imparted tothe colors.
aloe: The wood of the agalloch. [Obs.] Wyclif.
alfenide: An alloy of nickel and silver electroplated with silver.
aceldama: The potter's field, said to have lain south of Jerusalem,purchased with the bribe which Judas took for betraying his Master,and therefore called the field of blood. Fig.: A field of bloodshed.The system of warfare . . . which had already converted immensetracts into one universal aceldama. De Quincey.
annuloid: Of or pertaining to the Annuloida.
arc: A portion of a curved line; as, the arc of a circle or of anellipse.
abortionist: One who procures abortion or miscarriage.
annulosa: A division of the Invertebrata, nearly equivalent to theArticulata. It includes the Arthoropoda and Anarthropoda. By somezoölogists it is applied to the former only.
athetosis: A variety of chorea, marked by peculiar tremors of the fingersand toes.
adeptness: The quality of being adept; skill.
arrester: The person at whose suit an arrestment is made. [Also writtenarrestor.]
achillean: Resembling Achilles, the hero of the Iliad; invincible.
anna: An East Indian money of account, the sixteenth of a rupee, orabout 2
antiquate: To make old, or obsolete; to make antique; to make old in sucha degree as to put out of use; hence, to make void, or abrogate.Christianity might reasonably introduce new laws, and antiquate orabrogate old one. Sir M. Hale.
auction pitch: A game of cards in which the players bid for the privilege ofdetermining or "pitching" the trump suit.  R. F. Foster.
alkalamide: One of a series of compounds that may be regarded as ammonia inwhich a part of the hydrogen has been replaced by basic, and anotherpart by acid, atoms or radicals.
anecdotage: Anecdotes collectively; a collection of anecdotes.All history, therefore, being built partly, and some of italtogether, upon anecdotage, must be a tissue of lies. De Quincey.
amber: A yellowish translucent resin resembling copal, found as afossil in alluvial soils, with beds of lignite, or on the seashore inmany places. It takes a fine polish, and is used for pipemouthpieces, beads, etc., and as a basis for a fine varnish. Byfriction, it becomes strongly electric.
advene: To accede, or come (to); to be added to something or become apart of it, though not essential. [R.]Where no act of the will advenes as a coefficient. Coleridge.
automobile: An automobile vehicle or mechanism; esp., a self-propelledvehicle suitable for use on a street or roadway. Automobiles areusually propelled by internal combustion engines (using volatileinflammable liquids, as gasoline or petrol, alcohol, naphtha, etc.),steam engines, or electric motors. The power of the driving motorvaries from about 4 to 50 H. P. for ordinary vehicles, ranging fromthe run-about to the touring car, up to as high as 200 H. P. forspecially built racing cars. Automobiles are also commonly, andgenerally in British usage, called motor cars.
alguazil: An inferior officer of justice in Spain; a warrant officer; aconstable. Prescott.
approvable: Worthy of being approved; meritorious.-- Ap*prov"a*ble*ness, n.
aethogen: A compound of nitrogen and boro
animalculism: The theory which seeks to explain certain physiological andpathological by means of animalcules.
accidie: Sloth; torpor. [Obs.] "The sin of accidie." Chaucer.
