alas: An exclamation expressive of sorrow, pity, or apprehension ofevil; -- in old writers, sometimes followed by day or white; alas theday, like alack a day, or alas the white.
agrise: To shudder with terror; to tremble with fear. [Obs.] Chaucer.
arthrotome: A strong scalpel used in the dissection of joints.
aponeurotic: Of or pertaining to an aponeurosis.
apostrophe: A figure of speech by which the orator or writer suddenlybreaks off from the previous method of his discourse, and addresses,in the second person, some person or thing, absent or present; as,Milton's apostrophe to Light at the beginning of the third book of"Paradise Lost."
absquatulate: To take one's self off; to decamp. [A jocular word. U. S.]
approval: Approbation; sanction.A censor . . . without whose approval nTemple.
aphotic region: A depth of water so great that only those organisms can existthat do not assimilate.
acerbate: To sour; to imbitter; to irritate.
arbitral: Of or relating to an arbiter or an arbitration. [R.]
abele: The white polar (Populus alba).Six abeles i' the churchyard grow. Mrs. Browning.
accendibility: Capacity of being kindled, or of becoming inflamed;inflammability.
assuasive: Mitigating; tranquilizing; soothing. [R.]Music her soft assuasive voice applies. Pope.
ammeter: A contraction of amperometer or ampèremeter.
atomizer: One who, or that which, atomizes; esp., an instrument forreducing a liquid to spray for disinfecting, cooling, or perfuming.
abandonment: The relinquishment by the insured to the underwriters of whatmay remain of the property insured after a loss or damage by a perilinsured against.
actualization: A making actual or really existent. [R.] Emerson.
ardassine: A very fine sort of Persian silk.
arbitrarily: In an arbitrary manner; by will only; despotically; absolutely.
antepaschal: Pertaining to the time before the Passover, or before Easter.
aliquant: An aliquant part of a number or quantity is one which does notdivide it without leaving a remainder; thus, 5 is an aliquant part of16. Opposed to aliquot.
atlantes: Figures or half figures of men, used as columns to support anentablature; -- called also telamones. See Caryatides. Oxf. Gloss.
architectural: Of or pertaining to the art of building; conformed to the rulesof architecture.-- Ar`chi*tec"tur*al*ly, adv.
aid-de-camp: An officer selected by a general to carry orders, also toassist or represent him in correspondence and in directing movements.
acarina: The group of Arachnida which includes the mites and ticks. Manyspecies are parasitic, and cause diseases like the itch and mange.
avouchment: The act of avouching; positive declaration. [Obs.] Milton.
acatalectic: Not defective; complete; as, an acatalectic verse.-- n.
analyst: One who analyzes; formerly, one skilled in algebraicalgeometry; now commonly, one skilled in chemical analysis.
assibilate: To make sibilant; to change to a sibilant. J. Peile.
arapaima: A large fresh-water food fish of South America.
acalephoid: Belonging to or resembling the Acalephæ or jellyfishes.
arshine: A Russian measure of length = 2 ft. 4.246 inches.
assai: A direction equivalent to very; as, adagio assai, very slow.
anastatic: Pertaining to a process or a style of printing from charactersin relief on zinc plates.
antilogous: Of the contrary name or character; -- opposed to analogous.Antilogous pole (Eccl.), that pole of a crystal which becomesnegatively electrified when heated.
aphorismer: A dealer in aphorisms. [Used in derogation or contempt.]Milton.
attar: A fragrant essential oil; esp., a volatile and highly fragrantessential oil obtained from the petals of roses. [Also written ottoand ottar.]
appanagist: A prince to whom an appanage has been granted.
angler: A fish (Lophius piscatorius), of Europe and America, having alarge, broad, and depressed head, with the mouth very large. Peculiarappendages on the head are said to be used to entice fishes withinreach. Called also fishing frog, frogfish, toadfish, goosefish,allmouth, monkfish, etc.
aitchbone: The bone of the rump; also, the cut of beef surrounding thisbone. [Spelt also edgebone.]
angles: An ancient Low German tribe, that settled in Britain, whichcame to be called Engla-land (Angleland or England). The Anglesprobably came from the district of Angeln (now within the limits ofSchleswig), and the country now Lower Hanover, etc.
aldine: An epithet applied to editions (chiefly of the classics) whichproceeded from the press of Aldus Manitius, and his family, ofVenice, for the most part in the 16th century and known by the signof the anchor and the dolphin. The term has also been applied tocertain elegant editions of English works.
almond furnace: A kind of furnace used in refining, to separate the metal fromcinders and other foreign matter. Chambers.
alliteral: Pertaining to, or characterized by alliteration.
abominableness: The quality or state of being abominable; odiousness. Bentley.
abrahamic: Pertaining to Abraham, the patriarch; as, the Abrachamiccovenant.
allecret: A kind of light armor used in the sixteenth century, esp. bythe Swiss. Fairholt.
amassette: An instrument of horn used for collecting painters' colors onthe stone in the process of grinding.
ashen: Of or pertaining to the ash tree. "Ashen poles." Dryden.
aegilops: An ulcer or fistula in the inner corner of the eye.
antiphonary: A book containing a collection of antiphons; the book in whichthe antiphons of the breviary, with their musical notes, arecontained.
attornment: The act of a feudatory, vassal, or tenant, by which heconsents, upon the alienation of an estate, to receive a new lord orsuperior, and transfers to him his homage and service; the agreementof a tenant to acknowledge the purchaser of the estate as hislandlord. Burrill. Blackstone.
areopagus: The highest judicial court at Athens. Its sessions were held onMars' Hill. Hence, any high court or tribunal
agrope: In the act of groping. Mrs. Browning.
aration: Plowing; tillage. [R.]Lands are said to be in a state of aration when they are undertillage. Brande.
algin: A nitrogenous substance resembling gelatin, obtained fromcertain algæ.
anthological: Pertaining to anthology; consisting of beautiful extracts fromdifferent authors, especially the poets.He published a geographical and anthological description of allempires and kingdoms . . . in this terrestrial globe. Wood.
appetibility: The quality of being desirable. Bramhall.
acrospire: The sprout at the end of a seed when it begins to germinate;the plumule in germination; -- so called from its spiral form.
amelioration: The act of ameliorating, or the state of being ameliorated;making or becoming better; improvement; melioration. "Amelioration ofhuman affairs." J. S. Mill.
antiorgastic: Tending to allay venereal excitement or desire; sedative.
ariolation: A soothsaying; a foretelling. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
alkaloid: An organic base, especially one of a class of substancesoccurring ready formed in the tissues of plants and the bodies ofanimals.
avengement: The inflicting of retributive punishment; satisfaction taken.[R.] Milton.
actinometric: Pertaining to the measurement of the intensity of the solarrays, either (a) heating, or (b) actinic.
army organization: The system by which a country raises, classifies, arranges, andequips its armed land forces. The usual divisions are: (1) A regularor active army, in which soldiers serve continuously with the colorsand live in barracks or cantonments when not in the field; (2) thereserves of this army, in which the soldiers, while remainingconstantly subject to a call to the colors, live at their homes,being summoned more or less frequently to report for instruction,drill, or maneuvers; and (3) one or more classes of soldiersorganized largely for territorial defense, living at home and havingonly occasional periods of drill and instraction, who are variouslycalled home reserves (as in the table below), second, third, etc.,line of defense (the regular army and its reserves ordinarilyconstituting the first line of defense), territorial forces, or thelike. In countries where conscription prevails a soldier is supposedto serve a given number of years.  He is usually enrolled first inthe regular army, then passes to its reserve, then into the homereserves, to serve until he reaches the age limit. It for any reasonhe is not enrolled in the regular army, he may begin his service inthe army reserves or even the home reserves, but then serves the fullnumber of years or up to the age limit. In equipment the organizationof the army is into the three great arms of infantry, cavalry, andartillery, together with more or less numerous other branches, suchas engineers, medical corps, etc., besides the staff organizationssuch as those of the pay and subsistence departments.
appropinquation: A drawing nigh; approach. [R.] Bp. Hall.
abdominous: Having a protuberant belly; pot-bellied.Gorgonius sits, abdominous and wan, Like a fat squab upon a Chinesefan. Cowper.
about: On the point or verge of; going; in act of.Paul was now aboutto open his mouth. Acts xviii. 14.
abundant: Fully sufficient; plentiful; in copious supply; -- followed byin, rarely by with. "Abundant in goodness and truth." Exod. xxxiv. 6.Abundant number (Math.), a number, the sum of whose aliquot partsexceeds the number itself. Thus, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, the aliquot parts of12, make the number 16. This is opposed to a deficient number, as 14,whose aliquot parts are 1, 2, 7, the sum of which is 10; and to aperfect number, which is equal to the sum of its aliquot parts, as 6,whose aliquot parts are 1, 2., 3.
apishly: In an apish manner; with servile imitation; foppishly.
after-image: The impression of a vivid sensation retained by the retina ofthe eye after the cause has been removed; also extended toimpressions left of tones, smells, etc.
anathematizer: One who pronounces an anathema. Hammond.
approvedly: So as to secure approbation; in an approved manner.
agiotage: Exchange business; also, stockjobbing; the maneuvers ofspeculators to raise or lower the price of stocks or public funds.Vanity and agiotage are to a Parisian the oxygen and hydrogen oflife. Landor.
abatvoix: The sounding-board over a pulpit or rostrum.
argentalium: A (patented) alloy of aluminium and silver, with a density ofabout 2.9.
azobenzene: A substance (C6H5.N2.C6H5) derived from nitrobenzene, formingorange red crystals which are easily fusible.
almonry: The place where an almoner resides, or where alms aredistributed.
alpha rays: Rays of relatively low penetrating power emitted by radium andother radioactive substances, and shown to consist of positivelycharged particles (perhaps particles of helium) having enormousvelocities but small masses. They are slightly deflected by a strongmagnetic or electric field.
aphetic: Shortened by dropping a letter or a syllable from the beginningof a word; as, an aphetic word or form.-- A*phet"ic*al*ly, adv. New Eng. Dict.
acrophony: The use of a picture symbol of an object to representphonetically the initial sound of the name of the object.
acanthopterygian: Belonging to the order of fishes having spinose fins, as theperch.-- n.
archtreasurer: A chief treasurer. Specifically, the great treasurer of theGerman empire.
aerocurve: A modification of the aëroplane, having curved surfaces, theadvantages of which were first demonstrated by Lilienthal.
agible: Possible to be done; practicable. [Obs.] "Fit for agiblethings." Sir A. Sherley.
autocratorical: Pertaining to an autocrator; absolute. [Obs.] Bp. Pearson.
annuity: A sum of money, payable yearly, to continue for a given numberof years, for life, or forever; an annual allowance.
agastric: Having to stomach, or distinct digestive canal, as thetapeworm.
ataxic: Characterized by ataxy, that is, (a) by great irregularity offunctions or symptoms, or (b) by a want of coordinating power inmovements. Ataxic fever, malignant typhus fever. Pinel.
arc light: The light of an arc lamp.
administratrix: A woman who administers; esp., one who administers the estateof an intestate, or to whom letters of administration have beengranted; a female administrator.
attacca: Attack at once; -- a direction at the end of a movement to showthat the next is to follow immediately, without any pause.
agreeingly: In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably. [Obs.]
appropriateness: The state or quality of being appropriate; peculiar fitness.Froude.
affluxion: The act of flowing towards; afflux. Sir T. Browne.
apagoge: An indirect argument which proves a thing by showing theimpossibility or absurdity of the contrary.
absolution: An acquittal, or sentence of a judge declaring and accusedperson innocent. [Obs.]
additory: Tending to add; making some addition. [R.] Arbuthnot.
adore: To adorn. [Obs.]Congealed little drops which do the morn adore. Spenser.
acotyledon: A plant which has no cotyledons, as the dodder and allflowerless plants.
asyndetic: Characterized by the use of asyndeton; not connected byconjunctions.-- As`yn*det"ic*al*ly, adv.
archi-: A prefix signifying chief, arch; as, architect, archiepiscopal.In Biol. and Anat. it usually means primitive, original, ancestral;as, archipterygium, the primitive fin or wing.
appropriable: Capable of being appropriated, set apart, sequestered, orassigned exclusively to a particular use. Sir T. Browne.
ally: See Alley, a marble or taw.
ayme: The utterance of the ejaculation "Ay me !" [Obs.] See Ay,interj. "Aymees and hearty heigh-hoes." J. Fletcher.
aubaine: Succession to the goods of a stranger not naturalized. Littré.Droit d'aubaine (, the right, formerly possessed by the king ofFrance, to all the personal property of which an alien diedpossessed. It was abolished in 1819. Bouvier.
aphilanthropy: Want of love to mankind; -- the opposite of philanthropy. Coxe.
abstractness: The quality of being abstract. "The abstractness of the ideas."Locke.
acetylene: A gaseous compound of carbon and hydrogen, in the proportion oftwo atoms of the former to two of the latter. It is a colorless gas,with a peculiar, unpleasant odor, and is produced for use as anilluminating gas in a number of ways, but chiefly by the action ofwater on calcium carbide. Its light is very brilliant. Watts.
astrometry: The art of making measurements among the stars, or ofdetermining their relative magnitudes.
arrogance: The act or habit of arrogating, or making undue claims in anoverbearing manner; that species of pride which consists inexorbitant claims of rank, dignity, estimation, or power, or whichexalts the worth or importance of the person to an undue degree;proud contempt of others; lordliness; haughtiness; self-assumption;presumption.I hate not you for her proud arrogance. Shak.
assimilatory: Tending to assimilate, or produce assimilation; as,assimilatory organs.
anility: The state of being and old woman; old-womanishness; dotage."Marks of anility." Sterne.
antibacchius: A foot of three syllables, the first two long, and the lastshort.
adverbiality: The quality of being adverbial. Earle.
armilla: A ring of hair or feathers on the legs.
apoplectic: One liable to, or affected with, apoplexy.
adventurousness: The quality or state of being adventurous; daring;venturesomeness.
armorial: Belonging to armor, or to the heraldic arms or escutcheon of afamily.Figures with armorial signs of race and birth. Wordsworth.Armorial bearings. See Arms, 4.
antiar: A Virulent poison prepared in Java from the gum resin of onespecies of the upas tree (Antiaris toxicaria).
ambiguity: The quality or state of being ambiguous; doubtfulness oruncertainty, particularly as to the signification of language,arising from its admitting of more than one meaning; an equivocalword or expression.No shadow of ambiguity can rest upon the course to be pursued. I.Taylor.The words are of single signification, without any ambiguity. South.
adenology: The part of physiology that treats of the glands.
adnascent: Growing to or on something else. "An adnascent plant." Evelyn.
abaser: He who, or that which, abases.
adonean: Pertaining to Adonis; Adonic. "Fair Adonean Venus." Faber.
azotite: A salt formed by the combination of azotous, or nitrous, acidwith a base; a nitrite. [R.]
archbishopric: The jurisdiction or office of an archbishop; the see orprovince over which archbishop exercises archiepiscopal authority.
applicate: Applied or put to some use.Those applicate sciences which extend the power of man over theelements. I. Taylor.Applicate number (Math.), one which applied to some concrete case.-- Applicate ordinate, right line applied at right angles to theaxis of any conic section, and bounded by the curve.
associative: Having the quality of associating; tending or leading toassociation; as, the associative faculty. Hugh Miller.
applot: To divide into plots or parts; to apportion. Milton.
astonishing: Very wonderful; of a nature to excite astonishment; as, anastonishing event.
applicatory: Having the property of applying; applicative; practical.-- n.
ass: A quadruped of the genus Equus (E. asinus), smaller than thehorse, and having a peculiarly harsh bray and long ears. The tame ordomestic ass is patient, slow, and sure-footed, and has become thetype of obstinacy and stupidity. There are several species of wildasses which are swift-footed.
additional: Added; supplemental; in the way of an addition.
affirm: to assert or confirm, as a judgment, decree, or order, broughtbefore an appelate court for review.
ailantus: A genus of beautiful trees, natives of the East Indies. Thetree imperfectly di
asexualization: The act or process of sterilizing an animal or human being, asby vasectomy.
antozone: A compound formerly supposed to be modification of oxygen, butnow known to be hydrogen dioxide; -- so called because apparentlyantagonistic to ozone, converting it into ordinary oxygen.
adnominal: Pertaining to an adnoun; adjectival; attached to a noun. Gibbs.-- Ad*nom"i*nal*ly, adv.
ante mortem: Before death; -- generally used adjectivelly; as, an ante-mortem statement; ante-mortem examination.
apostatical: Apostate.An heretical and apostatical church. Bp. Hall.
areometer: An instrument for measuring the specific gravity of fluids; aform hydrometer.
aspire: To aspire to; to long for; to try to reach; to mount to. [Obs.]That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds. Shak.
aphthong: A letter, or a combination of letters, employed in spelling aword, but in the pronunciation having no sound.-- Aph*thon"gal, a.
atropism: A condition of the system produced by long use of belladonna.
afresh: Anew; again; once more; newly.They crucify . . . the Son of God afresh. Heb. vi. 6.
annals: The record of a single event or item. "In deathless annal."Young.
acumination: A sharpening; termination in a sharp point; a tapering point.Bp. Pearson.
amplectant: Clasping a support; as, amplectant tendrils. Gray.
archipelagic: Of or pertaining to an archipelago.
anura: One of the orders of amphibians characterized by the absence ofa tail, as the frogs and toads. [Written also anoura.]
affiliable: Capable of being affiliated to or on, or connected with inorigin.
anisocoria: Inequality of the pupils of the eye.
annumeration: Addition to a former number. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
annoying: That annoys; molesting; vexatious.-- An*noy"ing*ly, adv.
ark shell: A marine bivalve shell belonging to the genus Arca and itsallies.
arbor vitae: An evergreen tree of the cypress tribe, genus Thuja. TheAmerican species is the T. occidentalis.
abdest: Purification by washing the hands before prayer; -- aMohammedan rite. Heyse.
abdal: A religious devotee or dervish in Persia.
aculeated: Having a sharp point; armed with prickles; prickly; aculeate.
apollo: A deity among the Greeks and Romans. He was the god of lightand day (the "sun god"), of archery, prophecy, medicine, poetry, andmusic, etc., and was represented as the model of manly grace andbeauty; -- called also Phébus. The Apollo Belvedere, a celebratedstatue of Apollo in the Belvedere gallery of the Vatican palace atRome, esteemed of the noblest representations of the human frame.
anyhow: In any way or manner whatever; at any rate; in any event.Anyhow, it must be acknowledged to be not a simple selforiginatederror. J. H. Newman.Anyhow, the languages of the two nations were closely allied. E. A.Freeman.
argus shell: A species of shell (Cypræa argus), beautifully variegated withspots resembling those in a peacock's tail.
adulter: To commit adultery; to pollute. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
aspish: Pertaining to, or like, an asp.
asiatic: Of or pertaining to Asia or to its inhabitants.-- n.
atellan: Of or pertaining to Atella, in ancient Italy; as, Atellanplays; farcical; ribald.-- n.
aphanitic: Resembling aphanite; having a very fine-grained structure.
anthracomancy: Divination by inspecting a burning coal.
arcturus: A fixed star of the first magnitude in the constellationBoötes.
as: An ace. [Obs.] Chaucer. Ambes-as, double aces.
aflat: Level with the ground; flat. [Obs.] Bacon.
annueler: A priest employed in saying annuals, or anniversary Masses.[Obs.] Chaucer.
amygdalate: Pertaining to, resembling, or made of, almonds.
arthrology: That part of anatomy which treats of joints.
attrectation: Frequent handling or touching. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
another-gaines: Of another kind. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
apus: A genus of fresh-water phyllopod crustaceans. See Phyllopod.
anarch: The author of anarchy; one who excites revolt. Milton.Imperial anarchs doubling human woes. Byron.
assober: To make or keep sober. [Obs.] Gower.
antonym: A word of opposite meaning; a counterterm; -- used as acorrelative of synonym. [R.] C. J. Smith.
antipapal: Opposed to the pope or to popery. Milton.
anelectrotonus: The condition of decreased irritability of a nerve in theregion of the positive electrode or anode on the passage of a currentof electricity through it. Foster.
alveary: The hollow of the external ear. Quincy.
abraxas: A mystical word used as a charm and engraved on gems among theancients; also, a gem stone thus engraved.
awing: On the wing; flying; fluttering. Wallace.
antero-: A combining form meaning anterior, front; as, antero-posterior,front and back; antero-lateral, front side, anterior and at the side.
alignment: The ground-plan of a railway or other road, in distinction fromthe grades or profile.
adumbrant: Giving a faint shadow, or slight resemblance; shadowing forth.
abjudicate: To reject by judicial sentence; also, to abjudge. [Obs.] Ash.
ascidian: One of the Ascidioidea, or in a more general sense, one of theTunicata. Also as an adj.
asemia: Loss of power to express, or to understand, symbols or signs ofthought.
annulose: Of or pertaining to the Annulosa.
aside: Something spoken aside; as, a remark made by a stageplayerwhich the other players are not supposed to hear.
adjudicate: To adjudge; to try and determine, as a court; to settle byjudicial decree.
auchenium: The part of the neck nearest the back.
albuminin: The substance of the cells which inclose the white of birds'eggs.
arouse: To excite to action from a state of rest; to stir, or put inmotion or exertion; to rouse; to excite; as, to arouse one fromsleep; to arouse the dormant faculties.Grasping his spear, forth issued to arouse His brother, mightysovereign on the host. Cowper.No suspicion was aroused. Merivale.
alphonsine: Of or relating to Alphonso X., the Wise, King of Castile (1252-1284). Alphonsine tables, astronomical tables prepared under thepatronage of Alphonso the Wise. Whewell.
argot: A secret language or conventional slang peculiar to thieves,tramps, and vagabonds; flash.
agnatic: Pertaining to descent by the male line of ancestors. "Theagnatic succession." Blackstone.
amarantaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of whichthe amaranth is the type.
above-cited: Cited before, in the preceding part of a book or writing.
anaptychus: One of a pair of shelly plates found in some cephalopods, asthe ammonites.
apophasis: A figure by which a speaker formally declines to take notice ofa favorable point, but in such a manner as to produce the effectdesired. [For example, see Mark Antony's oration. Shak., JuliusCæsar, iii. 2.]
articular: Of or pertaining to the joints; as, an articular disease; anarticular process.
adscript: Held to service as attached to the soil; -- said of feudalserfs.
avocate: To call off or away; to withdraw; to transfer to anothertribunal. [Obs. or Archaic]One who avocateth his mind from other occupations. Barrow.He, at last, . . . avocated the cause to Rome. Robertson.
astony: To stun; to bewilder; to astonish; to dismay. [Archaic]The captain of the Helots . . . strake Palladius upon the side of hishead, that he reeled astonied. Sir P. Sidney.This sodeyn cas this man astonied so, That reed he wex, abayst, andal quaking. Chaucer.
arming: A piece of tallow placed in a cavity at the lower end of asounding lead, to bring up the sand, shells, etc., of the sea bottom.Totten.
almucantar: A small circle of the sphere parallel to the horizon; a circleor parallel of altitude. Two stars which have the same almucantarhave the same altitude. See Almacantar. [Archaic] Almucanter staff,an ancient instrument, having an arc of fifteen degrees, formerlyused at sea to take observations of the sun's amplitude at the timeof its rising or setting, to find the variation of the compass.
alienist: One who treats diseases of the mind. Ed. Rev.
apologue: A story or relation of fictitious events, intended to conveysome moral truth; a moral fable.
admove: To move or conduct to or toward. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
andante: Moving moderately slow, but distinct and flowing; quicker thanlarghetto, and slower than allegretto.-- n.
athlete: One who contended for a prize in the public games of ancientGreece or Rome.
aeolic: Æolian, 1; as, the Æolic dialect; the Æolic mode.
agasp: In a state of gasping. Coleridge.
associateship: The state of an associate, as in Academy or an office.
anharmonic: Not harmonic. The anharmonic function or ratio of four pointsabcd on a straight line is the quantity (ac/ad):(bc/bd), where thesegments are to regarded as plus or minus, according to the order ofthe letters.
affordment: Anything given as a help; bestowal. [Obs.]
apposable: Capable of being apposed, or applied one to another, as thethumb to the fingers of the hand.
arthromere: One of the body segments of Arthropods. See Arthrostraca.Packard.
altiscope: An arrangement of lenses and mirrors which enables a person tosee an object in spite of intervening objects.
abashment: The state of being abashed; confusion from shame.
assort: To agree; to be in accordance; to be adapted; to suit; to fallinto a class or place. Mitford.
authenticness: The quality of being authentic; authenticity. [R.] Hammond.
antennule: A small antenna; -- applied to the smaller pair of antennæ orfeelers of Crustacea.
ameliorate: To make better; to improve; to meliorate.In every human being there is a wish to ameliorate his own condition.Macaulay.
arrantly: Notoriously, in an ill sense; infamously; impudently;shamefully. L'Estrange.
asphalte: Asphaltic mastic or cement. See Asphalt, 2.
angulation: A making angular; angular formation. Huxley.
advertent: Attentive; heedful; regardful. Sir M. Hale.-- Ad*vert"ent*ly, adv.
acropodium: The entire upper surface of the foot.
abatement: A mark of dishonor on an escutcheon.
atimy: Public disgrace or stigma; infamy; loss of civil rights.Mitford.
amber fish: A fish of the southern Atlantic coast (Seriola Carolinensis.)
admittance: The act of giving possession of a copyhold estate. Bouvier.
adam: "Original sin;" human frailty.And whipped the offending Adam out of him. Shak.Adam's ale, water. [Coll.] -- Adam's apple.
allomorphism: The property which constitutes an allomorph; the changeinvolved in becoming an allomorph.
acquire: To gain, usually by one's own exertions; to get as one's own;as, to acquire a title, riches, knowledge, skill, good or bad habits.No virtue is acquired in an instant, but step by step. Barrow.Descent is the title whereby a man, on the death of his ancestor,acquires his estate, by right of representation, as his heir at law.Blackstone.
angularly: In an angular manner; with of at angles or corners. B. Jonson.
ardor: Bright and effulgent spirits; seraphim. [Thus used by Milton.]
agriologist: One versed or engaged in agriology.
accompaniment: That which accompanies; something that attends as acircumstance, or which is added to give greater completeness to theprincipal thing, or by way of ornament, or for the sake of symmetry.Specifically: (Mus.)
amphiblastic: Segmenting unequally; -- said of telolecithal ova with completesegmentation.
angrily: In an angry manner; under the influence of anger.
aberrate: To go astray; to diverge. [R.]Their own defective and aberrating vision. De Quincey.
abduce: To draw or conduct away; to withdraw; to draw to a differentpart. [Obs.]If we abduce the eye unto either corner, the object will notduplicate. Sir T. Browne.
animastic: Pertaining to mind or spirit; spiritual.
assertor: One who asserts or avers; one who maintains or vindicates aclaim or a right; an affirmer, supporter, or vindicator; a defender;an asserter.The assertors of liberty said not a word. Macaulay.Faithful assertor of thy country's cause. Prior.
adieu: Good-by; farewell; an expression of kind wishes at parting.
acceptable: Capable, worthy, or sure of being accepted or received withpleasure; pleasing to a receiver; gratifying; agreeable; welcome; as,an acceptable present, one acceptable to us.
aldermanly: Pertaining to, or like, an alderman.
almagra: A fine, deep red ocher, somewhat purplish, found in Spain. Itis the sil atticum of the ancients. Under the name of Indian red itis used for polishing glass and silver.
anamorphism: A gradual progression from one type to another, generallyascending. Huxley.
avant-courier: A person dispatched before another person or company, to givenotice of his or their approach.
adminicular: Supplying help; auxiliary; corroborative; explanatory; as,adminicular evidence. H. Spencer.
audient: Listening; paying attention; as, audient souls. Mrs. Browning.
approximately: With approximation; so as to approximate; nearly.
auditive: Of or pertaining to hearing; auditory. [R.] Cotgrave.
alcoholize: An instrument for determining the strength of spirits, with ascale graduated so as to indicate the percentage of pure alcohol,either by weight or volume. It is usually a form of hydrometer with aspecial scale.
aestival: Of or belonging to the summer; as, æstival diseases. [Speltalso estival.]
antetemple: The portico, or narthex in an ancient temple or church.
apodosis: The consequent clause or conclusion in a conditional sentence,expressing the result, and thus distinguished from the protasis orclause which expresses a condition. Thus, in the sentence, "Though heslay me, yet will I trust in him," the former clause is the protasis,and the latter the apodosis.
arvicole: A mouse of the genus Arvicola; the meadow mouse. There are manyspecies.
anxietude: The state of being anxious; anxiety. [R.]
anorthite: A mineral of the feldspar family, commonly occurring in smallglassy crystals, also a constituent of some igneous rocks. It is alime feldspar. See Feldspar.
anelectric: Not becoming electrified by friction; -- opposed toidioelectric.-- n.
arace: To tear up by the roots; to draw away. [Obs.] Wyatt.
anticlinorium: The upward elevation of the crust of the earth, resulting froma geanticlinal.
acephala: That division of the Mollusca which includes the bivalveshells, like the clams and oysters; -- so called because they have noevident head. Formerly the group included the Tunicata, Brachiopoda,and sometimes the Bryozoa. See Mollusca.
actinostome: The mouth or anterior opening of a coelenterate animal.
argent: Whiteness; anything that is white.The polished argent of her breast. Tennyson.
aethrioscope: An instrument consisting in part of a differential thermometer.It is used for measuring changes of temperature produced by differentconditions of the sky, as when clear or clouded.
autunite: A lemon-yellow phosphate of uranium and calcium occurring intabular crystals with basal cleavage, and in micalike scales. H., 2-2.5. Sp. gr., 3.05-3.19.
allegation: A statement by a party of what he undertakes to prove, --usually applied to each separate averment; the charge or matterundertaken to be proved.
apteryges: An order of birds, including the genus Apteryx.
adolescency: The quality of being adolescent; youthfulness.
antitype: That of which the type pattern or representation; that which isrepresented by the type or symbol.
agonic: Not forming an angle. Agonic line (Physics), an imaginary lineon the earth's surface passing through those places where themagnetic needle points to the true north; the line of no magneticvariation. There is one such line in the Western hemisphere, andanother in the Eastern hemisphere.
alcalde: A magistrate or judge in Spain and in Spanish America, etc.Prescott.
audible: Capable of being heard; loud enough to be heard; actuallyheard; as, an audible voice or whisper.
australasian: Of or pertaining to Australasia; as, Australasian regions.-- n.
abecedarian: Pertaining to, or formed by, the letters of the alphabet;alphabetic; hence, rudimentary. Abecedarian psalms, hymns, etc.,compositions in which (like the 119th psalm in Hebrew) distinctportions or verses commence with successive letters of the alphabet.Hook.
airily: In an airy manner; lightly; gaily; jauntily; fippantly.
aroint: Stand off, or begone. [Obs.]Aroint thee, witch, the rump-fed ronyon cries. Shak.
abjectness: The state of being abject; abasement; meanness; servility.Grew.
accumbent: Lying against anything, as one part of a leaf against anotherleaf. Gray.Accumbent cotyledons have their edges placed against the caulicle.Eaton.
absolutist: One who believes that it is possible to realize a cognition orconcept of the absolute. Sir. W. Hamilton.
alveolar: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, alveoli or little cells,sacs, or sockets. Alveolar processes, the processes of the maxillarybones, containing the sockets of the teeth.
asura: An enemy of the gods, esp. one of a race of demons and giants.
anonymousness: The state or quality of being anonymous. Coleridge.
automatism: The state or quality of being automatic; the power of self-moving; automatic, mechanical, or involuntary action. (Metaph.) Atheory as to the activity of matter.
adulterant: That which is used to adulterate anything.-- a. Adulterating; as, adulterant agents and processes.
apostle: A brief letter dimissory sent by a court appealed from to thesuperior court, stating the case, etc.; a paper sent up on appeals inthe admiralty courts. Wharton. Burrill. Apostles' creed, a creed ofunknown origin, which was formerly ascribed to the apostles. Itcertainly dates back to the beginning of the sixth century, and someassert that it can be found in the writings of Ambrose in the fourthcentury.-- Apostle spoon (Antiq.), a spoon of silver, with the handleterminating in the figure of an apostle. One or more were offered bysponsors at baptism as a present to the godchild. B. Jonson.
ant-cattle: Various kinds of plant lice or aphids tended by ants for thesake of the honeydew which they secrete. See Aphips.
athletics: The art of training by athletic exercises; the games and sportsof athletes.
alluvium: Deposits of earth, sand, gravel, and other transported matter,made by rivers, floods, or other causes, upon land not permanentlysubmerged beneath the waters of lakes or seas. Lyell.
alliance: To connect by alliance; to ally. [Obs.]
alkermes: A compound cordial, in the form of a confection, deriving itsname from the kermes insect, its principal ingredient.
antilegomena: Certain books of the New Testament which were for a time notuniversally received, but which are now considered canonical. Theseare the Epistle to the Hebrews, the Epistles of James and Jude, thesecond Epistle of Peter, the second and third Epistles of John, andthe Revelation. The undisputed books are called the Homologoumena.
agonism: Contention for a prize; a contest. [Obs.] Blount.
addeem: To award; to adjudge. [Obs.] "Unto him they did addeem theprise." Spenser.
anglo-saxondom: The Anglo-Saxon domain (i. e., Great Britain and the UnitedStates, etc.); the Anglo-Saxon race.
antiattrition: Anything to prevent the effects of friction, esp. a compoundlubricant for machinery, etc., often consisting of plumbago, withsome greasy material; antifriction grease.
anubis: An Egyptian deity, the conductor of departed spirits,represented by a human figure with the head of a dog or fox.
acrodont: One of a group of lizards having the teeth immovably united tothe top of the alveolar ridge.-- a. Of or pertaining to the acrodonts.
ascription: The act of ascribing, imputing, or affirming to belong; also,that which is ascribed.
arches: pl. of Arch, n. Court of arches, or Arches Court (Eng. Law),the court of appeal of the Archbishop of Canterbury, whereof thejudge, who sits as deputy to the archbishop, is called the Dean ofthe Arches, because he anciently held his court in the church of St.Mary-le-Bow (de arcubus). It is now held in Westminster. Mozley & W.
anecdotal: Pertaining to, or abounding with, anecdotes; as, anecdotalconversation.
anacrotism: A secondary notch in the pulse curve, obtained in asphygmographic tracing.
annotative: Characterized by annotations; of the nature of annotation.
anemorphilous: Fertilized by the agency of the wind; -- said of plants inwhich the pollen is carried to the stigma by the wind; wind-Fertilized. Lubbock.
alkalize: To render alkaline; to communicate the properties of an alkalito.
appulsion: A driving or striking against; an appulse.
accreditation: The act of accrediting; as, letters of accreditation.
accouple: To join; to couple. [R.]The Englishmen accoupled themselves with the Frenchmen. Hall.
absently: In an absent or abstracted manner.
afraid: Impressed with fear or apprehension; in fear; apprehensive.[Afraid comes after the noun it limits.] "Back they recoiled,afraid." Milton.
aphelion: That point of a planet's or comet's orbit which is most distantfrom the sun, the opposite point being the perihelion.
anticathode: The part of a vacuum tube opposite the cathode. Upon it thecathode rays impinge.
archaeozoic: Like or belonging to the earliest forms of animal life.
amphictyonic: Of or pertaining to the Amphictyons or their League or Council;as, an Amphictyonic town or state; the Amphictyonic body. W. Smith.
affiche: A written or printed notice to be posted, as on a wall; aposter; a placard.
aport: On or towards the port or left side; -- said of the helm.
appraisal: A valuation by an authorized person; an appraisement.
acroterial: Pertaining to an acroterium; as, ornaments. P. Cyc.
argus: A fabulous being of antiquity, said to have had a hundred eyes,who has placed by Juno to guard Io. His eyes were transplanted to thepeacock's tail.
anthroposophy: Knowledge of the nature of man; hence, human wisdom.
assibilation: Change of a non-sibilant letter to a sibilant, as of -tion to -shun, duke to ditch.
arsenious: Pertaining to, or derived from, arsenic, when having anequivalence next lower than the highest; as, arsenious acid.
admissibility: The quality of being admissible; admissibleness; as, theadmissibility of evidence.
ashantee: A native or an inhabitant of Ashantee in Western Africa.
argulus: A genus of copepod Crustacea, parasitic of fishes; a fishlouse. See Branchiura.
affectionated: Disposed; inclined. [Obs.]Affectionated to the people. Holinshed.
analyze: To subject to analysis; to resolve (anything complex) into itselements; to separate into the constituent parts, for the purpose ofan examination of each separately; to examine in such a manner as toascertain the elements or nature of the thing examined; as, toanalyze a fossil substance; to analyze a sentence or a word; toanalyze an action to ascertain its morality.No one, I presume, can analyze the sensations of pleasure or pain.Darwin.
adducent: Bringing together or towards a given point; -- a word appliedto those muscles of the body which pull one part towards another.Opposed to abducent.
antinomianism: The tenets or practice of Antinomians. South.
avellane: In the form of four unhusked filberts; as, an avellane cross.
antimonial: Of or pertaining to antimony.-- n. (Med.)
aesthete: One who makes much or overmuch of æsthetics. [Recent]
acception: Acceptation; the received meaning. [Obs.]Here the word "baron" is not to be taken in that restrictive sense towhich the modern acception hath confined it. Fuller.Acception of persons or faces (Eccl.), favoritism; partiality. [Obs.]Wyclif.
altitudinarian: Lofty in doctrine, aims, etc. [R.] Coleridge.
acidulent: Having an acid quality; sour; acidulous. "With anxious,acidulent face." Carlyle.
annulment: The act of annulling; abolition; invalidation.
antemosaic: Being before the time of Moses.
adduction: The action by which the parts of the body are drawn towards itsaxis]; -- opposed to abduction. Dunglison.
alnage: Measurement (of cloth) by the ell; also, a duty for suchmeasurement.
arboretum: A place in which a collection of rare trees and shrubs iscultivated for scientific or educational purposes.
abyssal: Belonging to, or resembling, an abyss; unfathomable. Abyssalzone (Phys. Geog.), one of the belts or zones into which Sir E.Forbes divides the bottom of the sea in describing its plants,animals, etc. It is the one furthest from the shore, embracing allbeyond one hundred fathoms deep. Hence, abyssal animals, plants, etc.
abba: Father; religious superior; -- in the Syriac, Coptic, andEthiopic churches, a title given to the bishops, and by the bishopsto the patriarch.
annotate: To explain or criticize by notes; as, to annotate the works ofBacon.
ancientness: The quality of being ancient; antiquity; existence from oldtimes.
abusiveness: The quality of being abusive; rudeness of language, or violenceto the person.Pick out mirth, like stones out of thy ground, Profaneness,filthiness, abusiveness. Herbert.
abaca: The Manila-hemp plant (Musa textilis); also, its fiber. SeeManila hemp under Manila.
alcedo: A genus of perching birds, including the European kingfisher(Alcedo ispida). See Halcyon.
ant-bear: An edentate animal of tropical America (the Tamanoir), livingon ants. It belongs to the genus Myrmecophaga.
arch stone: A wedge-shaped stone used in an arch; a voussoir.
abeam: On the beam, that is, on a line which forms a right angle withthe ship's keel; opposite to the center of the ship's side.
arrenotokous: Producing males from unfertilized eggs, as certain wasps andbees.
assot: To besot; to befool; to beguile; to infatuate. [Obs.]Some ecstasy assotted had his sense. Spenser.
argentine: A siliceous variety of calcite, or carbonate of lime, having asilvery-white, pearly luster, and a waving or curved lamellarstructure.
arnica: A genus of plants; also, the most important species (Arnicamontana), native of the mountains of Europe, used in medicine as anarcotic and stimulant.
athermancy: Inability to transmit radiant; impermeability to heat. Tyndall.
aorist: A tense in the Greek language, which expresses an action ascompleted in past time, but leaves it, in other respects, whollyindeterminate.
adonize: To beautify; to dandify.I employed three good hours at least in adjusting and adonozingmyself. Smollett.
atterrate: To fill up with alluvial earth. [Obs.] Ray.
antiqueness: The quality of being antique; an appearance of ancient originand workmanship.We may discover something venerable in the antiqueness of the work.Addison.
achlamydate: Not possessing a mantle; -- said of certain gastropods.
admirative: Relating to or expressing admiration or wonder. [R.] Earle.
apparatus: A collection of organs all of which unite in a common function;as, the respiratory apparatus.
astacus: A genus of crustaceans, containing the crawfish of fresh-waterlobster of Europe, and allied species of western North America. SeeCrawfish.
athermanous: Not transmitting heat; -- opposed to diathermanous.
augite: A variety of pyroxene, usually of a black or dark green color,occurring in igneous rocks, such as basalt; -- also used instead ofthe general term pyroxene.
aspidobranchia: A group of Gastropoda, with limpetlike shells, including theabalone shells and keyhole limpets.
ahriman: The Evil Principle or Being of the ancient Persians; the Princeof Darkness as opposer to Ormuzd, the King of Light.
agriology: Description or comparative study of the customs of savage oruncivilized tribes.
antepast: A foretaste.Antepasts of joy and comforts. Jer. Taylor.
armed: Having horns, beak, talons, etc; -- said of beasts and birds ofprey. Armed at all points (Blazoning), completely incased in armor,sometimes described as armed cap-à-pie. Cussans.-- Armed en flute. (Naut.) See under Flute.-- Armed magnet, a magnet provided with an armature.-- Armed neutrality. See under Neutrality.
army worm: The wild buffalo of India (Bos, or Bubalus, arni), larger thanthe domestic buffalo and having enormous horns.
according: Agreeing; in agreement or harmony; harmonious. "This accordingvoice of national wisdom." Burke. "Mind and soul according well."Tennyson.According to him, every person was to be bought. Macaulay.Our zeal should be according to knowledge. Sprat.
alterability: The quality of being alterable; alterableness.
antipasch: The Sunday after Easter; Low Sunday.
acroceraunian: Of or pertaining to the high mountain range of "thunder-smitten" peaks (now Kimara), between Epirus and Macedonia. Shelley.
auction bridge: A variety of the game of bridge in which the players, beginningwith the dealer, bid for the privilege of naming the trump andplaying with the dummy for that deal, there being heavy penalties fora player's failure to make good his bid. The score value of eachtrick more than six taken by the successful bidder is as follows:when the trump is spades, 2; clubs, 6; diamonds, 7; hearts, 8; royalspades (lilies), 9; and when the deal is played with no trump, 10.
anatomist: One who is skilled in the art of anatomy, or dissection.
appearance: The coming into court of either of the parties; the beingpresent in court; the coming into court of a party summoned in anaction, either by himself or by his attorney, expressed by a formalentry by the proper officer to that effect; the act or proceeding bywhich a party proceeded against places himself before the court, andsubmits to its jurisdiction. Burrill. Bouvier. Daniell. To put in anappearance, to be present; to appear in person.-- To save appearances, to preserve a fair outward show.
annexment: The act of annexing, or the thing annexed; appendage. [R.]Shak.
antherogenous: Transformed from anthers, as the petals of a double flower.
autonomasy: The use of a word of common or general signification for thename of a particular thing; as, "He has gone to town," for, "He hasgone to London."
acorn-shell: One of the sessile cirripeds; a barnacle of the genus Balanus.See Barnacle.
accustomedness: Habituation.Accustomedness to sin hardens the heart. Bp. Pearce.
apositic: Destroying the appetite, or suspending hunger.
altern: Acting by turns; alternate. Milton. Altern base (Trig.), asecond side made base, in distinction from a side previously regardedas base.
accost: To adjoin; to lie alongside. [Obs.] "The shores which to thesea accost." Spenser.
ariose: Characterized by melody, as distinguished from harmony.Mendelssohn wants the ariose beauty of Handel; vocal melody is nothis forte; the interest of his airs harmonic. Foreign Quart. Rev.
averseness: The quality of being averse; opposition of mind; unwillingness.
anagrammatize: To transpose, as the letters of a word, so as to form ananagram. Cudworth.
agood: In earnest; heartily. [Obs.] "I made her weep agood."  Shak.
alcornoque: The bark of several trees, esp. of Bowdichia virgilioides ofBrazil, used as a remedy for consumption; of Byrsonima crassifolia,used in tanning; of Alchornea latifolia, used medicinally; or ofQuercus ilex, the cork tree.
amygdaline: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, almonds.
apposed: Placed in apposition; mutually fitting, as the mandibles of abird's beak.
asbestic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling asbestus; inconsumable;asbestine.
araneous: Cobweblike; extremely thin and delicate, like a cobweb; as, thearaneous membrane of the eye. See Arachnoid. Derham.
anthorism: A description or definition contrary to that which is given bythe adverse party. [R.]
antithet: An antithetic or contrasted statement. Bacon.
ance: A suffix signifying action; also, quality or state; as,assistance, resistance, appearance, elegance. See -ancy.
adhesiveness: Propensity to form and maintain attachments to persons, and topromote social intercourse.
anatiferous: Producing ducks; -- applied to Anatifæ, under the absurd notionof their turning into ducks or geese. See Barnacle.
aleconner: Orig., an officer appointed to look to the goodness of ale andbeer; also, one of the officers chosen by the liverymen of London toinspect the measures used in public houses. But the office is asinecure. [Also called aletaster.] [Eng.]
apperception: The mind's perception of itself as the subject or actor in itsown states; perception that reflects upon itself; sometimes,intensified or energetic perception. Leibnitz. Reid.This feeling has been called by philosophers the apperception orconsciousness of our own existence. Sir W. Hamilton.
ant-eater: One of several species of edentates and monotremes that feedupon ants. See Ant-bear, Pangolin, Aard-vark, and Echidna.
albuminosis: A morbid condition due to excessive increase of albuminouselements in the blood.
adroitness: The quality of being adroit; skill and readiness; dexterity.Adroitness was as requisite as courage. Motley.
anaesthesia: Entire or partial loss or absence of feeling or sensation; astate of general or local insensibility produced by disease or by theinhalation or application of an anæsthetic.
alb: A vestment of white linen, reaching to the feet, an envelopingthe person; -- in the Roman Catholic church, worn by those in holyorders when officiating at mass. It was formerly worn, at least byclerics, in daily life.
algerine: Of or pertaining to Algiers or Algeria.
anthropophaginian: One who east human flesh. [Ludicrous] Shak.
allelomorph: One of the pure unit characters commonly existing singly or inpairs in the germ cells of Mendelian hybrids, and exhibited invarying proportion among the organisms themselves. Allelomorphs whichunder certain circumstances are themselves compound are calledhypallelomorphs. See Mendel's law. -- Al*le`lo*mor"phic (#), a.
azalea: A genus of showy flowering shrubs, mostly natives of China orof North America; false honeysuckle. The genus is scarcely distinctfrom Rhododendron.
asmonean: Of or pertaining to the patriotic Jewish family to which theMaccabees belonged; Maccabean; as, the Asmonean dynasty. [Writtenalso Asmonæan.]
aphemia: Loss of the power of speaking, while retaining the power ofwriting; -- a disorder of cerebral origin.
agraphia: The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by writtensigns. It is one form of aphasia.
aimless: Without aim or purpose; as, an aimless life.-- Aim"less*ly, adv.-- Aim"less*ness, n.
apportionment: The act of apportioning; a dividing into just proportions orshares; a division or shares; a division and assignment, to eachproprietor, of his just portion of an undivided right or property. A.Hamilton.
addition: That part of arithmetic which treats of adding numbers.
afflictive: Giving pain; causing continued or repeated pain or grief;distressing. "Jove's afflictive hand." Pope.Spreads slow disease, and darts afflictive pain. Prior.
arundinaceous: Of or pertaining to a reed; resembling the reed or cane.
air plant: A plant deriving its sustenance from the air alone; anaërophyte.
australize: To tend toward the south pole, as a magnet. [Obs.]They [magnets] do septentrionate at one extreme, and australize atanother. Sir T. Browne.
acanthus: A genus of herbaceous prickly plants, found in the south ofEurope, Asia Minor, and India; bear's-breech.
aggroup: To bring together in a group; to group. Dryden.
acorn: A cone-shaped piece of wood on the point of the spindle abovethe vane, on the mast-head.
armory: A thick plain silk, generally black, and used for clerical.Simmonds.
abirritate: To diminish the sensibility of; to debilitate.
accelerator: One who, or that which, accelerates. Also as an adj.; as,accelerator nerves.
angelize: To raise to the state of an angel; to render angelic.It ought not to be our object to angelize, nor to brutalize, but tohumanize man. W. Taylor.
annodated: Curved somewhat in the form of the letter S. Cussans.
appearer: One who appears. Sir T. Browne.
apneumatic: Devoid of air; free from air; as, an apneumatic lung; also,effected by or with exclusion of air; as, an apneumatic operation.
anchor space: In the balk-line game, any of eight spaces, 7 inches by 3½,lying along a cushion and bisected transversely by a balk line.Object balls in an anchor space are treated as in balk.
antiperiodic: A remedy possessing the property of preventing the return ofperiodic paroxysms, or exacerbations, of disease, as in intermittentfevers.
azotize: To impregnate with azote, or nitrogen; to nitrogenize.
air brush: A kind of atomizer for applying liquid coloring matter in aspray by compressed air.
autodynamic: Supplying its own power; -- applied to an instrument of thenature of a water-ram.
agminal: Pertaining to an army marching, or to a train. [R.]
attache: One attached to another person or thing, as a part of a suiteor staff. Specifically: One attached to an embassy.
argental: Of or pertaining to silver; resembling, containing, or combinedwith, silver.
aria: An air or song; a melody; a tune.
acetabuliform: Shaped like a shallow; saucer-shaped; as, an acetabuliformcalyx. Gray.
apocryphally: In an apocryphal manner; mythically; not indisputably.
aslope: Slopingly; aslant; declining from an upright direction;sloping. "Set them not upright, but aslope." Bacon.
afterpains: The pains which succeed childbirth, as in expelling theafterbirth.
attrition: Grief for sin arising only from fear of punishment or feelingsof shame. See Contrition. Wallis.
anthobranchia: A division of nudibranchiate Mollusca, in which the gills forma wreath or cluster upon the posterior part of the back. SeeNudibranchiata, and Doris.
afore: In the fore part of a vessel.
alcaic: Pertaining to Alcæus, a lyric poet of Mitylene, about 6000 b.c.-- n. A kind of verse, so called from Alcæus. One variety consistsof five feet, a spondee or iambic, an iambic, a long syllable, andtwo dactyls.
acaridan: One of a group of arachnids, including the mites and ticks.
aswail: The sloth bear (Melursus labiatus) of India.
alizari: The madder of the Levant. Brande & C.
assuredly: Certainly; indubitably. "The siege assuredly I'll raise." Shak.
apophlegmatic: Designed to facilitate discharges of phlegm or mucus from mouthor nostrils.-- n.
archaeology: The science or study of antiquities, esp. prehistoricantiquities, such as the remains of buildings or monuments of anearly epoch, inscriptions, implements, and other relics, writtenmanuscripts, etc.
amyl: A hydrocarbon radical, C5H11, of the paraffine series found inamyl alcohol or fusel oil, etc.
aptote: A noun which has no distinction of cases; an indeclinable noun.
affiliation: The establishment or ascertaining of parentage; the assignmentof a child, as a bastard, to its father; filiation.
assertorial: Asserting that a thing is; -- opposed to problematical andapodeictical.
algometer: An instrument for measuring sensations of pain due to pressure.It has a piston rod with a blunted tip which is pressed against theskin. -- Al*gom"e*try (#), n. -- Al`go*met"ric (#), *met"ric*al (#),a. --Al`go*met"ric*al*ly, adv.
aepyornis: A gigantic bird found fossil in Madagascar.
anglo-: A combining form meaning the same as English; or English and,or English conjoined with; as, Anglo-Turkish treaty, Anglo-German,Anglo-Irish. Anglo-American, . Of or pertaining to the English andAmericans, or to the descendants of Englishmen in America.-- n. A descendant from English ancestors born in America, or theUnited States. Anglo-Danish, a. Of or pertaining to the English andDanes, or to the Danes who settled in England. Anglo-Indian, a. Of orpertaining to the English in India, or to the English and East Indianpeoples or languages.-- n. One of the Anglo-Indian race born or resident in the EastIndies. Anglo-Norman, a. Of or pertaining to the English and Normans,or to the Normans who settled in England.-- n. One of the English Normans, or the Normans who conqueredEngland. Anglo-Saxon. See Anglo-Saxon in the Vocabulary.
appallment: Depression occasioned by terror; dismay. [Obs.] Bacon.
avale: To descend; to fall; to dismount. [Obs.]And from their sweaty courses did avale. Spenser.
assiento: A contract or convention between Spain and other powers forfurnishing negro slaves for the Spanish dominions in America, esp.the contract made with Great Britain in 1713.
alula: A false or bastard wing. See under Bastard.
atmometer: An instrument for measuring the rate of evaporation from amoist surface; an evaporometer. Huxley.
assyrian: Of or pertaining to Assyria, or to its inhabitants.-- n. A native or an inhabitant of Assyria; the language of Assyria.
arsenal: A public establishment for the storage, or for the manufactureand storage, of arms and all military equipments, whether for land ornaval service.
argillo-calcareous: Consisting of, or containing, clay and calcareous earth.
atrede: To surpass in council. [Obs.]Men may the olde atrenne, but hat atrede. Chaucer.
asparagus: A genus of perennial plants belonging to the natural orderLiliaceæ, and having erect much branched stems, and very slenderbranchlets which are sometimes mistaken for leaves. Asparagusracemosus is a shrubby climbing plant with fragrant flowers.Specifically: The Asparagus officinalis, a species cultivated ingardens.
accumbency: The state of being accumbent or reclining. [R.]
achromatopsy: Color blindness; inability to distinguish colors; Daltonism.
astrophotometry: The determination of the brightness of stars, and also of thesun, moon, and planets. --As`tro*pho`to*met"ric*al (#), a.
atramentarious: Like ink; suitable for making ink. Sulphate of iron (copperas,green vitriol) is called atramentarious, as being used in making ink.
atresia: Absence or closure of a natural passage or channel of the body;imperforation.
aerophyte: A plant growing entirely in the air, and receiving itsnourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.
accelerative: Relating to acceleration; adding to velocity; quickening. Reid.
anallagmatic: Not changed in form by inversion. Anallagmatic curves, a classof curves of the fourth degree which have certain peculiar relationsto circles; -- sometimes called bicircular quartics.-- Anallagmatic surfaces, a certain class of surfaces of the fourthdegree.
audaciously: In an audacious manner; with excess of boldness; impudently.
angelify: To make like an angel; to angelize. [Obs.] Farindon (1647).
abator: (a) One who abates a nuisance. (b) A person who, without right,enters into a freehold on the death of the last possessor, before theheir or devisee. Blackstone.
absinthial: Of or pertaining to wormwood; absinthian.
alcohol: A class of compounds analogous to vinic alcohol inconstitution. Chemically speaking, they are hydroxides of certainorganic radicals; as, the radical ethyl forms common or ethyl alcohol(C2H5OH); methyl forms methyl alcohol (CH3.OH) or wood spirit; amylforms amyl alcohol (C5H11.OH) or fusel oil, etc.
articulus: A joint of the cirri of the Crinoidea; a joint or segment of anarthropod appendage.
applicable: Capable of being applied; fit or suitable to be applied; havingrelevance; as, this observation is applicable to the case underconsideration.-- Ap"pli*ca*ble*ness, n.-- Ap"pli*ca*bly, adv.
addorsed: Set or turned back to back.
antibrachial: Of or pertaining to the antibrachium, or forearm.
apoplexy: Sudden diminution or loss of consciousness, sensation, andvoluntary motion, usually caused by pressure on the brain.
almanac: A book or table, containing a calendar of days, and months, towhich astronomical data and various statistics are often added, suchas the times of the rising and setting of the sun and moon, eclipses,hours of full tide, stated festivals of churches, terms of courts,etc. Nautical almanac, an almanac, or year book, containingastronomical calculations (lunar, stellar, etc.), and otherinformation useful to mariners.
anthozoic: Of or pertaining to the Anthozoa.
acronycally: In an acronycal manner as rising at the setting of the sun, andvise versâ.
antibody: Any of various bodies or substances in the blood which act inantagonism to harmful foreign bodies, as toxins or the bacteriaproducing the toxins. Normal blood serum apparently containsvariousantibodies, and the introduction of toxins or of foreign cellsalso results in the development of their specific antibodies.
acanthine: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the plant acanthus.
anaerobic: Relating to, or like, anaërobies; araërobiotic.
antimonsoon: The upper, contrary-moving current of the atmosphere over amonsoon.
ambrosia beetle: A bark beetle that feeds on ambrosia.
aromatization: The act of impregnating or secting with aroma.
alkahest: The fabled "universal solvent" of the alchemists; a menstruumcapable of dissolving all bodies.-- Al`ka*hes"tic, a.
anolis: A genus of lizards which belong to the family Iguanidæ. Theytake the place in the New World of the chameleons in the Old, and inAmerica are often called chameleons.
arteriology: That part of anatomy which treats of arteries.
araba: A wagon or cart, usually heavy and without springs, and oftencovered. [Oriental]
amphigonic: Pertaining to amphigony; sexual; as, amphigonic propagation.[R.]
aeromechanics: The science of equilibrium and motion of air or an aëriformfluid, including aërodynamics and aërostatics.
arrow grass: An herbaceous grasslike plant (Triglochin palustre, and otherspecies) with pods opening so as to suggest barbed arrowheads.
annealer: One who, or that which, anneals.
antinephritic: Counteracting, or deemed of use in, diseases of the kidneys.-- n.
apple-squire: A pimp; a kept gallant. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
assyriological: Of or pertaining to Assyriology; as, Assyriological studies.
ascensional: Relating to ascension; connected with ascent; ascensive;tending upward; as, the ascensional power of a balloon. Ascensionaldifference (Astron.), the difference between oblique and rightascension; -- used chiefly as expressing the difference between thetime of the rising or setting of a body and six o'clock, or six hoursfrom its meridian passage.
adjutory: Serving to help or assist; helping. [Obs.]
amphistylic: Having the mandibular arch articulated with the hyoid arch andthe cranium, as in the cestraciont sharks; -- said of a skull.
agger: An earthwork; a mound; a raised work. [Obs.] Hearne.
ambulatory: Not yet fixed legally, or settled past alteration; alterable;as, the dispositions of a will are ambulatory until the death of thetestator.
anemone: A genus of plants of the Ranunculus or Crowfoot family;windflower. Some of the species are cultivated in gardens.
absentment: The state of being absent; withdrawal. [R.] Barrow.
ammite: Oölite or roestone; -- written also hammite. [Obs.]
algoid: Of the nature of, or resembling, an alga.
adjument: Help; support; also, a helper. [Obs.] Waterhouse.
accountableness: The quality or state of being accountable; accountability.
anticoherer: A device, one form of which consists of a scratched deposit ofsilver on glass, used in connection with the receiving apparatus forreading wireless signals. The electric waves falling on thiscontrivance increase its resistance several times. The anticoherercan be used in conjunction with a telephone.
allottee: One to whom anything is allotted; one to whom an allotment ismade.
advantageous: Being of advantage; conferring advantage; gainful; profitable;useful; beneficial; as, an advantageous position; trade isadvantageous to a nation.Advabtageous comparison with any other country. Prescott.You see . . . of what use a good reputation is, and how swift andadvantageous a harbinger it is, wherever one goes. Chesterfield.
arterialize: To transform, as the venous blood, into arterial blood byexposure to oxygen in the lungs; to make arterial.
assistant: Of the second grade in the staff of the army; as, an assistantsurgeon. [U.S.]
alkalimeter: An instrument to ascertain the strength of alkalies, or thequantity of alkali in a mixture.
attemptable: Capable of being attempted, tried, or attacked. Shak.
amuck: In a frenzied and reckless. To run amuck, to rush out in astate of frenzy, as the Malays sometimes do under the influence of"bhang," and attack every one that comes in the way; to assailrecklessly and indiscriminately.Satire's my weapon, but I'm too discreet To run amuck, and tilt atall I meet. Pope.
adulterator: One who adulterates or corrupts. [R.] Cudworth.
allurer: One who, or that which, allures.
attorney: To perform by proxy; to employ as a proxy. [Obs.] Shak.
alkalify: To convert into an alkali; to give alkaline properties to.
apiary: A place where bees are kept; a stand or shed for bees; abeehouse.
anticipatory: Forecasting; of the nature of anticipation. Owen.Here is an anticipatory glance of what was to be. J. C. Shairp.
anisic: Of or derived from anise; as, anisic acid; anisic alcohol.
antagonize: To contend with; to oppose actively; to counteract.
armored cruiser: A man-of-war carrying a large coal supply, and more or lessprotected from the enemy's shot by iron or steel armor. There is nodistinct and accepted classification distinguishing armored andprotected cruisers from each other, except that the first have moreor heavier armor than the second.
arabesqued: Ornamented in the style of arabesques.
ascites: A collection of serous fluid in the cavity of the abdomen;dropsy of the peritoneum. Dunglison.
ametabolian: Of or pertaining to insects that do undergo any metamorphosis.
analogous: Having analogy; corresponding to something else; bearing someresemblance or proportion; -- often followed by to.Analogous tendencies in arts and manners. De Quincey.Decay of public spirit, which may be considered analogous to naturaldeath. J. H. Newman.nalogous pole (Pyroelect.), that pole of a crystal which becomespositively electrified when heated.
antimony: An elementary substance, resembling a metal in its appearanceand physical properties, but in its chemical relations belonging tothe class of nonmetallic substances. Atomic weight, 120. Symbol, Sb.
appealing: That appeals; imploring.-- Ap*peal"*ing*ly, adv.-- Ap*peal"ing*ness, n.
anagogics: Mystical interpretations or studies, esp. of the Scriptures. L.Addison.
archivist: A keeper of archives or records. [R.]
arctation: Constriction or contraction of some natural passage, as inconstipation from inflammation.
abstinent: Refraining from indulgence, especially from the indulgence ofappetite; abstemious; continent; temperate. Beau. & Fl.
anethol: A substance obtained from the volatile oils of anise, fennel,etc., in the form of soft shining scales; -- called also anisecamphor. Watts.
aonian: Pertaining to Aonia, Boeotia, or to the Muses, who weresupposed to dwell there. Aonian fount, the fountain of Aganippe, atthe foot of Mount Helicon, not far from Thebes, and sacred to theMuses.
ambs-ace: Double aces, the lowest throw of all at dice. Hence: Bad luck;anything of no account or value.
ad libitum: . At one's pleasure; as one wishes.
alphabetics: The science of representing spoken sounds by letters.
acne: A pustular affection of the skin, due to changes in thesebaceous glands.
allhallowtide: The time at or near All Saints, or November 1st.
alkalization: The act rendering alkaline by impregnating with an alkali; aconferring of alkaline qualities.
arcanum: A secret remedy; an elixir. Dunglison.
aristology: The science of dining. Quart. Rev.
ampelite: An earth abounding in pyrites, used by the ancients to killinsects, etc., on vines; -- applied by Brongniart to a carbonaceousalum schist.
anticivism: Opposition to the body politic of citizens. [Obs.] Carlyle.
alectryomancy: Divination by means of a cock and grains of corn placed on theletters of the alphabet, the letters being put together in the orderin which the grains were eaten. Amer. Cyc.
anchor light: The lantern shown at night by a vessel at anchor. Internationalrules of the road require vessels at anchor to carry from sunset tosunrise a single white light forward if under 150 feet in length, andif longer, two such lights, one near the stern and one forward.
armiger: Formerly, an armor bearer, as of a knight, an esquire who borehis shield and rendered other services. In later use, one next indegree to a knight, and entitled to armorial bearings. The term isnow superseded by esquire. Jacob.
achievement: An escutcheon or ensign armorial; now generally applied to thefuneral shield commonly called hatchment. Cussans.
acarine: Of or caused by acari or mites; as, acarine diseases.
adjunct: Conjoined; attending; consequent.Though that my death were adjunct to my act. Shak.Adjunct notes (Mus.), short notes between those essential to theharmony; auxiliary notes; passing notes.
anito: In Guam and the Philippines, an idol, fetich, or spirit.
apple-john: A kind of apple which by keeping becomes much withered; --called also Johnapple. Shak.
a: The first letter of the English and of many other alphabets.The capital A of the alphabets of Middle and Western Europe, as alsothe small letter (a), besides the forms in Italic, black letter,etc., are all descended from the old Latin A, which was borrowed fromthe Greek Alpha, of the same form; and this was made from the firstletter (Aleph, and itself from the Egyptian origin. The Aleph was aconsonant letter, with a guttural breath sound that was not anelement of Greek articulation; and the Greeks took it to representtheir vowel Alpha with the ä sound, the Phoenician alphabet having novowel symbols. This letter, in English, is used for several differentvowel sounds. See Guide to pronunciation, §§ 43-74. The regular longa, as in fate, etc., is a comparatively modern sound, and has takenthe place of what, till about the early part of the 17th century, wasa sound of the quality of ä (as in far).
ammonitoidea: An extensive group of fossil cephalopods often very abundant inMesozoic rocks. See Ammonite.
angioma: A tumor composed chiefly of dilated blood vessels.
anomalism: An anomaly; a deviation from rule. Hooker.
amidin: Start modified by heat so as to become a transparent mass, likehorn. It is soluble in cold water.
archiepiscopate: The office of an archbishop; an archbishopric.
australian: Of or pertaining to Australia.-- n.
aegrotat: A medical certificate that a student is ill.
apogamy: The formation of a bud in place of a fertilized ovule oroöspore. De Bary.
argentite: Sulphide of silver; -- also called vitreous silver, or silverglance. It has a metallic luster, a lead-gray color, and is sectilelike lead.
apron man: A man who wears an apron; a laboring man; a mechanic. [Obs.]Shak.
aphis lion: The larva of the lacewinged flies (Chrysopa), which feedsvoraciously upon aphids. The name is also applied to the larvæ of theladybugs (Coccinella).
atlantides: The Pleiades or seven stars, fabled to have been the daughtersof Atlas.
approve: To make profit of; to convert to one's own profit; said esp. ofwaste or common land appropriated by the lord of the manor.
ailuroidea: A group of the Carnivora, which includes the cats, civets, andhyenas.
aster: A genus of herbs with compound white or bluish flowers;starwort; Michaelmas daisy.
alegge: To allay or alleviate; to lighten. [Obs.]That shall alegge this bitter blast. Spenser.
abject: To cast off or down; hence, to abase; to degrade; to lower; todebase. [Obs.] Donne.
admonition: Gentle or friendly reproof; counseling against a fault orerror; expression of authoritative advice; friendly caution orwarning.
acetal: A limpid, colorless, inflammable liquid from the slow oxidationof alcohol under the influence of platinum black.
attrite: Repentant from fear of punishment; having attrition of grieffor sin; -- opposed to contrite.
aplanatic: Having two or more parts of different curvatures, so combinedas to remove spherical aberration; -- said of a lens. Aplanatic focusof a lens (Opt.), the point or focus from which rays diverging passthe lens without spherical aberration. In certain forms of lensesthere are two such foci; and it is by taking advantage of this factthat the best aplanatic object glasses of microscopes areconstructed.
abstain: To hold one's self aloof; to forbear or refrain voluntarily,and especially from an indulgence of the passions or appetites; --with from.Not a few abstained from voting. Macaulay.Who abstains from meat that is not gaunt Shak.
amiss: Astray; faultily; improperly; wrongly; ill.What error drives our eyes and ears amiss Shak.Ye ask and receive not, because ye ask amiss. James iv. 3.To take (an act, thing) amiss, to impute a wrong motive to (an act orthing); to take offense at' to take unkindly; as, you must not takethese questions amiss.
anaglyptic: Relating to the art of carving, enchasing, or embossing in lowrelief.
anisopoda: A division of Crustacea, which, in some its characteristics, isintermediate between Amphipoda and Isopoda.
automixte system: A system (devised by Henri Pieper, a Belgian) of drivingautomobiles employing a gasoline engine and an auxiliary reversibledynamo. When there is an excess of power the dynamo is driven by theengine so as to charge a small storage battery; when there is adeficiency of power the dynamo reverses and acts as an auxiliarymotor. Sometimes called Pieper system. -- Automixte car, etc.
amt: An administrative territorial division in Denmark and Norway.
apostolic: A member of one of certain ascetic sects which at various timesprofessed to imitate the practice of the apostles.
adiaphoristic: Pertaining to matters indifferent in faith and practice.Shipley.
adagio: Slow; slowly, leisurely, and gracefully. When repeated, adagio,adagio, it directs the movement to be very slow.
abstractedness: The state of being abstracted; abstract character.
amicableness: The quality of being amicable; amicability.
agricolist: A cultivator of the soil; an agriculturist. Dodsley.
anasarca: Dropsy of the subcutaneous cellular tissue; an effusion ofserum into the cellular substance, occasioning a soft, pale,inelastic swelling of the skin.
autocephalous: Having its own head; independent of episcopal or patriarchaljurisdiction, as certain Greek churches.
apprize: To appraise; to value; to appreciate.
amphipodous: Of or pertaining to the Amphipoda.
attitudinarianism: A practicing of attitudes; posture making.
antiquarian: Pertaining to antiquaries, or to antiquity; as, antiquarianliterature.
airling: A thoughtless, gay person. [Obs.] "Slight airlings." B. Jonson.
apteryx: A genus of New Zealand birds about the size of a hen, with onlyshort rudiments of wings, armed with a claw and without a tail; thekiwi. It is allied to the gigantic extinct moas of the same country.Five species are known.
abdication: The act of abdicating; the renunciation of a high office,dignity, or trust, by its holder; commonly the voluntary renunciationof sovereign power; as, abdication of the throne, government, power,authority.
ascidiozooid: One of the individual members of a compound ascidian. SeeAscidioidea.
adrift: Floating at random; in a drifting condition; at the mercy ofwind and waves. Also fig.So on the sea shall be set adrift. Dryden.Were from their daily labor turned adrift. Wordsworth.
area: The superficial contents of any figure; the surface includedwithin any given lines; superficial extent; as, the area of a squareor a triangle.
awned: Furnished with an awn, or long bristle-shaped tip; bearded.Gray.
adjuster: One who, or that which, adjusts.
apocynin: A bitter principle obtained from the dogbane (Apocynumcannabinum).
ascidioidea: A group of Tunicata, often shaped like a two-necked bottle. Thegroup includes, social, and compound species. The gill is a netlikestructure within the oral aperture. The integument is usuallyleathery in texture. See Illustration in Appendix.
another-guess: Of another sort. [Archaic]It used to go in another-guess manner. Arbuthnot.
ago: Past; gone by; since; as, ten years ago; gone long ago.
apophyllite: A mineral relating to the zeolites, usually occurring in squareprisms or octahedrons with pearly luster on the cleavage surface. Itis a hydrous silicate of calcium and potassium.
atheromatous: Of, pertaining to, or having the nature of, atheroma. Wiseman.
amplificatory: Serving to amplify or enlarge; amplificative. Morell.
addibility: The quantity of being addible; capability of addition. Locke.
anhinga: An aquatic bird of the southern United States (Platus anhinga);the darter, or snakebird.
anthem: To celebrate with anthems. [Poet.]Sweet birds antheming the morn. Keats.
anomaly: Any deviation from the essential characteristics of a specifictype.
abecedary: A primer; the first principle or rudiment of anything. [R.]Fuller.
aber-de-vine: The European siskin (Carduelis spinus), a small green andyellow finch, related to the goldfinch.
astyllen: A small dam to prevent free passage of water in an adit orlevel.
alure: A walk or passage; -- applied to passages of various kinds.The sides of every street were covered with fresh alures of marble.T. Warton.
angiostomous: With a narrow mouth, as the shell of certain gastropods.
absorbedly: In a manner as if wholly engrossed or engaged.
amniota: That group of vertebrates which develops in its embryonic lifethe envelope called the amnion. It comprises the reptiles, the birds,and the mammals.
arrowroot: A west Indian plant of the genus Maranta, esp. M. arundinacea,now cultivated in many hot countries. It said that the Indians usedthe roots to neutralize the venom in wounds made by poisoned arrows.
arete: An acute and rugged crest of a mountain range or a subsidiaryridge between two mountain gorges.
alienate: Estranged; withdrawn in affection; foreign; -- with from.O alienate from God. Milton.
administer: To settle, as the estate of one who dies without a will, orwhose will fails of an executor.
alphabetically: In an alphabetic manner; in the customary order of the letters.
ampleness: The state or quality of being ample; largeness; fullness;completeness.
ament: A species of inflorescence; a catkin.The globular ament of a buttonwood. Coues.
anthropophagy: The eating of human flesh; cannibalism.
accelerograph: An apparatus for studying the combustion of powder in guns,etc.
astrolabe: An instrument for observing or showing the positions of thestars. It is now disused.
anglomania: A mania for, or an inordinate attachment to, English customs,institutions, etc.
avail: To be of use or advantage; to answer the purpose; to havestrength, force, or efficacy sufficient to accomplish the object; as,the plea in bar must avail, that is, be sufficient to defeat thesuit; this scheme will not avail; medicines will not avail to checkthe disease. "What signs avail " Milton.Words avail very little with me, young man. Sir W. Scott.
adhesion: The molecular attraction exerted between bodies in contact. SeeCohesion.
anarthrous: Used without the article; as, an anarthrous substantive.
asperser: One who asperses; especially, one who vilifies another.
alamode: According to the fashion or prevailing mode. "Alamode beefshops." Macaulay.
anosmia: Loss of the sense of smell.
alibi: The plea or mode of defense under which a person on trial for acrime proves or attempts to prove that he was in another place whenthe alleged act was committed; as, to set up an alibi; to prove analibi.
