abalienate: To transfer the title of from one to another; to alienate.
arquated: Shaped like a bow; arcuate; curved. [R.]
aeriality: The state of being aërial; [R.] De Quincey.
armipotent: Powerful in arms; mighty in battle.The temple stood of Mars armipotent. Dryden.
aquosity: The condition of being wet or watery; wateriness. Huxley.Very little water or aquosity is found in their belly. Holland.
adamantean: Of adamant; hard as adamant. Milton.
aphasic: Pertaining to, or affected by, aphasia; speechless.
apostatize: To renounce totally a religious belief once professed; toforsake one's church, the faith or principles once held, or the partyto which one has previously adhered.He apostatized from his old faith in facts, took to believing inCarlyle.
ant bird: See Ant bird, under Ant, n.
ammoniacal fermentation: Any fermentation process by which ammonia is formed, as that bywhich urea is converted into ammonium carbonate when urine is exposedto the air.
acolyte: One who has received the highest of the four minor orders inthe Catholic church, being ordained to carry the wine and water andthe lights at the Mass.
artiodactyla: One of the divisions of the ungulate animals. The functionaltoes of the hind foot are even in number, and the third digit of eachfoot (corresponding to the middle finger in man) is asymmetrical andpaired with the fourth digit, as in the hog, the sheep, and the ox; -- opposed to Perissodactyla.
adorement: The act of adoring; adoration. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
appetent: Desiring; eagerly desirous. [R.]Appetent after glory and renown. Sir G. Buck.
amphiuma: A genus of amphibians, inhabiting the Southern United States,having a serpentlike form, but with four minute limbs and twopersistent gill openings; the Congo snake.
amethyst: A variety of crystallized quartz, of a purple or bluish violetcolor, of different shades. It is much used as a jeweler's stone.Oriental amethyst, the violet-blue variety of transparentcrystallized corundum or sapphire.
absinthium: The common wormwood (Artemisia absinthium), an intensely bitterplant, used as a tonic and for making the oil of wormwood.
aleurometer: An instrument for determining the expansive properties, orquality, of gluten in flour. Knight.
adverbialize: To give the force or form of an adverb to.
allomerism: Variability in chemical constitution without variation incrystalline form.
areometry: The art or process of measuring the specific gravity of fluids.
amorosity: The quality of being amorous; lovingness. [R.] Galt.
abdominales: A group including the greater part of fresh-water fishes, andmany marine ones, having the ventral fins under the abdomen behindthe pectorals.
aborticide: The act of destroying a fetus in the womb; feticide.
addible: Capable of being added. "Addible numbers." Locke.
awanting: Missing; wanting. [Prov. Scot. & Eng.] Sir W. Hamilton.
astroscope: An old astronomical instrument, formed of two cones, on whosesurface the constellations were delineated.
allayment: An allaying; that which allays; mitigation. [Obs.]The like allayment could I give my grief. Shak.
acetable: An acetabulum; or about one eighth of a pint. [Obs.] Holland.
apprecatory: Praying or wishing good. [Obs.]"Apprecatory benedictions." Bp.Hall.
appendiculata: An order of annelids; the Polychæta.
amphora: Among the ancients, a two-handled vessel, tapering at thebottom, used for holding wine, oil, etc.
actino-chemistry: Chemistry in its relations to actinism. Draper.
ambassadress: A female ambassador; also, the wife of an ambassador. Prescott.
abstemiousness: The quality of being abstemious, temperate, or sparing in theuse of food and strong drinks. It expresses a greater degree ofabstinence than temperance.
alpen: Of or pertaining to the Alps. [R.] "The Alpen snow." J.Fletcher.
adambulacral: Next to the ambulacra; as, the adambulacral ossicles of thestarfish.
abietite: A substance resembling mannite, found in the needles of thecommon silver fir of Europe (Abies pectinata). Eng. Cyc.
argillaceous: Of the nature of clay; consisting of, or containing, argil orclay; clayey. Argillaceous sandstone (Geol.), a sandstone containingmuch clay.-- Argillaceous iron ore, the clay ironstone.-- Argillaceous schist or state. See Argillite.
arrasene: A material of wool or silk used for working the figures inembroidery.
attenuant: Making thin, as fluids; diluting; rendering less dense andviscid; diluent.-- n. (Med.)
amitotic: Of or pertaining to amitosis; karyostenotic; -- opposed tomitotic.
archimedean: Of or pertaining to Archimedes, a celebrated Greek philosopher;constructed on the principle of Archimedes' screw; as, Archimedeandrill, propeller, etc. Archimedean screw, or Archimedes' screw, aninstrument, said to have been invented by Archimedes, for raisingwater, formed by winding a flexible tube round a cylinder in the formof a screw. When the screw is placed in an inclined position, and thelower end immersed in water, by causing the screw to revolve, thewater is raised to the upper end. Francis.
atazir: The influence of a star upon other stars or upon men. [Obs.]Chaucer.
aerially: Like, or from, the air; in an aërial manner. "A murmur heardaërially." Tennyson.
amphisbaena: A genus of harmless lizards, serpentlike in form, without legs,and with both ends so much alike that they appear to have a head ateach, and ability to move either way. See Illustration in Appendix.
antique: In general, anything very old; but in a more limited sense, arelic or object of ancient art; collectively, the antique, theremains of ancient art, as busts, statues, paintings, and vases.Misshapen monuments and maimed antiques. Byron.
anachronous: Containing an anachronism; anachronistic.-- An*ach"ro*nous*ly, adv.
asystolism: The state or symptoms characteristic of asystole.
award: To give by sentence or judicial determination; to assign orapportion, after careful regard to the nature of the case; toadjudge; as, the arbitrators awarded damages to the complainant.To review The wrongful sentence, and award a new. Dryden.
actinic: Of or pertaining to actinism; as, actinic rays.
advertise: To give notice to; to inform or apprise; to notify; to makeknown; hence, to warn; -- often followed by of before the subject ofinformation; as, to advertise a man of his loss. [Archaic]I will advertise thee what this people shall do. Num. xxiv. 14.
abusively: In an abusive manner; rudely; with abusive language.
argilliferous: Producing clay; -- applied to such earths as abound with argil.Kirwan.
annotine: A bird one year old, or that has once molted.
amuletic: Of or pertaining to an amulet; operating as a charm.
alomancy: Divination by means of salt. [Spelt also halomancy.] Morin.
audition: The act of hearing or listening; hearing.Audition may be active or passive; hence the difference betweenlistening and simple hearing. Dunglison.
appreciate: To rise in value. [See note under Rise, v. i.] J. Morse.
anguish: Extreme pain, either of body or mind; excruciating distress.But they hearkened not unto Moses for anguish of spirit, and forcruel bondage. Ex. vi. 9.Anguish as of her that bringeth forth her first child. Jer. iv. 31.
acceptancy: Acceptance. [R.]Here's a proof of gift, But here's no proof, sir, of acceptancy. Mrs.Browning.
aphorism: A comprehensive maxim or principle expressed in a few words; asharply defined sentence relating to abstract truth rather than topractical matters.The first aphorism of Hippocrates is, "Life is short, and the art islong." Fleming.
applique: Ornamented with a pattern (which has been cut out of anothercolor or stuff) applied or transferred to a foundation; as, appliquélace; appliqué work.
anaphora: A repetition of a word or of words at the beginning of two ormore successive clauses.
arval: A funeral feast. [North of Eng.] Grose.
aphyllous: Destitute of leaves, as the broom rape, certain euphorbiaceousplants, etc.
anal: Pertaining to, or situated near, the anus; as, the anal fin orglands.
al segno: A direction for the performer to return and recommence from thesign
anabaptist: A name sometimes applied to a member of any sect holding thatrebaptism is necessary for those baptized in infancy.
augurship: The office, or period of office, of an augur. Bacon.
ambidextrousness: The quality of being ambidextrous; ambidexterity.
anaclastics: That part of optics which treats of the refraction of light; --commonly called dioptrics. Encyc. Brit.
amaranth: A genus of ornamental annual plants (Amaranthus) of manyspecies, with green, purplish, or crimson flowers.
amphiprostyle: Doubly prostyle; having columns at each end, but not at thesides.-- n.
archer fish: A small fish (Toxotes jaculator), of the East Indies; -- socalled from its ejecting drops of water from its mouth at its prey.The name is also applied to Chætodon rostratus.
anthropotomy: The anatomy or dissection of the human body; androtomy. Owen.
abominably: In an abominable manner; very odiously; detestably.
anasarcous: Belonging, or affected by, anasarca, or dropsy; dropsical.Wiseman.
allegorist: One who allegorizes; a writer of allegory. Hume.
appoggiatura: A passing tone preceding an essential tone, and borrowing thetime it occupies from that; a short auxiliary or grace note onedegree above or below the principal note unless it be of the sameharmony; -- generally indicated by a note of smaller size, as in theillustration above. It forms no essential part of the harmony.
anno domini: In the year of the Christian era; as, a. d. 1887.
apsidal: Of or pertaining to the apsides of an orbit.
anisopleura: A primary division of gastropods, including those having spiralshells. The two sides of the body are unequally developed.
armorist: One skilled in coat armor or heraldry. Cussans.
amadou: A spongy, combustible substance, prepared from fungus (Boletusand Polyporus) which grows on old trees; German tinder; punk. It hasbeen employed as a styptic by surgeons, but its common use is astinder, for which purpose it is prepared by soaking it in a strongsolution of niter. Ure.
anti-american: Opposed to the Americans, their aims, or interests, or to thegenius of American institutions. Marshall.
argive: Of or performance to Argos, the capital of Argolis in Greece.-- n.
apodeme: One of the processes of the shell which project inwards andunite with one another, in the thorax of many Crustacea.
anglophobia: Intense dread of, or aversion to, England or the English.-- An"glo*phobe, n.
acanthocarpous: Having the fruit covered with spines.
arriere: "That which is behind"; the rear; -- chiefly used as anadjective in the sense of behind, rear, subordinate. Arriere fee,Arriere fief, a fee or fief dependent on a superior fee, or a feeheld of a feudatory.-- Arriere vassal, the vassal of a vassal.
authorless: Without an author; without authority; anonymous.
alarmist: One prone to sound or excite alarms, especially, needlessalarms. Macaulay.
agree: To correspond in gender, number, case, or person.
antiphthisic: Relieving or curing phthisis, or consumption.-- n.
anarthropodous: Having no jointed legs; pertaining to Anarthropoda.
authentics: A collection of the Novels or New Constitutions of Justinian,by an anonymous author; -- so called on account of its authencity.Bouvier.
arbuscular: Of or pertaining to a dwarf tree; shrublike. Da Costa.
arrogation: Adoption of a person of full age.
aver: A work horse, or working ox. [Obs. or Dial. Eng.]
autocratrix: A female sovereign who is independent and absolute; -- a titlegiven to the empresses of Russia.
annulata: A class of articulate animals, nearly equivalent to Annelida,including the marine annelids, earthworms, Gephyrea, Gymnotoma,leeches, etc. See Annelida.
artificer: A military mechanic, as a blacksmith, carpenter, etc.; also,one who prepares the shells, fuses, grenades, etc., in a militarylaboratory.
anamnestic: Aiding the memory; as, anamnestic remedies.
aztec: Of or relating to one of the early races in Mexico thatinhabited the great plateau of that country at the time of theSpanish conquest in 1519.-- n.
albedo: Whiteness. Specifically: (Astron.) The ratio which the lightreflected from an unpolished surface bears to the total light fallingupon that surface.
ampere turn: A unit equal to the product of one complete convolution (of acoiled conductor) into one ampère of current; thus, a conductorhaving five convolutions and carrying a current of half an ampère issaid to have 2½ ampère turns. The magnetizing effect of a coil isproportional to the number of its ampère turns.
arrish: The stubble of wheat or grass; a stubble field; eddish. [Eng.][Written also arish, ersh, etc.]The moment we entered the stubble or arrish. Blackw. Mag.
alogian: One of an ancient sect who rejected St. John's Gospel and theApocalypse, which speak of Christ as the Logos. Shipley.
anthropogeny: The science or study of human generation, or the origin anddevelopment of man.
abolishment: The act of abolishing; abolition; destruction. Hooker.
angelicalness: The quality of being angelic; excellence more than human.
antitypical: Of or pertaining to an antitype; explaining the type.-- An`ti*typ"ic*al*ly, adv.
acromonogrammatic: Having each verse begin with the same letter as that with whichthe preceding verse ends.
allnight: Light, fuel, or food for the whole night. [Obs.] Bacon.
anchorless: Without an anchor or stay. Hence: Drifting; unsettled.
ankus: An elephant goad with a sharp spike and hook, resembling ashort-handled boat hook. [India] Kipling.
amendment: Correction of an error in a writ or process.
angina: Any inflammatory affection of the throat or faces, as thequinsy, malignant sore throat, croup, etc., especially such as tendsto produce suffocation, choking, or shortness of breath. Anginapectoris, a peculiarly painful disease, so named from a sense ofsuffocating contraction or tightening of the lower part of the chest;-- called also breast pang, spasm of the chest.
anhelation: Short and rapid breathing; a panting; asthma. Glanvill.
absinthate: A combination of absinthic acid with a base or positiveradical.
anatomically: In an anatomical manner; by means of dissection.
altarpiece: The painting or piece of sculpture above and behind the altar;reredos.
actively: In an active signification; as, a word used actively.
anthracite: A hard, compact variety of mineral coal, of high luster,differing from bituminous coal in containing little or no bitumen, inconsequence of which it burns with a nearly non luminous flame. Thepurer specimens consist almost wholly of carbon. Also called glancecoal and blind coal.
additive: Proper to be added; positive; -- opposed to subtractive.
acquirement: The act of acquiring, or that which is acquired; attainment."Rules for the acquirement of a taste." Addison.His acquirements by industry were . . . enriched and enlarged by manyexcellent endowments of nature. Hayward.
archimedes: An extinct genus of Bryzoa characteristic of thesubcarboniferous rocks. Its form is that of a screw.
absinthiated: Impregnated with wormwood; as, absinthiated wine.
auriscopy: Examination of the ear by the aid of the auriscope.
anthropomorphite: One who ascribes a human form or human attributes to the Deityor to a polytheistic deity. Taylor. Specifically, one of a sect ofancient heretics who believed that God has a human form, etc.Tillotson.
apollinaris water: An effervescing alkaline mineral water used as a tablebeverage. It is obtained from a spring in Apollinarisburg, near Bonn.
aliunde: From another source; from elsewhere; as, a case proved aliunde;evidence aliunde.
avel: To pull away. [Obs.]Yet are not these parts avelled. Sir T. Browne.
affability: The quality of being affable; readiness to converse;courteousness in receiving others and in conversation; complaisantbehavior.Affability is of a wonderful efficacy or power in procuring love.Elyot
australian ballot: A system of balloting or voting in public elections, originallyused in South Australia, in which there is such an arrangement forpolling votes that secrecy is compulsorily maintained, and the ballotused is an official ballot printed and distributed by the government.
arsenic: One of the elements, a solid substance resembling a metal inits physical properties, but in its chemical relations ranking withthe nonmetals. It is of a steel-gray color and brilliant luster,though usually dull from tarnish. It is very brittle, and sublimes at356º Fahrenheit. It is sometimes found native, but usually combinedwith silver, cobalt, nickel, iron, antimony, or sulphur. Orpiment andrealgar are two of its sulphur compounds, the first of which is thetrue arsenticum of the ancients. The element and its compounds areactive poisons. Specific gravity from 5.7 to 5.9. Atomic weight.Symbol As.
afforestation: The act of converting into forest or woodland. Blackstone.
acephalocyst: A larval entozoön in the form of a subglobular or oval vesicle,or hy datid, filled with fluid, sometimes found in the tissues of manand the lower animals; -- so called from the absence of a head orvisible organs on the vesicle. These cysts are the immature stages ofcertain tapeworms. Also applied to similar cysts of different origin.
aeronautics: The science or art of ascending and sailing in the air, as bymeans of a balloon; aërial navigation; ballooning.
atomicity: Degree of atomic attraction; equivalence; valence; also (alater use) the number of atoms in an elementary molecule. SeeValence.
alligate: To tie; to unite by some tie.Instincts alligated to their nature. Sir M. Hale.
allotriophagy: A depraved appetite; a desire for improper food.
autocratship: The office or dignity of an autocrat.
actualist: One who deals with or considers actually existing facts andconditions, rather than fancies or theories; -- opposed to idealist.J. Grote.
assumption: The minor or second proposition in a categorical syllogism.
antenna: A movable, articulated organ of sensation, attached to theheads of insects and Crustacea. There are two in the former, andusually four in the latter. They are used as organs of touch, and insome species of Crustacea the cavity of the ear is situated near thebasal joint. In insects, they are popularly called horns, and alsofeelers. The term in also applied to similar organs on the heads ofother arthropods and of annelids.
asteroid: A starlike body; esp. one of the numerous small planets whoseorbits lie between those of Mars and Jupiter; -- called alsoplanetoids and minor planets.
ayle: A grandfather. [Obs.] Writ of Ayle, an ancient English writwhich lay against a stranger who had dispossessed the demandant ofland of which his grandfather died seized.
aback: Backward against the mast;-said of the sails when pressed bythe wind. Totten. To be taken aback. (a) To be driven backwardagainst the mast; -- said of the sails, also of the ship when thesails are thus driven. (b) To be suddenly checked, baffled, ordiscomfited. Dickens.
aggregation: The act of aggregating, or the state of being aggregated;collection into a mass or sum; a collection of particulars; anaggregate.
arch brick: A wedge-shaped brick used in the building of an arch.
aloft: In the top; at the mast head, or on the higher yards orrigging; overhead; hence (Fig. and Colloq.), in or to heaven.
ableness: Ability of body or mind; force; vigor. [Obs. or R.]
arabian: Of or pertaining to Arabia or its inhabitants. Arabian bird,the phenix. Shak.
asbolin: A peculiar acrid and bitter oil, obtained from wood soot.
abay: Barking; baying of dogs upon their prey. See Bay. [Obs.]
adjoining: Joining to; contiguous; adjacent; as, an adjoining room. "Theadjoining fane." Dryden.Upon the hills adjoining to the city. Shak.
aeolotropic: Exhibiting differences of quality or property in differentdirections; not isotropic. Sir W. Thomson.
apogeotropic: Bending away from the ground; -- said of leaves, etc. Darwin.
abjudge: To take away by judicial decision. [R.]
affinity: That attraction which takes place, at an insensible distance,between the heterogeneous particles of bodies, and unites them toform chemical compounds; chemism; chemical or elective affinity orattraction.
aurigal: Of or pertaining to a chariot. [R.]
accadian: Pertaining to a race supposed to have lived in Babylonia beforethe Assyrian conquest.-- Ac*ca"di*an, n., Ac"cad, n. Sayce.
antiphlogistian: An opposer of the theory of phlogiston.
albumin: A thick, viscous nitrogenous substance, which is the chief andcharacteristic constituent of white of eggs and of the serum ofblood, and is found in other animal substances, both fluid and solid,also in many plants. It is soluble in water is coagulated by heat adby certain chemical reagents. Acid albumin, a modification of albuminproduced by the action of dilute acids. It is not coagulated by heat.-- Alkali albumin, albumin as modified by the action of alkalinesubstances; -- called also albuminate.
annotinous: A year old; in Yearly growths.
apparel: The furniture of a ship, as masts, sails, rigging, anchors,guns, etc.
